Nice flowery hoppy aroma, malty base.
Flavor is dry, malty, slightly bitter caramelly, flowery hoppy, bitter hoppy, Good american agressive hoppy beer, a little on the bittersweet side. Also notes of berries. pretty complex flavor.
Bottle. Pours dark amber. Lots of lacing. Lasting head. Aromas of citrus, pine,medicine and resin. Taste is similar. Lots of citrus and pine. Long bitter aftertaste. Pretty drinkable.

A super caramel red.  A very balanced nose with caramel malts lending a bold backdrop for bright and citric hops. Puffy and spicy in the mouth with lots of peppery hotness and fresh green hop flavours. Smooth and bold it could be a little potent for any kind of session but it is manically tasty.

Wow. One of the best, if not the best red Ive ever had in my life. This is of the class of strong reds thats lighter and more carbonated, which I prefer to the heavier, sweeter types. Very similar to Lagunitas imperial red, but substantially better. Awesome.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home on the terrace.Clear dark amber colour with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, citrus, orange - citrus, warm citrus. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, warm citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110507]

12 oz bottle: Aroma has an upfront nice hoppy floral, candy-like scent, and a very little of roasted and caramel aromas.  Appearance is a dark amber almost a clear brownish with a off white head that lingers.  Taste has got a nice hop bite, very subtle malt characteristic but a little smoky and caramel malt notes that are in there.  Palate has a medium body, hop forward, lively, and a bitter finish.  Overall, Really nice beer overall.  Cheers!

red rocket in a taster at urge gastropub.  Small thin off-white head.  Ruby red color.  Very red taste with an all-around light bitter biting hop taste.  Rather strong complex caramel toasty honey and red malt complexion.  Lacing was quite lovely.  Overall 7.5 of 10.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of toasted malts, caramel, resin and citrus hops.  Deep red/amber hue with an average off-white hue that mostly diminished and left some lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and bitter.  Palate is medium bodied and oily soft.  Overall a good drinking brew with a great name.

(12oz bottle).  Pours a hazy mahogany color with thick off-white head.  Has aroma of cardboard, florals, caramel, and some alcohol.  Taste is malty with some hop bitterness.  Medium bodied with an oily texture.  Bitter finish.  Its a little too malty for my liking, but otherwise, its a nice beer.

Reddish orange pour with small head. Bottle. Aroma full of sharp, bitter hops and a touch of mild sugar. Flavor of tropical fruit, grapefruit rind, pine needles and a hint of biscuit. a nice, refreshing am strong ale.

22oz bottle from SuperMarket liquors in Fort Collins 
Appearance: Dark amber with a nice sized off-white head and lots of sticky lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, caramel and dark fruits 
Taste: Toasted malts, fruity, caramel with a bitter finish 
A nice easy drinking beer. Plenty of caramel but not cloying.
slightly metallic, hoppy, bitter, rye. pours a cloudy dark brown/amber. earthy, herbal, hops finish. not quite what i was expecting. pretty good, though.
Bottle.  Reddish brown, cloudy, light tan head.   Sweet, caramel aroma.  Medium to full body, smooth. Good finish. Very good all around beer - nice balance, taste, finish.

Pours a mahogany red with medium off-white head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, floral hops, and ever so slight nutty and dried fruits.  Flavor matches well and comes together very nicely.  Thanks Bear Republic, this is a nice change of pace beer.

Bottle from Total Wine. Poured murky, with a mahogany color and a tan, lacing minimal head. Berries dominate the aroma with hints of apple, honey, vanilla, bit of cellar. Earthy taste that melts into a pleasant, dry bitterness. Fruity, bitter finish. Good one!

12 fl.oz., courtesy of Balazs, thanks!
Poured deep amber-brown with a small foamy-creamy tan head. Caramel, candy, some fruit, raspberries-wild fruits, raisins, a bit of herbal hop. Medium bodied beer with candy taste again, berries in the flavor, caramel, a powerful herbal, mild resiny bit of hop in the finish.

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Dense begie head. Aroma of caramel, pine, herbs, flowers. Flavour of pine, caramel, some herbs, grass and flowers. Spice notable. Medium to full bodied. Has a nice tense bitterness in the end. Lovely and very easy to drink.

Pours a deep amber red with aroma of dry roasted malt.  Taste is slightly sweet, with a slight bitter aftertaste.  This beer is not overly bitter but packs a little bitter punch throughout.  It got better as the beer finished, overall a good hybrid strong ale.

This brew is one killer red.  It wants with all its heart to be Scottish, to be malty and toffee-centered and kilt-clad, but the hops smash these aspirations all to pieces.  In a good way.  Red Rocket balances a rich, sweet caramel malt front with a prolonged, Cascadian finish, bitter and piney and vital to keeping this brew from devolving into a syrupy mess.  Perfect for a hop fix without any IBU brutality.
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear deep red/brown -  offwhite head. Berries, fruity, nice hoppy, toasted, amber malts, light bitterness, roasted, nutty, piney. Nice.
Pours a nice reddish brown color.  Taste is wonderful.  Has a nice bitter aftertaste with some malty goodness at the beginning.  Aroma is slightly bitter.
Shared with yalnikim. Darker than I expected, abounds with rich malt. I didnt get the hops that others had, but still got the delight.

Sampler at the W&C in Ballwin, Mo.  It poured a hazy reddish color with a beige head. The aroma was of caramel, citrus and pine. The flavor was of hops and citrus rind, possibly grapefruit. A very well balanced brew.

The beer pours a dark amber with a white head, good head but lacking on the lacing.

The smell is light and bitter of hops.

Im not a big fan of amber ales, but this one started to sway my mind. It was full and filling with a light bitter taste and complex flavors of spice. Mouthfeel was nice and heavy, drinkability ok.

22 oz bomber poured out a medium red brown ale. Nice head which left good lacing. Aromas of hops with a pine scent Roasted malts add a nice backbone of sweetness to balance the hoppiness of this brew. Tastes of pine resin toffee and roasted malts. Strong hop presence typical of a California IPA.

12oz bottle. 
Dark red color, small amount of white head with some lacing.   Aromas of caramel malt and citrus hops.  Good balance of bitterness and sweetness - very tasty.

Bomber from Discount Waukesha.  Pours a cherry cola reddish brown with big floating chunks.  Aroma is earthy rich molasses with sweet fruits.  Taste is sweet toffee, raisins, some citrus, some resin - sweet and thick.  A hint of that earthiness carries through.  A hint of alcohol shows as it warms.
Poured from a bottle and it had a nice dark amber reddish color. Toasty hop aroma with a touch of dried fruits. It delivers a big flavor of barley & malts with a long finish. Unique beer.

some ruby, with a moderate amount of quickly dissipating khaki-white head. The aroma is great on this one - dried apricot and grapefruit coming through immediately with hints of resinous hops and slight toasty malt. Taste is much the same as the aroma, with a variety of resinous and citrusy hop flavors coming through over a muted malt backbone. finishes relatively clean for such a hoppy brew, with no alcohol flavors at all.

Bottle; Pour is dark brown/amber with an off white head. The scottish feel doesnt exactly dominate, for me. I mean - really, you have that bready malt, graininess, toffee, caramel, peat, and an interesting hop bitterness on the tongue as well. This is a nice brew..... I dont  know about the american strong ale tag, either. Either way

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 Location/Date:Bottle on February 2nd, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a dark brown. 
Aroma: Caramely malty aroma.
Taste: Medium bitterness, very strong malt that is sweet.
Palate:Lingering aftertaste.
Summary: This bottle was in the fridge for awhile, BUT still, it comes out tasty. My rating this second is while its cold, but I think Im going to let this warm up a bit and possibly add some more notes.

Always enjoy Bear Republics beers.  This was a nice American Stronge Ale, I need to rate it again.

A: Pours dark, dark red. Can barely see through it. Head is about a finger of light tan.

S: A light scent of hops, malts are evident, too. Almost smells like a pale ale.

T: Not outstanding, but good tasting. Hops and malt are balanced well. Again, like a pale ale.

M: Medium carbonation, really creamy mouthfeel. I dont remember the last time Ive had this smoothness in a hoppy beer.

D: Pretty darn good. Would be a good summer beer. Nice, smooth, and refreshing. Not particularly my favorite beer, but I wouldnt turn one down.

At a tasting, Thanks David, pours deep stunning red with a medium tan head, aroma of peach, apricot, strawberry, cherries and plums, flavor is bitter and crisp with some malt, smokey tones, grapefruit, american hops and nice carbonation, medium bodied.

2nd try from Bear Republic.  Very impressed.  poured from 22oz bomber.  Exceedingly fantastic red ale aroma!  I rarely rate a beers aroma a 10, but this is perfect.  Not bad hazy ruby appearance either.  Carmel malts hit first, but nice hop package shows up soon after.  Very impressed with this one.  Wasnt expecting much and got a winner.

A: The pour is rather dark for an amber, approaching brown, with a couple of fingers of tan colored head.

S: Smells nice and hoppy with plenty of oily pine and grapefruit, particularly the rind. Quite a lot of caramel sweetness with a solid toffee and bread aroma. Theres just a bit of a toasted character, too.

T: The flavor is also quite heavy on the pine. The beer is very bitter but it is also nicely well balanced with a big base of caramel and toffee. Just a bit of citrus to go with the toasted bread/maltiness of the beer.

M: This one is medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation and a bitter finish.

D: This was one of the first "craft beers" that I had back when I turned 21 and while I didnt love it back then, I think its pretty solid now.

Pours a dark translucent red, with plenty of foamy off-white head that laces a bit on top, but not much otherwise. Aroma is intensely tropical, with loads of mango on the nose before anything else. Smells like mango lassi almost, with the mango augmented by the malty sugary sweetness. Taste is a change of pace, as it initially is coarse and leafy hop-bitter, but then reverts back to the sugar-sweetened mango, which then fades to a clean, bitter, raw-leaf ending. Hop bill is very balanced here, and the finish is nice and smooth to add to the drinkability. Mouthfeel is very coarse, with my enamel taking a beating right now, but it is good all the same. Drinkability is helped by the finish, but also by the light body and texture of this beer (which isnt to say its thin - it isnt - but that it is very light for such a full bodied and flavorful brew). High marks to bear republic, they know how to make hoppy beers.

Bottle at Growlers Pub in St. Louis.  Very dark cloudy red pour.  Lots of hops and some cherry fruity flavor in this one.  Reminded me of a chocolate flavored cherry a little bit.  Really smooth and creamy.  Goes great as a dessert on a cold night in south county.  A great unique beer, and Ill now be forced to try more Bear Republic.  I wish I felt this way about other St. Louis brews.
A so so red ale. Very blend and boring. No palate development. Overall I would recommend avoiding it.

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks David Cohen. Dark hazy red with a beige head. Aroma of somewhat stale hops with piney notes, some malt, caramel, a bit of fruits, and oxidized notes. Flavor starts sweetish with caramelly malt and light toastiness, continues bitter with quite a bit of slightly piney bitterness. Medium-bodied.

At a tasting, thanks David, smallish head, very deep and quite clear red colour, aroma jam, nuts and oxidised notes, flavour of tea, barnyard and dried fruits, strong empathic but quite mellow hoppy bitterness, long bitter aftertaste. Probably a bit past its prime but still quite good.

I tried to bring this up in points but failed in my efforts. Maybe it was my bottle, then maybe not!  Into a fluted chalice, cool not cold. Pours hazy and muddied by a lot of greyish globules of yeast that fail to dissipate but do manage to settle out. Sloppy, lax, soapy off-white head is mostly lasting. Body seems almost still aside a few brave bubbles, deep brownish copper in colour. Big, bright hop nose; floral, citric and earthy with hints of apricot, peach, pine needles, toffee and wood, the husks of roasted peanuts and a hint of the alcohol. American hop dominated palate, no surprises there. Sharply bitter, too aggressive for balance, the minimal malt notes just drown underneath. Subtle hint of Anzac biscuits and ripe oranges in the acridly weedy and earthy swallow. Holds some nasty phenols too, rubber, burnt plastic, lonely smoke. Mild bite of carbonation upfront in the void of flavour zone, this has it all in the back where it does smooth out in mouthfeel only to be up-heaved by the clashing flavours, esters and phenols of the finish. The body is relatively light for something I assumed was an American interpretation of a Scotch Ale. Oh well, I guess a re-rate some day down the track is fair. Until then!! (12fl.Oz, BB 10/01/11, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

Pour deep auburn 2 finger head with great lacing. Aroma of malt forward sweet rye, grapefruit, caramel, pine, oak, and tropical fruits. Taste of malt, caramel, citrus/floral hops, toffee, and orange peel. MF thick chewy syrupy full bod with mild carb. Interesting take on an American red tasty.

Heavy white lace on a moderate head.  Apricot, hops and malt aroma.  Medium body with a quick sharp note of hops into chewy herbal follow through, plenty of alcohol.  Slightly sour taste in mouth after a few minutes, probably due to the sweetness of the brew.  Flavorful and lively but lacking.  Im not a huge fan of red ales, to be fair.  Add .5-.8 points if you are a fan.

Poured a very dark honey/amber color with a filmy off-white head.  Aroma is very hoppy with apricot and caramel malts.  Taste is also quite hoppy.  The body is surprisingly smooth and creamy.  Well balanced, but not the most complex beer Ive had.  The flavors blend together well.  Reminds me of a red ale.
Deep ruby red body with off white head. A little bit grassy and also a little grainy in the taste, soft caramel in the finish. It certainly improved as the beer warmed up.

On tap at Hashigo zake

The caramel malts standout. Gives it a mild molasses nose. Hops are very much in evidence. Dark clear brown with good head and persistent lacing. Not at all sweet, certainly bitter, not fully rounded, I am guessing it is on the flat side due to lack of any salt - that is just a guess. Mild carbonation, just this side of full bodied, with a slightly creamy and sticky tongue and a slightly astringent finish.

Noticed that few of the top raters were going overboard here. It is limited but it is a solid brew. I like it.
Pours a nice amber hue with a lasting lacing head. Aroma gives a slight smell of cherry. Taste is very nice a sweet introduction with a slight hint of alcohol, very dry. This is a solid beer.

This is a very nice beer.  Pours a semi-translucent deep red color with a medium-thick tan bubbly head.  Smell was quite disappointing, surprising for such a flavor packed beer... the nose was almost non-existent.  The initial flavor is of butterscotch/caramel followed by a very nice bitter/roasted coffee finish.  The mouthfeel is almost perfect, thick, creamy, syrupy. Overall this is an excellent beer, one of my favorites!

Stuff kicks butt.  Totally intense west coast hope flavor witha nice malty red backbone.  I know it calls this an "american strong" but that means nothing.  Think strong IPA crossed with red.  Great hop nose and front of palate, with malty backbone and the smoothness of a good irish red.  Its on the heavier side, but not too much.  Recommended.

Bottle. Clear coppery red pour with a foamy tan head that lasts a little while. Aroma is fairly hoppy but has a solid malt backbone, with notes of lemon, lime, pineapple, mango, grapefruit, toffee and spice. Flavour is still quite hoppy but a lot less fruity, its more grassy and piney with toffee and nuts. Slick, oily mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a long bitter finish. Nice, sessionable, uncomplicated, straightforward red ale.

Draught at Toronado, San Francisco. Surprise surprise its a reddy brown colour with a middling tan head. Sweet malts and piney hops predominated in the nose, and it was a similar yarn down the flavour lane. Some slight burnt notes lurking. Bitterish finish. Quite tasty and perfectly drinkable, but lacked any real complexity or balls.

Poured nice red/brown. Clear with thin off-white head. Had nice citrusy hop aroma, but that was it. thought it had a syrupy/hoppy trainwreck flavor. As if they couldnt decide to make it hoppy or malty. received this bottle as a gift. Id be upset if I paid for it.

Bottle from a trade with Chickencoop. Pours dark reddish brown color with beige head. Aromas of pine and caramel. Moderate bitterness with some caramel flavor and spicy rye. Medium body with average carbonation. Thanks Jeremy.

Slight question mark over the condition of this bottle with the hop impact was not perhaps as strong as expected. Great looking beer; dark toffee with chunky lacing. and a think off-white head.  Nose shows lifted hops albeit mild (for the style).  Very mild and easy going to drink although the hops just dont really get going. Not stale, just lacking power. All that said dead easy to suck down.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with a large tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of citrus and piney hops, some malt presence.  Tastes similar with the citrus and piney hops very apparent.  Some malt for balance.  Well made.  Nice price.

Pours out really dark brown with only faint dark orange hues around the edge of the glass.  Light tan head, doesnt last too long but leaves a nice cap.  Aromas of roasted grains, grapefruit hops, and caramel malt.  Taste is more of a barleywine, and tastes boozy, much more boozy than the ABV would lead you to guess.  Heavy on the hops, mainly citrus and grapefruit.  Middle of the taste profile was caramelly, finishing really bitter with some notes of flavored tobacco.  Not bad, in fact its really good.  Its just not my thing,  Very impressive for a common, nonseasonal 12oz.
Pours red as you figured.  Cream off white head. Nose is caramelly and resinous hops.  Taste is similar with citrus resinous hops.  Very good red.  I would get more if available.
Love this brew!  Many times in the gullet has this been consumed.  Its been a minute at the moment though, I may have to go grab one soon...

Bomber.  Pours a dark ruby with a light tan head.  Lots of lacing.  Aroma is hop forward -- floral, citrus pine -- plus a lot of caramel malt.  Flavor is well balanced.  Lots of caramel, some nuts, smoke.  Rather grainy -- do I detect some rye?  Hops are complex, flavorful, and spicy.  Full, slightly oily mouthfeel.  Easy drinking but really delicious.

12 ounce bottle. Poured into Bruery tulip. 

Off white, cream colored head dissipates relatively quickly leaving only few clusters of foam atop the beer. 

Essentially inexistent lacing. 


Pours very dark for a red ale (ie, when looking at full glass it appears dark brown like a stout or porter). When held close to light, hue is deep orange/ruby-ish brown shade of amber. 


Plenty sediment throughout with the largest chunks of light ash colored sediment falling to the bottom of glass  first have seen in a red or imperial red ale (then noticed it is noted on side of bottle: Brew Master Notes: real ale is alive, yeast is good). Almost as much sediment as some Belgian golden strong ales (eg, La Chouffe as a recently drunk example). 

Piney hops is primary aroma, caramel malt scent is secondary. Slight earthiness on nose. Pleasant and well balanced aroma. Seems to have very subtle hint of tobacco with perhaps even less of a hint of bitter chocolate.  


Hops on front palate. Caramel malt on mid palate begins to balance out hops. Malt is slightly less sweet and less caramely than other reds/imperial have recently tried. Back of palate and finish are very well balanced; especially the finish as compared to some other red and imperial red ales have had recently, which had quite hoppy finishes. Just a touch of alcohol on the finish. 

Highly quaffable. Mild mouth feel. Almost sessionable expect that it nears 7% abv.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark ruddy color with a heavy off-white head.  Aroma is woody, dark malts, dark fruit with lots of hops.  Hops are present in the flavor as well as a bitter, dry woody taste.  Finishes very dry with a lingering hop bitterness.

Bottle, picked up at an excellent organic foods market in Kalispell whose name I forget. Pours deep garnet/amber, with a medium off-white head, really nice lacing. Nose is big citrus hops, and fudgy caramel/toffee, some light spruce and cereal (rye?) here as well. Flavours are big, and lightly bitter, nice round spiciness to the hops here, reminds me quite a bit of Arrogant Bastard Ale, with the toffee paired well with the bitterness. Some very lightr smoke/roast notes begin to peer through, as well as a walnut/chestnut flavour as this one warms. Very nice.
caramel smell, but very bitter taste.  its hard to pick up much taste past the bitterness.  figs, um..nope, too bitter.

(12oz bottle thanks to mar) pours an extremely rich ruby color, soapy tan bubbles, leads to excellent lacing everywhere. A fantastic looking beer. Nose of sweet caramel, juicy citrus fruits in the background, some light milk chocolate, sweet graham cracker, and vanilla. Surprisingly complex nose for the style and what it is. Taste of sweet caramel reminiscent of a barleywine, nice hoppy bite with plenty of malt to go around, toasty grains, and fudgey chocolate are here too. The body is unbelievably smooth, creamy, and leaves a nice toasty caramel and hops linger. I cant imagine a beer having a much better texture than this. After having had so many beers it is rare to come across an "every day" beer that is so awesome. Cheers Bear Republic!

Pours a nice brown-red, bordering on mahogany. A nice white head and plenty of lacing. The nose has plenty of citrus and piney hops along with some nice dark amber malt and accompanying sweetness. The taste is similar, with a lovely bitterness as well as nice herbal, citrus, and caramel flavors. Moderate body with excellent drinkability.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 02-16-2010

355ml bottle. Coppery red teak colour that is almost black. Head that threatens to burst out of the glass, creamy beige foam. Full hop aroma that sends the senses into overdrive. The flavour is biscuity with caramel background and a strong alcohol finish. Another great beer from Bear Republic.

Notes toffee an caramel in the nose. Also a little alcohol.  Taste is very similar to Great Lakes Nosferatu, just not quite as good.  A strong, hoppy red ale.  This beer is average overall, and I would probably not seek it out again.
Nice combination af hops and malt. some taste of hazelnut and brown sugar. nice farly easy drinkable beer.
Well this is good . Realy nice malt blend showing lots of caramel and nuts, then the sweetness & hops arrive. To many miss the malts and concentrate on the bitterness in this beer, they are superb.

Bomber purchased at BevMo fifteen months ago ($3.99).  Pours a nice deep garnet color (more red than brown) with one finger of beige foam.  Aroma of American hops (citrus, pine), brewed tea, flowers, and some caramel.  Flavor of slightly bitter hops (citrus), lemony-y iced team, and earthy caramel.  Nicely balanced with some good lingering bitterness.  A little lighter in body than I would have expected.  (911, 424)

Smallish head good medium carbonation dark ruby pour aromas pine citrus dark fruits and malts alcohol like port brown sugar floral note flavour toffee pine citrus bitter strong good taste brown sugar mild tawny port malt has a good sweetness hops very strong citrus flavour grapefruit good ale has decent body finish sweet malts hop bitter lasting aftertastes that please the palate

Bottle. Dark red with an inch of beige head. Pine and singed caramel aroma. Taste has toffee malt without being very sweet, lots of pine and some grass. Bitter finish. Started off thinking this was very crude but pretty nice, but the malt side has nutty and toasted things going on that arent quite obscured by the big resinous hops. Unbalanced - of course - but pretty good.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2012 Re-rated: Pours brownish-red. An invigorating sweet caramel and piney hops aroma. Exceptionally well balanced with malts and hops in good proportion. Perhaps my tastes have changed as I think it could have more hop bitterness on the finish (will be interested to try fresh from brewery). For me, its fuller body and malt characteristics give it the edge over Green Flash Hop Head Red, when comparing.

12oz bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy deep mahogany red color with a huge creamy tan head that leaves a great spotchy lace.  Malty and bready aroma with hints of caramel and smoke.  The flavor follows along the same lines with a hearty smoky smooth malt flavor and thick body paired with a moderate hop bitterness and a creamy finish.

Pours dark mahogany with a large dissipating head.
Nose shows lashings of piney resin and fruity confectionery followed by caramel and fruitcake. Very nice.
Flavours follow along the same lines with lots of rich malt providing dried fruit and nutty characters, after which the piney hops enter. The bitterness is a bit sharp and domineering.
Carbonation is a bit high but without it the rich malt could be cloying.

22oz bottle from Specs.  Poured a clear, cola-colored body with some bubbly, off-white head that left sticky lacing.  Aromas of piney/resinous hops and some caramel sweetness.  Flavor mirrors the aromas.  Nicely balanced malt with a smooth, long, medium pine and floral hop finish.  Lively carbonation and a medium mouthfeel.

Amber-brown pour into the glass with a lightly retentive head that leaves some window-wash lacing.  The nose is of toasty caramel.  Good malt base with a solid hop back that provides a sturdy balance and a nice bitter finish.  The round body is full and oily on the palate.  A very nice ASA from Bear Republic!  Highly drinkable and just plain good.

Bottle. Poured a dark brownish color with a smaller white head. Left some lacing on the side of the glass as it went. Aroma was caramel, bubblegum, spices, and fruits. Flavor was the scotch. Bitter aftertaste. Medium body, oily mouthfeel. Very good beer
Medium brown in the glass. Strong hoppy aroma of resin and pine. Malt stands up well to the hops on the palate. Well made.

Nontraditional red ale showing ample west coast hops in nose. Flavoring hops are very apparent while drinking this brew, but bittering is low. Nice round mouthfeel with everything in balance. Malt shows caramel notes and deep sweet barley.
22 oz bottle. A bit too thin in appearance but doesnt feel bad on the palate. Malty aroma and more malty taste. Pretty good brew and definitely an easy drinker.
12oz btl. Pours a dark rust with a white head. A grassy hoppy aroma. Yoi can really taste the character of the hops in this, a nice bitterness as well. Not bad.

Bottle at LIC Craft Beer Festival. Nice dark amber pour with standard white head. Little going on in the aroma other than pine. The taste is odd of water, pine, and red food dye. Weak stuff. Did not like this.

[Tap] Pours a ruddy brown color with about an inch worth of off white head. The aroma is hop forward, with mostly citrus and lesser amounts of pine needles. The taste is of sticky brown sugar and caramel. Some dry grains and pleasant lingering bitterness. Good hop balance in here as well. Nice mouthfeel and palate with this beer. Pretty enjoyable!

Another Damn good beer from Bear Republic.  Pours dark brown w/ some ruby highlites.  nice thick, creamy, tan head that lasts all the way and laces the whole glass.  Getting citrus and floral hops on the nose, orange and lemon along with a solid malt backbone, sweet malts, caramel, , some smokiness, and some toasted malts.  Medium full body, creamy, medium carbonation, and a balanced finish.  On the tongue is nice citrus and floral hops over top of the malts but they are balanced by the sweet, caramel, malts, toasted malts and smokiness.  A very nicely done beer. This beers goes right on my must have more list.

A: thick, rich amber color...almost mahogany. tan head, with good retention and rather nice lacing.

S: big citrus hop aroma. huge malts. some sweet tones, apples with some dates.

T: very mellow, yet rich amber ale. solid malt backbone, with some spicy characteristics. light citrus hop flavors.

M: very smooth and mellow mouthfeel. mild carbonation level. medium bodied.

D: very nice brew. I could have a couple of bombers but that would probably do me in.

Notes from Saturday, September 18, 2010
12 oz. bottle from Woodmans Madison, $1.65

Ar: Piney hops are the first thing to hit (is there rye in this?), and the aroma is quite pleasant.  Beneath the primary aroma are lemon and roasted malt.
Ap: Pours a deep reddish amber with a 1" manila head that lasts a while.  Nice lace.
T: Theres a nice sweet roastiness on the nose, but the wonderful pine is very present on the finish, which is perfectly bittered.  The alcohol is noticeable, but not overly so.
P: Medium carbonation, medium-thick body.

Simple but quite profound...the nose is a smorgasbord of floral, nutty, and possibly even fruity notes, but the climax comes at the end when the profundity of this economical beer is realized with its malty and perhaps woodland finish. I will stock up on this one next time.

OK...the 3rd Bear Republic I tried, and they keep getting better. 
Beautiful clear/Brown, with an outstanding head. The initial aroma, for me, was very hoppy with underlying notes of caramel and malt. This beer is actually complex, as there seems to be so much going on. You think it has a malt finish, yet as you sit waiting for the next sip, here come the hops again. Very drinkable, I DO recommend this beer. NEED....TO....GET.....MORE.....

Dark amber or maybe brown.  Lots of hops aroma - mostly pine.  Taste has a decent amount of bitterness, but very well balances with toasty malt and some sweetness that gives way to more roasty aroma through the nose in the finish.  Its good, its balances, it hides the alcohol well.  A well done brew.

Poured from 12 oz bottle, enjoyed during the opening night of the 2010 NFL season!  Aroma is very prevalent with a strong malt / caramel backing, smells like its a high ABV brew.  Appearance is a deep amber / red hue with a thin, thick head.  Taste is smooth but thick, really complex, goes down very easily.  Definite hop presence with caramel notes, rather rich.  Would definitely drink again.

Bottled. A more robust Red Ale than expected, could almost be a hybrid IPA/Red Ale.  Floral aromas are prevalent above all others with a slight twinge of caramel.  Tastes perky and crisp to the draw with a clean mouthfeel while it washes down with a very slight bite.  Just slightly rough on my tongue for a clean finish, but nowhere too harsh.  A good bier.

Pours a deep amber, almost brown with a nice tan/rose head that is well supported.  The nose is packed full of hops!  A deeper inhalation reveals a wonderful caramelly, biscuity, malt character that calms your anxiety over the hops intensity.  Guess what?!? Youve been had as bright citrus hops, spicy on the tip, floral in the middle and crisp, pleasantly bitter on the finish explode on your palette. Thankfully, the luscious malt starts creeping in mid-swallow and rounds out the finish, saving you from a dastardly end.  This beer has a great weight, balanced nicely by the carbonation (think very pleasant mids... I meant mid-levels of CO2 - nevermind)

I could probably drink a case of bombers in one sitting... I couldnt stand up afterwards, but I could revel in my greatness!

12 ounce bottle in my 6 pack of Racer 5.  I cant believe I have never rated this before.  Aroma is very malty, sweet, caramelly, with appropriate chewy maltiness that I would expect in a big red ale.  Really nicely aromatic.  Mildly hazy ruby mahogany body with a fair light tan head that leaves really good lacing.  Starts with a nice, sweet, chewiness.  Some caramel malty flavors come through in the middle.  There almost seems like a little rye in this contributing to the piney, resiny bitterness later on.  Light hints of vanilla.  Tasty stuff!

Pours a red haze with an off white foam head.  Has an aroma of grapefruit, pine, and caramel.  Caramel heavy.  Sweet up front with a heavy malt backbone.Nice hop hit.  Has a spicy hop, scotch ale like finish.  Excellent beer.
th beer poured a dark red body with a pillow head. The smell is of roasted malt and sweetness. The taste is of light malt and a perfect hopps for a smooth mild sweet ale. good carbonation.

Bear Republic Brewing Company--Ricardos Red Rocket Ale--1999 22 oz. Bottle.  6.80% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Red Ale.  Clear medium dark red color despite being unfiltered.  Rich earthy floral hop front leading to rich licorice cherry body.  Hints of Scottish character.  Dry spicy hop finish.  Nice balance.	  Sampled 4/25/1999.

Bear Republic Brewing Company--Ricardos Red Rocket Red Ale--2007 22 oz. Bottle.  6.80% ABV.  65+IBUs?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Red Ale--Scottish.  Rich lacy head.  Clear dark mahogany red color hazes with BC sediment.  Floral hop mild peat front.  Tangy toasted malty mild sweet crisp toffee fruit rich Red Ale Hop body.  Hot hop mild citrus malty end.  Sampled 8/7/2007.

Bear Republic Brewing Company--Ricardos Red Rocket Red Ale--2008 12 oz. Plastic Stick On  Label Bottle.  6.80% ABV.  65+IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Red Ale--Scottish.  Light sediment.  Big dense rocky lacy off white tan head.  Mild hazy dark bronze red color.  Rich roasted hop peat hint front.  Crisp tangy zesty dry sweet roasted mild fruit hop ester malty Scottish body.  Crisp roasted hop spice clean balanced rich end.  Nice blend.  Sampled 11/21/2008.  6-Pack $7.49.

Bear Republic Brewing Company--Ricardos Red Rocket Ale--2009	22 oz. Bottle.  6.80% ABV.  65+IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Red Ale--Scottish.  Rich lacy off white head.  Clear deep dark copper red color.  Sediment hint hazes bronze.  Roasted malty rich floral hop smoky peat hint front.  Rich malty roasted mild sweet hop resin infused toffee mild smoky peat burnt fruit body.  Cloying malt hop spice end.  Sampled 9/16/2009.  4 @ $4.00 Each.

Deep red pour with a thinning off-tan head and some visible yeast.  Excellent lacing. Strong pine and grass hop aromas are immediately evident. Roasty malts, caramel, and dark fruits make their way into the fold. Tastes like it smells. Very hoppy at first with just a twang of yeast. Malt flavors become more evident as you get deeper into the glass. Very mild alcohol warmth. Medium body and carbonation. Enough hops to pass for an IPA, but nutty, fruity, and sweet enough to be a Scottish ale. Awesome overall, one of my favorites.

Pours amber with light brown head, decent lacing.  Aroma is florals, citrus, resin, caramel and dough.  Taste is bitter with sweetness coming through on the backend.   Finish is dry, this is a great brew.  So much going on.

Nicely blended aroma of wood, grapefruit peel, very woody. Hazy ruby brown, thin head. Rusty and metallic. Flavor is tart malt and currants. Dirty, rustic finish. Quite a nice "india dark ale" or whatever its being called. Alcohol content isnt excessive and is well concealed. Slightly too hoppy to be an ABA.

Bottle poured into a pint glass.  Smelled hops and caramel malts.  The beer is obviously bottle conditioned with yeast chunks floating around.  Poured a dark reddish amber.  Off white head.  Big  hop taste followed by a full body of malt.  Excellent.
Strong smell, aroma of malt, mild hops, extremely smooth, average lacing, no head, ruby red color.  3 of Chicago trip 10.  94%
Aroma: grapefruit, caramel, cherries and other dried fruit. Wonderful. Appearance: deep ruby red, thick tan head, substantial thick, sticky lacing. Taste: quite sweet and lingering.

Pours dark red with a decent thick head. The aroma is caramel and hops. The appearance is the only real turn off, chunky floaters of what look like hops particles but are probably yeast. Mouthfeel is nice and thick. Taste is strong caramel and malt then a hoppy mid taste and a caramel finish. A really drinkable red ale.

pours dark red with a great deal of suspended yeast.   Thin off white head and nice lacing.  rich fruit and hop aroma.  cherries predominate.  dark malt coupled with strong hops.  hoppy finish.  very different and maybe not a classic but a well made beer nonetheless.
Draft at the American Craft Beer Fest in Boston.  Poured a red-brown with a tan head.  Caramel malt comes through very nicely, piny hops to be had.  Really liked this one.

12 oz bottle.  Pours red brown with lots of chunky debris and an off-white head.  Light citrus hop aroma with a little caramel.  Flavor has a fair amount of citrus and grassy hops and some toasted and caramel malts.  Flavors start out a little light but gradually intensify.  Solid.
Sampled at American Craft Beer Fest 2010. Pours ruby-brown.  Thick.  Good combination of hops and malt in the flavor.  Definitely worth trying.

(Bottle) Poured reddish brown and clear. Head was medium sized and lightly brown. Aroma contained malts, molasses and hops. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, molasses, hops, mildy roastedness, some sea water, hint of liquorice and medium bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter.

Ive seen this beer around for a long time and Im just now getting around to buying and rating.  All I can say is WOW!  Gorgeous dark brown color with a touch of red.  Delicious hoppy citrus flavor with roasted malt notes in the aftertaste that seem to be competing with one another.  Same thing with the aroma.  Hops and roasted malt competing with each other that makes the sum of the parts greater than its whole.  All I can say is... awesome...

120z bottle poured into a snifter. Lots of unfiltered goodness in the glass, and it leaves significant lacing as you drink it down. For its strength, this beer is eminently quaffable, a factor aided by a somewhat watery body. Dee[brown and malty, but with a long bitter finish, this one evokes Stone AB and DFH India brown ale, though I think it combines the sweetness and bitterness more holistically than does the Stone offering. A fine option for the next time youre in Sonoma.

2010 Bottle - Pours a hazy dk amber with a medium beige head...aroma is sweet caramel and red fruit, lightly spicy and tons of grain, hop florals...flavour is much drier than the nose suggests, earthy, gritty grain, toffee...has a table sugar sweetness which is why I typically dont care for lighter crystal malt, but overall is nicely put together...

pours deep brown/ruby with a medium lt. tan head.  nice lacing and retention.  aroma is very malty and sweet, slightly winey with subtle fruit, and a hint of vanilla.  flavor is less sweet than the aroma suggests but has some toasty malt and caramel sweetness to go with earthy/woody hops.  mouthfeel is lively but it getts slightly watery towards the finish which is dry and lingers nicely with some earthiness.  overall a very nice beer that id drink again.

Pours a hazy deep reddish brick with a beige head. Aroma has lots of caramel, citrus and pine. Flavor opens with a blast of C hops and moves into a sweltering bitterness of citrus rind, grapefruit . The malt is bready and sweet as the hops turn a bit spicy and herbal. The carbonation gets this beer moving and allows the caramel to shine and be sticky without making it too full bodied. Overall well balanced and drinkable with a great personal signature on the flavor profile. Very enjoyable.

Poured an amber brown with good lacing across the top of the glass.  Aromas of sweet malt and subtle hops dominate with some earthy notes.  Taste is fabulous - strong malt flavors - typical of a red ale with a great balance of hop bitterness.  Some vanilla creeps in there as well.  Finish is well balanced and very clean ... some pine notes linger.  For not being a big fan of reds ... this one is terrific!!

Pours a murky, reddish brown with lots of yeast sediment sneaking its way in, and  a 2-3 finger creamy, beige head that has excellent retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, burnt sugar, woody hops, sweet bread crust, citrus, light wildflorew notes and just a touch of vanilla. Flavor is caramel, woody hops, burnt sugar, citrus, and some toasty pine. Palate is medium bodied with a somewhat slightly chalky feel and moderate to light carbonation. Not bad.

Aroma of pine, woody herb, citrus, somewhat floral.  Dark red/amber with a decent head and lacing.  The rich caramel malt flavor really balances the bitterness, it has a velvety texture and fruity profile.  This reminds me of Arrogant Bastard but less aggressive.  Medium body, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a long, beautifully lingering bitter finish.  A classic strong American ale, top of the line.
Just wow. Pours deep cheery red, with fluffy off white head. Great lacing all the way down. Aroma of pine, caramel, and citrus. Typical over the top Bear Republic hops.. fantastic.
Dark brown pour from bottle.  Hops, citrus and rye dominate the nose and taste buds.  Light, creamy finish.  Damn, everything BR produces is just excellent.  Thumbs up!
Reddish cherry pour. Aroma is apple cognac, citrus, spruce, pine and brown sugar. Taste is sweet candy apple, bitter hops, spruce and rye. Rated 5/17/05
Bready with a light hoppiness in the aroma.  Amber in color.  Tastes just as it smells.

Bottle.  Pours deep ruby brown with dark particles suspended, and a 2-finger foamy beige head.  Aroma is pineapple, orange, brandy, brown sugar, and pine (reminds me of a mellower DFH Olde School).  Sweet orange flavor, candi sugar, and papaya; bitter pine and alcohol finish, with more fruit as it warms.  This is pleasantly bitter, low/medium carbonation, and quite smooth.  Very good.

Big malty beer with a ton of hops, cant beat it. These folks for years have been making solid reebs and seem to be in the RR shadows, pretty sad because BR is one of the better breweries in Sonoma County. This is an over the top red, but it works becase of the smooth malty-hop balance. Big ups....go hounds!
So nice I drank it twice. Bear Republic beers have such fantastic creamy malty mouth feel.... mmmm. Nicely bitter and malty - get a 12 pack.
650mL bottle, pours dark amber with a beige head. Aroma of caramel malts and lots of hops. Flavour is a strong caramel malt and lots of hops, with a good bitterness. Fantastic one.

Bought Sept. 08. Pours a dark brown with a reddish hue. Light brown head, big and creamy, mostly diminishing and excellent lacing. The aroma is some hops, a roasted sweetness. The taste is a little bitter, some sweetness, creamy body, reminds me of a barleywine.
Bottle at RBNAG-2009. Red amber colour with an off-white head. Aroma is alcohol,malt, hop. Flavour is alcohol, malt, hop, fruit, berries, grapefruit, peaches, caramel. Full body. Nice beer.

I bought a six pack on a whim. This rating so for the last bottle. Pours a cloudy red with lots of floaties on the bottom and not much of a head. The hop aroma is very fragrant without being overwhemling. I dont really get much else. The first sips hits with a big bang of bitter hops that are very woody and after a while the malt comes thru. Its very much like an IPA but without the big buzz. Its a good brew but not something I would have to have all the time.

Bottle from the Whole Foods on Lamar.  Dark red pour with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is roasted nuts, a little pine hops, and caramel.  Taste is pretty hoppy, a little fruity, malt, and a sweet finish.

Bottle, 22oz, at RBNAG -09. It pours a clear, amber body under a small off-white head. West-coast sweetness and pleasant piney, citrusy hops on the nose. The flavor is caramel-sweet, with balancing bitterness that lasts. Citrus and pine cones. Full-bodied and dryish. A pleasant beer I would like to repeat. 091107

Golden brown with a slight red tint and a small one finger wide off white head. The smell is a lot more fruity than I was expecting and also has nice hop and floral hints. Light and soft front, almost Abbey Dubbel like. The taste is almost nothing like the aroma and has hints of roasted malts, hops, citrus and booze with a very subtle caramel/sweet flavoring throughout.
Pours a beautiful hazy red with a thin tan head.  Aromas of malt, citrus, and hops.  Very bitter taste from start to finish.
From a bottle poured a dark amber color with a fair amount of head.  Nice strong hoppy flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle poured into a trappist glass produced a dark amber body with tall, light tan head. Aroma is burnt toast and alcohol.  I could smell the hops as this was poured.  Nice sweet malts with tons of pine and citrus hop notes which ends dry with lots of nice bitterness on the tongue.
Theres a Scottish ale influence to the malt character.  The finish is hoppy and pleasantly bitter.  A first class beer.
From a 12 oz botttle,clear, red, white foam, medium bitterness, Super hoppy great red.Will try buy again

12oz. bottle served in a shaker pint. Poured a hazy reddish brown with a finger of off white head. Big citrus hop aroma with some malt sweetness. Solid medium body. Good malt base with a nice hop presence. Some bready and caramely malt. Very drinkable. I usually stay away from amber ales, but this is a top notch example.
Poured reddish brown with a white head. Aroma of citrus. More hoppy than malty. Some caramel.

2007: Excellent deep brownish red color, with a colossal pillowy head; cloud-like. Hard for light to shine through, but is probably relatively clear. Major icy lace. Quite enticing. 

Appears to have a nice balance of strong hops and strong malt. The malt smells sharp and red, and serves as a bitter match to the hops. 

Very nice flavor with a great balance of dueling bitters; both hops and sharp malt. Complex malt with a nutty, roasted second wave. Deep and rich flavor. Two hits obitter. (Reminds me if Cascazilla, for comparison.) 

Thick and fully body. Feels almost like a porter, believe it or not. Fits the deep flavor. A slight bit bubbly. A very fin, solid beer. Quite bitter; very bitter. And good. And STRONG!
red to orange pour witha small dense creamy off white head.sweet aroma and taste with a bitter finish

12 oz. bottle from Sams (Binnys), Downers Grove, Apr. 09. This shouldve been opened some time before now, I guess. Still, it pours into my glass a dark brown with red highlighting, and a short clingy head the color of a cola head. Smell is rich caramel malts, with graininess in the background, probably from aging. Taste is dry to start, still with resiny hops, and more caramel malt. Nice, happy alcohol notes. I kind of like the grainy taste, as it sets off the bitterness nicely. Pretty good lacing on the sides of the glass.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 On tap at San Diego Brewing Co. (San Diego, CA): Pours out a stunningly clear, deep amber brown shade, topped with a khaki one-finger head. Aroma of citrus and pine hops blended with sweet malts and some light chocolate. Flavors of dark fruits, spices, light chocolate, and definitely a load of pine hops that lasts well into the delicately bitter finish. Medium bodied. Drinkability: Nicely put together. Pairing: A bowl of cheddar and spicy jalapeno soup. Rebuy: Yes. #315 on 01032010, DG.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Café Sveavägen, Stockholm. Deep rubyish amber brown colour with mediumsized creamy/foamy off-white head. Aroma is a bunch of citrus fruits, some nectar, mild caramel malts as well as some slight chocolate and mild toasted notes. Flavour is quite much the same along with some dark dry fruits and mild herbal notes.  Pleasantly balanced and not all too radical.
Better than I thought it would be. A scotch base but with the punch of hops of an American IPA. Great malty caramel flavor with the bitter balance of hops.
Caramel roasty nose and taste with medium sweetness, medium body, slick feel, lively, long finish. Pretty good

22oz bomber into a chilled glass.   Bear Republic is famous for their Racer 5 IPA, and Red Rocket should garner ample praise on its own merit.  The hop forward aroma and taste could pass for an IPA at most brewerys.  The rich malt flavor gave this ale a complex profile that is missing in many lesser beers.  Im eager to try their other offerings and i look forward to visiting this local operation.
Bottle from world market...Pours a reddish brown with a fluffy tan head...Aroma is sweet but very faint...Flavor is very malty with a nice lingering hop bitterness..Smooth palate.
brown hue with tan creamy head, decent lacing, sweet, carmely, smells malty and brown sugar, syrupy texture, light carbonation, hoppy charecteristics of Bear Republic

Poured from bottle. I think I am starting to be able to identify a Bear Republic beer by aroma only -- citrus, lavender, and a touch of moss rose. Color is caramel -- not much head, no lace. Taste is all hops up front, but opens up into a complex, rich malty toast. Very nice beer -- I just wish it had a touch more appearance to it.

A satisfying, hoppy red ale.  Whatever the style origins, this is a nice beer with a lot of flavor.  Its aggressively hopped, a sweet blend of citric, floral and spruce notes.  The malt brings some deeper caramel flavors, toasty sweet bread and burnt sugars.  Theres a good yeast flavor that dries out the finish beyond the already dry tone of the beer.  The mouthfeel is creamy and a bit oily with hops.  The beer looks great, carmine liquid with a thick layer of off-white foam.  Bear Republic makes good beer.
Very good, I thought it was an IPA though. Medium bodied and lightly spicy, but mainly hop dominated. Some caramel malts in the background. Grapefruit aroma. Dry finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours a beautiful deep amber red brown color, still glowing with a thick creamy off white head. Aroma is nicely blended with citric and pine forward hops, along with a sweet cake like malt, blended chocolate and just a hint of tartness in there, quite strange but I like it. Flavor is also nicely blended, dark fruits and spices in the front, mixing into chocolate and finally piney hops before a lightly bitter finish. Medium body and a spry carbonation. Really nicely put together beer.

650 ml bottle [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2009, Vatlandsvåg. Amber body with a thin beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel and citric hops. Flavor is sweet, good malt, caramel, dry fruit and citric fruit with a light and pleasant oxidation. Nice flavor, good balance - a big beer at only 6,8 ABV.

Bottle:  Pours aglowing ruby amber color with a short lived beige head.  Lots of sticky and creamy lacing.  I dig this type of aroma with rich citrus sweetness, faded ctirus hop bits, caramel, and candied fruit.  Delicious!  The flavor is full of citrus and florals, caramel, faint vinous notes, and candied sugar.  Lingering bitters in the tail are sweet and floral.  Quite nice.

Hazy ruby amber with lots of sediment. Thick beige head. Aroma of earthy pine, dank resin, molasses. Taste is heavy bitter hops, very dank, just enough toffee/molasses to balance. Long bitter finish. Medium body, low carbonation.

12oz bottle (2009) into a pint glass.  Pours reddish with a fluffy off-white head.  The aroma is hoppy, but a bit malty.  The flavor is chocolately with a hint of peat and a dose of soapy citrus hops.

Pours a deep red slightly hazy with a nice sized tannish head, excellent lacing... Somewhat sweet malty aroma... Surprisingly watery quality, thin for the weight, nutty in a way, with a subtle hoppiness, malty, dry finish, unique beer... This is definitely an americanized scotch ale... Nice beer...

en san juan despues de la catastrofe en haiti y con un gran vergaso de agua. 
esta buena. compleja; comienza europea con un toque de belga y scottish ale y luego se vuelve mas oscura y hoppy.  buena combinacion del ashtray con los hops.  buena, un fuerte aplauso

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2012 Bomber. Pours a dark brownish red color with a half-inch of beige head. The aroma is a potent mix of caramel malt, brown sugar and dates with a bit of herbal hops and pine resin at the end. The taste is pretty much the same with a strong emphasis on caramel, dark fruit and bitter hops flavors. The mouthfeel has medium carbonation and a mildly creamy body with more caramel and citrus in the finish. Definitely one of the best Amber/Red/American Strong Ales out there which isnt too surprising considering how consistently good the beers are from this brewery.

Sampled with scottyp and curly.   Pours a murky purple with good tan head and some large particulate.  Nose is great caramel and dark citrusy dank hops.  Very resinous bitter earthy hop flavor.  Delicious beer.

Cask at Fat Heads in Pittsburgh.  The cask temp helped this beer a ton.  Aroma of caramel, hops, booze.  Taste comes through nicely with definite caramel seeping along the palate.  Hoppy taste, smooth and bitter finish, not too boozy, nice.

aroma is caramel malt and good hop pine with a light astringency and spirity booze note. appearance is glowing maroon, deep and dark. very pretty. flavor is excellent balance of well defined caramel and near toffee with big pine/resin backup.  low or lack of citrus despite use of cascade (but none to the beers dismay). as beer opens nose moves more towards straight caramel.

bottle.  pours a clear, dark copper with ruby red highlights and a tan frothy head.  aroma of grapefruit, pine, caramel, dough.  flavor is much more bitter than expected.  a really nice grapefruit punch to it.  also some scotch, caramel malts and dough.  pretty good.

From [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2009 in Vatlandsvåg. A creamy tan hed resting on a red shaded, dark amber body. A pleasant whiff of  caramel up front, along with a distinct citrus hoppy scent. Also some cheesy hop notes is coming though. Taste is rather vinous, bitter-sweet, slight caramelly with citrus notes. Mid-bodied. Hoppy finish.  Ok beer, but lack unfortunatly some freshness, due to a light oxidation perhaps.
A very deep ruby body with a negligible dark tan head, very fruity (think plums) nose, and a strong hoppy flavor, but a complex finish
On tap at The Rake, Borough.  Too sweet.  But some good grapefruit hops.  Took me an hour to drink this.  But ended up liking it a lot.  Sweetish, but very likeable.

bottle thanks to Treborwhip, pours dark amber with a tall light tan head.  Aroma is light toast and alcohol with lots of nice hop notes.  This is like a scotch ale amped up on hops.  Nice sweet bready malts with tons of pine and citrus hop notes ending dry with lots of nice bitterness on the tongue.  I really liked this......thanks Dad!

Pours a deep ruby/brown color forming a nice craggy off beige foamy head, aroma of roasted malts, hops and ocean water.  Flavour was much of the same, a hopped up porter/Scottish ale, extremely drinkable beer.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours red orange with an off white head and some lace.  Aromas of brown sugar and floral hops.  Floral and grapefruit in the taste with some bitter chocolate.  Finishes bitter.

22oz bottle. Pours a dark amber with mahogany with one finger tannish head that settles slowly. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of caramel, toffee, ripe citrus, grapefruit, light honey and spice notes. Flavor is sweet and malty with caramel, honey, citrus, toffee, floral esters, floral hops, light grapefruit, hazelnut, light malty chocolate notes. Medium body with a pleasing floral hop finish.

Bottle, 6.8% ABV, RBNAG 2009 in Vatlandsvåg. Beautiful reddish brown colour, low off-white head. Excellent aroma and flavour with vinous and oaky notes, also strong notes of American hops. Very good! ("Beer of the Gathering" for me.)

Pours a dark and clear amber. 
Nose is barely existent, mostly simple syrup and old hops.
Taste is basic sweet malt base, hop bitterness, not much hop flavor, decent, but nothing special.

In short: A cohesive blend of berries, caramel and pink grapefruits flavours.  A little too sweet but overall very good beer.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed fresh about 1 to 2 months after purchase
The look: Beautiful partly cloudy ruby body topped by a large beige head with medium retention
In long: The nose is rich caramel and plenty of fruity hops, reminiscent of some hoppy American barley wines.  Taste has lots of berries swimming in caramel and concludes with a pink grapefruits finish.  Not a very complex beer but there is something about that rich fruity caramel and red grapefruits flavours that work surprisingly well together.  Slightly tart.  Medium carbonation.  Bitterness is mild-medium.  A little sweetness creeps in (unfortunately) in the after-taste.  Not quite balanced enough to me.  So much I liked about this beer but it just needed a little more bite in the hops department (more resinous, more pine-cone dryness, something).  Very good but a little twist and it could be excellent.  The beer looks great, but looks is not everything, unless you are a chick without much professional ambition.

Bottle from Rodmans. Pours a dark red/crimson with a fluffy white head that has quite a bit of retention and lacing. Tons of yeast and other bits floating around. Unfiltered, indeed. Smells sweet, some resinous pine and some prune/plum/cherry action. Watery front, not the kind of malt backbone that I look for in a red ale. Lots of hoppy pine notes though. Lots of carbonation Id have it again, but I think I prefer Green Flashs Hop Head Red.

Thanks to qmeister. Pours a thick reddish amber color with a slightly tan head.  Aroam of caramel, malts, and hops.  Flavor of caramel, malts, and a solid hops bitterness at the back end.  Lots of floaties.  Creamy mouth feel.

22 ounce bottle at the Bayou. Pours a dark amber color with a medium tan head. The aroma is huge caramel, malty and light fruit. The flavor was really nice; sweet caramel, light fruitiness, rich malts, a light bitter hop. Nice and tasty.

12oz bottle. Poured cloudy, reddish brown in color. Thing white head, good carbonation. Smelled heavily of malts, sweet. Taste was pretty average. Bitter, maltiness, and dark fruits. This was a beer Ive been wanting to try for a while and it was a bit disappointing for me. With the appearance and smell I was looking for more taste than I got. Pretty light on the mouthfeel as well, another thing I was wanting more out of.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2010 Poured from 12 oz, Thought I had already rated this, as it was one of my all time favorites.  Dark brown with nice red hue.  Medium tan head.  Malty caramel nose with a bit of fruit.  Hoppy bitter taste, sweet and malty. Well balanced brew with a  nice after taste with a strong finish.

Very strong red ale.
Very hoppy in aroma and taste.
Red in color.
Pine, hops, caramel. 
Medium body.
Not a bad finish. Not too bitter.

First complaint, which has nothing to do with the specific beer, is that the 12 oz bottle had a shockingly small amount of beer (you could pour enough to go at least a quarter way up the neck). That said, I love hoppy reds, and this was a decent example of the style, but perhaps not hoppy enough for me.

Bomber poured a clear dark reddish amber with a lingering ring of amber fgoam. Aromas of earthiness, carmel, light citrus and light pine. Palate was medium bodied and crisp. Flavors of earthiness, carmel, light grapefruit and light pine with a crisp lingering moderatly bitter finish.

Dark to medium brown in color.  Head is small and short lived with a tan hue.  Aroma is caramel and dark fruit.  A bunch of different hops make up the front end.  Sweetness and rye on the back.  Bitterness on the aftertaste.  Not huge alcohol but if feels like alcohol evaporating off the tongue.  This beer in delightfully complex with dark fruit, hops, caramel, citrus fruit, and rye all moving in and out.  It also offers a nice zingy feel.  Very well crafted.
22oz - Brown/orange liquid/ small light tan head.  Sweet sugar and flowers on nose.  Mildly sweet malt with a peppery back.  A proper ale, can certainly see the Scotch Ale influence.

Deep, rich mahogany on pour with a pillowy off white to tan head that has staying power. The lace clings to the glass like the morning frost on the windows. Very complex notes of cherry, red berry, malt, and tobacco appeal to the olfactory system. Im going to say medium bodied with a creamy start and hoppy/slightly bitter finish. It leaves me short of calling it balanced. Being only familiar with Racer 5, I can confidently say I will be searching out other Bear Republic concoctions.

12oz bottle.  Lovely mahogany color with dense and fluffy tan head that leaves lots of lacy bits on the glass, bright and rich aroma like a grapefruit drenched in molasses, flavor is pretty light with plenty of hoppy citrusy notes and some cinnamon and cardamom, finishes with some nice bitterness but not as smooth and balanced on the end as I would like.  Very tasty and refreshing, light on the palate but with a nice depth of flavor.

Deep reddish, brown pour.  Darker towards the middle with a two-finger, off-white pillowy head.  Very sticky lace and tons of floaties.  Sweet nose....caramel, brown sugar, grapefruit and orange peels.  Great, almost familiar, flavor.  Similar to a 90 minute.  Molasses, candied grapefruit, chocolate covered oranges and a sappy herbalness to boot.  Crystal malt shines here as it finishes moderately sweet with a lingering bitterness.  Very smooth and creamy...another solid concoction.  Im not sure if its an Am. Strong though.  Seems more like a dark IPA or a toned down BW.  Nonetheless, good stuff.
ྫྷoz bottle) Sampled at Solomons in Victoria for $6. Nice malty base, shellacked orange peel. Smooth. Great hop and malt balance. Very enjoyable. 7/4/8/3/15

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2010 Bottle. Deep, dark reddish brown, with a fine tall off-white head. Super hop aroma, very fruity, with a slight amber malt background. Citrus and a bit of bubblegum as well. Round malt flavor, very rich and smooth, with dark fruits, caramel, chocolate; slightly chewy and grainy. Amazingly hopped. Rich, deep, complex malts. Very big flavor all around. Long, almost burning hop finish, with fruit and slightly roasted grains. Fantastic. Might even get better with age

from crackedkettle.com - slighlty hazy reddish-brown colour with a little beige foam; aroma of prune and caramel; fairly malty, medium to full body; the solid initial sweetness is met by a strong bitterness; moderately dry fruity and malty finish - solid and well-made

22oz bottle.  pours a deep garnet/purple with a medium sized foamy beige head.  aroma of black tea, hops, caramel malt, citrus and floral hops, licorice.  flavors are robust with plenty of hops, caramel, licorice and a spicy cinnamon finish.  really smooth, creamy, velvety palate.  this stuff is really tasty!  leaves a great drippy lace in glass.  the cinnamon brings this to life.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Dark ruby colour with frothy, beige head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of blood orange, red berries and pine needles. Malty, fruity taste with blood orange, caramel, red berries and a generous piney bitterness in the finish. Very nice beer with solid malt and an impressive hop character.

Dark smoky reddish brown with a tan head. Fruity sweet hoppy aromas. The hops and caramel malt notes make this pretty chewy. Biting hop character lingers on through to a long finish. The malts are nice, but clearly play a  supporting role for this full bodied ale. There is some light notes of grapefruit, and orange towards the end as well as a sharp, herbal hop astringency.
Great deep red color. Im getting malt, and maybe a hint of hops but nothing else from the nose. Taste gives a harsh bitter from the hops - and some nice caramel on the finish.

22oz bottle.  Color is a deep dark ruby.  Carbonation is very good producing a thick tan head that stay on till your done.  Aroma is malty sweet with a bright hop scent.  Taste smooth and sweet.  Starting with a medium body it goes down with a creamy feel.  Finish comes in sweet with malt, caramel and a hint of fruit, then floral hops and a mellow bitterness.  In the after taste the sweet flavor drop quickly letting the bitterness stand out a bit.  This brew rocks, it has bold flavors and yet it drinks with a light feel.  Best of all this bottle only cost $4.50 so I can drink it all the time.

A hazy and sedimented dark red-brown beer with a decent light tan head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is darker malt, evocative of dark fruit, dried fruit, with some roasty notes and also vague hops in the background. Flavor is a bit roastier, with burnt toast, a bit of coffee/chocolate, plum, cherry, and a bitter astringency. Comparable to, but not as good as Arrogant Bastard.

A beautiful amber/crimson color with beige head.  The aroma is malty and full of caramel with a touch of pine and hops.  The body is of medium weight and smooth.  The aftertaste is somewhat bitter and dry.

12 oz bottle..hazy dark amber pour, small beige ,some lacing.aroma of caramel, citrus hops and a hint of roasted malt.sweet malt flavor gives way to aa agressive piney/citrusy hop bitteriness .medium bodied ,finish is dry and lingering.

Pours a dark brownish red with a small beige head. The aroma is very malty, lots of caramel, and a touch of hops. The flavor is nice and sweet, and drinks a lot like a barleywine. Rich mouthfeel and nice flavor make this a very enjoyable brew.

This is only my second Bear Republic.  Racer 5 is a specail ale that is one of my go to IPAs. Rocket Ale pours dark and with a smallish head. This a complex ale more like a hopped up red ale.    The deep maghogany color and bitter hops flavors was great.  The spicy aroma gave a hint this was going to be a ride.
Pours ruby red with a tan head.  Smells of dark fruit, some spicy hints, velvety hoppy hints, some citrus.  Tastes resiny and sweet with a sticky palate.

Bottle. Pours deep, deep red (nearly maroon--its gorgeous). Very thin tannish head. Aroma is extremely pleasant; hints of caramel and perhaps raisin or other dried fruit. Flavor is complex, yet subtle. Body is medium, with a rich, creamy complexion. Absolutely fantastic ale.

Bottle at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Deep reddish brown color with a rich firm tan-coloured foam. Rich hoppy aroma of lychee, resin and pink grapefruit with sweetish undertones of black cherries and caramel. Medium-bodied with notes of caramel, black cherries, grapefruit, resin, mint and crackers. Long bitter finish of grapefruit, grass, resin and burnt caramel.
22oz bottle.  Pours clear red with a big tan head.  Sweet malt aroma with caramel and some piney hops.  Caramel malt flavor with some fruit and dry bitter hop finish.
A reddish-brown beer with a 1 finger head. A nice hoppy aroma with some spice. The taste was fruity hops, a dash of caramel, & a dash of chocolate with the bitterness coming in the end.

12 oz bottle.  Pours deep dark ruby with hints of orange.  Foamy light tan head, decent lacing.  Smell of pine hops, spicy cinnamon and caramel.  Deep sweetness that is pretty complex almost giving hints of umami and soy, then followed by a sharp clean bitterness.  A bit dry on the tongue and a long lasting funky bitterness deep at the back of the tongue.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 Pours a deep, dark red with a light cream colored head.  I loved this a lot, its balanced, yet bold.  The big bitter pine hops in the finish are the most noticable aspect, but up front theres a great sweet fruity caramel flavor with a touch of spice to it.

Draft.  Dark red pour with foamy off white head.  Aroma of hops, caramel, malt, citrus, and grains.  Hoppy flavor with malt and caramel.  Good balance.  Medium bodied.  Sweet, dry, slightly bitter finish.  Very tasty.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2009 Draft at restaurant... dark red-brown opaque, beige frothy head . Very hoppy aroma mixed with big caramel sweetness... Big malt chocolate sweetness is well balances with the big hoppiness. A full-bodied and well crafted brew.
Impressive dark red pour with nice creamy off white head...very smooth drink for the hop head in you.

Pretty nice Hoppy red.. Pours dark red with a nice white head. Smells of some pine and malt. Really nice medium body with a great carbonation. Flavor was pretty close to other hoppy reds I have had.. sweet and a bitter finish

Pours deep red with big rocky, meringue-like head that is oh so gorgeous and just wont go away.  Nose is sometime tame with faint citrus and caramelly aromas.  That caramel is certainly present on the palate along with an unexpected complexity of hops that actually reminds me of some of Bear Republics other beers.  This one is easy drinking and full of flavor for a "mere" red ale.
Belle mousse beige qui colle bien au verre. Mélange darômes de malt-houblo-caramel. Très maltée et légèrement caramélisée en bouche. Finale légèrement houblonnée et piquante.

Pours a very dark amber bearing a frothy light brown head. Big aromas of citrus, little floral hops, big caramel, with a little grain. The flavor mostly resembles an IPA. It has a a slight over empowerment of citrus and floral hops over the caramel with some grapefruit. Sweet, bitter, and slightly dry. Comes close to a balanced equilibrium but the hops do come through first and more so. Love these aspects of a beer!

Bomber.  Pours a deep dark red with frothy tan head.  Nice caramel nose with hops underneath.  Flavor is caramel with raisins and bitter hops over a nice toasted malt backbone.  Ends with a nice bitterness which balances the malt sweetness.  Medium palate, very drinkable but yet aggresive.  Very good.

bottle: pint glass: Pours... you guessed it: RED! a deep mahahony/ brown actually.  Very thin head upon pour, yet literally zero head remained.  Tastes of roasted malts, dark fruits... nice start.  Ends with strong bitters and a burned quality, fairly offensive.  Not a fan at all... however it is a good representative of its style.

bottle:  pour deep red with thin head.  Smelled of hops and a slight carmel malt smell.  Bit more to the bitter side than I  like, but flavor had light carmel malts with strong bitter end.  Pretty good.

Pours dark amber color with a big dark tan head that has some staying power. Cane sugar and hop aroma with a hint of alcohol. The flavor is similar, some sweetness from the sugars, balanced very nicely by the right amount of bitterness from the hops. Warm and toasty palate, very enjoyable red/strong ale.

Bottle: Hoppy and malty, well balanced. All medals well deserved. I´m not sure is I would classify ir as an American Strong Ale, IPA, or Red Ale, for sure somewhere in between. Food Pairing: BBQ Steak or Pork and strong cheeses. Drank in San Diego.

330 mL. Pours a translucent dark brown with a small, tan, Coca-cola head that has okay retention and leaves excellent, sheety lacing. Big west coast IPA aroma, a little pumpkin spice, earthy hops. Taste is big on grapefruit, resiny hops, caramel malt, dirty earthiness. Long, resiny bitter aftertaste. Sort of like a dark IPA. Yummy.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Quite hoppy and light fruity to roasted malt aroma. Fruity hoppy flavoured. Light roasted malt note to this. Quite bitter and grapefruity finish.

bottle. Average light creamy beige head that mostly diminished. Spare lacework. Nutty amber color. Aroma of caramel, toasted malt, floral, grape. Medium to almost full bodied, average carbonation. Moderated sweet and bitter flavor. Toasted malty and light bitter finish.

Bottle. Deep red brown in color, very little head, lots of particles floating around. Aroma is malts, dark fruits, yeast, caramel & brown sugar, and maybe a hint of grassy hops. Flavor is sweet malts, caramel, brown sugar, hints of dark frutis, a little bready, and then finishes with a nice smattering of hoppy bitterness. Really like this ale, very drinkable. Well done.
Bought it at Whole Foods in Sacramento. Pours a redish brown color.  Nice sweetness of the malts at the beginning, then it is followed by slight bitterness of the hops.  Very well brewed.

From a bottle.  Pours a dark red/brown with a little head and lots of lacing.  Aroma is brown sugar and hops.  Mouthfeel is thick.  Hops are prevalent with a good amount of bitterness.  I like this beer but it quite get a top tier rating.  It could use a little more flavor balance.  I could mainly taste the hops and not much else. Either way, I would drink again and can tell its very high quality.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 HAVENT HEARD MUCH ABOUT THIS BEER GRABBED IT JUST OUTTA CURIOSITY. POURS DEEP RED ALMOST BLACK WITH A LITTLE  OFF WHITE HEAD THAT DISAPEARS AFTER A FEW SIPS, TASTES LIKE TOASTED ALMOST BURNT MALT GENEROUS BITTER HOPS WITHOUT THE SWEETNESS AND SLIGHT LICORICE NOT BAD.
Bottle, Nice hops, pours a dark red color with a thin tan head. Good, tasty stuff. Once again Bear Republic impresses me. Another great quality brew.

Pours reddish brown into the glass with a slightly off white head.  Aroma is nice hops with some caramel malt.  Really love the flavor and balance of this beer.  Lots of bitterness yet very soft on the palate with plenty of sweet caramel malt.  Really great brew from these guys.

This beer pours a deep mahogany almost black with a thin tan head leaving some decent lacing down the sides. The smell is of nice beet sugars and hops and the flavor totally emulates this. I am not a huge hops guy, but this really is not that bad of a beer!   Its got a strong hops flavor but is equally balanced by the malts. I thought by the smell this would be more malty and less hoppy, which was a bit of a letdown for mw, but still a great brew.

bottle. Average light creamy beige head that mostly diminished. Spare lacework. Nutty amber color. Aroma of caramel, toasted malt, floral, grape. Medium to almost full bodied, average carbonation. Moderated sweet and bitter flavor. Toasted malty and light bitter finish.

Unusual meaty aroma, somewhat like fish on the initial burst. Malty, with some tobacco like notes. Dark reddish brown body with a tan rich head.  Flavor is hopped up roasted red malt.  Dryish at the end and lightly bitter. Some mild dried figs, caramel.  Palate is lightly creamy with a bitter sweet duration. Pretty good.

Pours a very cloudy dark reddish brown, thin bit of dark tan foam. Aroma has a little bit of everything in it -- malty/bready, hoppy/spicy, and fruity/citrusy. Taste is the same - a pretty complex beer. I think the one I tried was a little bit old perhaps -- a bit flat and a hint of a sour note to it, but still very good.
Bottle at home ... brown thin lacing ... sweet phoppy toffe malt little chocolate nose ... very soft ... little creamy ... little toffee ... soft vanilla malt ..

Bomber, poured into tulip glasses and split four ways.  Color is soft amber, with a nice fluffy head (it doesnt last all that long!).  Aroma has red cherries, milk chocolate, hops and parsley.  Flavor starts with some interesting chocolate, cherry, and toffee, then moves swiftly  a touch heavy-handedly  towards strawberry and bitter hops.  By the finishing essence, this emerges quite bitter and lasting. Very tasty, but drank with the wrong crowd (i.e. non-hopheads), this one wont sit well.

Poured from Bottle into Pint glass.

Pours a brilliant deep ruby color that is crystal clear with a thin tan head that remains atop the glass and leaves nice lacing as you sip. The Aroma has a resinous piney hop aroma with some bready, toasted malts to follow it up. The flavor has more hop flavor upfront with some dried fruits and ends up sweet and with a lingering citrus bitterness. Its a medium bodied beer that is slightly sticky. Im really glad the flavor came through for this one because the aroma was just a little boring. Tasty Malt Beverage.

Bottle from mar, thanks!  Pours a reddish color wtih a nice tan head.  aroma is has great malt and hop notes.  Citrus, caramel, yeast, resin and some good fruity notes.  Flavor is very nice.  Pine and citrus hops dominate with some nice fruity caramel malts blending perfectly.  Good stuff!

Just an insanely tasty beer that for some unknown reason Ive not rated, although consumed in rather large amounts.  The beer pours out stunning dark amber/rusty red color, clear with a really nice light tan creamy thick head.  Aroma has a fresh, clean hop attack with the 1-2 grapefruit/pine punch, followed up with a great toasted bread angle and some roasted nuts.  Really interesting.  Flavor is oozing with glorious hops, dark fruits, some cherry cordial, and caramel.  Is this a beer or is this a freakin dessert?  WOW.  Amazingly tasty beer that Ive enjoyed repeatedly for the past 2-3 years.

Bottle, 65cl - Hazy dark orange amber beer with a large beige orange head. Aroma is sweet malty with strong grapefruit notes. Flavor is sweet with strong notes of grapefruit and litchi. Balanced but rather bitter for an American strong ale.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a fantastic color, a reddish copper with a great tan head.  The head lasts quite awhile, helps produce some great aromas throughout.
