Those aromas include some citrus, some bread, lots of pine.  The taste has some impressive bitterness, but starts with a hint of sweet malts.  Overall the balance is quite nice.  Suprisingly low ABV for all of that strong flavor.  Still enough alcohol to get the job done, though, that wasnt a complaint.  Really great beer.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a thick looong lived tan head, with great lacing, over a clear, brownish (SRM 18) body....nose is floral ,slightly citrus, bit of bread, medium pine....taste is initiallly sweet malt, folloewd by balancing citrus bitterness.....mouth feel is thick heavy, carbonation light. Nice heavy brew, with a rather low ABV for all the taste.

22oz bottle $4.49. Deep red color, chestnut almost, creamy yet short off-white head. The smell is "sticky" and a little sweet to my nose, maybe its malts? Flavor is pretty good, I think there are hops but they seem to be layered under a chewy maltiness. Overall, this was a good buy and a good value.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-28-2009 01:36:24

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 I didnt care for this beer. I found it a bit flabby and shapeless. I know that puts me strongly in the minority here. Ill have to give it a shot again sometime, but for now the rating stands. I was at a Bear Republic tasting last night, and at some point, I think due to the pervasive hop use, it all started tasting the same to me. 

Rerate: I think I like this beer more than my initial rate indicated, but its too malty/sweet. Can definitely tell its Bear Republic!
Root beer colored pour with a thick beige head and medium lacing. Nose is earth and bread with a hint of pine. Taste is malt and caramel. mouthfeel is plush. Finish is hoppy and lingers nicely.

pours a cloudy brown with a red tint when held to the light, a medium size tan head, and great lacing.

smell of grapefruit, spice, earth, some pine, and a touch of caramel.

taste is thick, dry, malt, spice, caramel, roasted nuts, brown sugar, and hops in the back, ends nicely bitter.

22oz bottle.... murky reddish pour... little head, slight carbonation.... aromas of chocolate are very prevalent.... nice balanced ale... that is highly drinkable and complex.... a good first try from bear republic... recommended

Pours a deep amber-brown with a pale brown head and tonnes of lace. Light sweet malt aroma, not much in the way of hops. Malty, sweet taste with a good but neutral hop balance. Small amount of roasted malt, not too cloying sweet. Nice! Good carbonation and nice creamy mouthfeel. The only problem I have with this beer is the notion of it being an American Strong Ale. If anything, its an ESB, or an Irish Red Ale. There simply isnt enough oily citrus hop character for it to stand out as particularly American. Great session beer, though!

Bottle - Wow. I didnt really expect much out of this beer, but it knocked me clean off my feet and french-kissed me with all sorts of flavors. Its a nice pour, with a hazy mahogany color and a little tan head. My wife, who apparently wasnt french-kissed by this beer, said it smelled like a "stinky barn." I would agree, if stinky barns smelled like buttery toffee, caramel, molasses, and bourbon. The taste was nearly as good, with sweet malt, that lovely bourbon, and some dry grains. It finishes with some subtly spicy hops on the back of my tongue, though there was a weird off taste from time to time. Man, this beer is smooth too -- I loved everything about it.
Dark amber pour, medium head, light lace. Hoppy sweet aroma. Whoa, big hops and alcohol. Very little malt to balance. All hops and pine, thick and tasty, yum.

Pours brown with a thin caramel head.  Aroma is caramel malts, some licorice, and spices.  Taste is bitter hops, caramel malts, licorice.  This is maybe a little too bitter, but still a very good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2009 A bit more bitter/astringent than Im used to, but its starting to win me over.  I got this 22oz bottle at a good price so Id probably get it again.  

I like the licorice flavor overtones... good for a sipper.

On a whim, I mixed it with some Blue Point Blueberry ale that I was also drinking, and the flavors balanced pretty nicely.  

update 11/24. I think I like this less on the retry. My taste has developed somewhat since I had this beer, but I still havent gotten the hang of appreciating these strong ales.

Aroma of flowery hops and sweet malt and some spices.  Hints of licorice as well.  Color is a dark mahogany with a medium tan head.  Flavor is rich and malty, this beer is full bodied with a creamy finish.  Alcohol content is not super high but there is still a chest warming feeling in the finish.
Bottle at World Beer Pub and Foods Bulldog, Ginza. Mahogny-coloured with a huge tan head. Citrus hop nose and flavours, but with a solid malty base to complement it. Uncompromising red ale.

Bottle  Pours a cloudy brown with red highlights with a thin off white head.  The head seems to last well and laces fairly well also.  The aroma is of pine citrus, malts and a touch caramel.  Has a decent carbination.  The mouthfeel is good. Has a good blending, and nice flavors.  This is light to medium bodied.  Has a pretty good finish.  In style I think this is an awesome beer.  It hits on all the points it should.  As a beer drinker its refreshing and good.  A win win.
22 oz bomber. pours dark red/brown i was expecting less than i got. huge hop aroma with just the right mix of malts. Seems all these west coast brews never disapoint. glad Im here to try them!

Pours an opaque deep amber colour with a sudsy, frothy tan head that has moderate retention and spotty lacing. The aroma is rich with pine, caramel, grapefruit citrus and vinous malts. There is also a peppery overtone accompanying the nose. Initially, the flavour is dominated with bright citric notes and toffee sweetness. The aftertaste though brings out a spicy bite that is reminiscent of rye malt. The finish is dry, roasty and somewhat coffee-like. The palate is medium bodied and sticky in texture, especially in the finish.

Bottle courtesy Maltjoe. Pours a thick copper brown with a thick creamy head. Citrus hops and a touch of caramel aroma. Taste is big and hoppy, lots of bitter citrus and pine with a nice thick malt body and a touch of spiciness. I like the balance of hop and darker malts, very well done.

Poured from a 22 oz bottle into a pint glass for drinking.  The beer had a strong caramel malt aroma with some fruit and toffee undertones.  There was also a hop presence, heavily focused on pine with some grain too.  It had a somewhat cloudy dark copper-amber color with an average-sized foamy tan head that had shorter retention and moderate cling.  The beer had a sweet caramel malt flavor with some underlying grainy bitterness, and only a touch of sour character.  A wet, drinkable beer that was smooth, but very lively with its carbonation and full on the palate.  A solid ale that fit its style well.

Clear dark copper pour, moderate beige head with good retention and complex lacing. Nose of piney hops, plums, figs, and tea leaves; Flavour is dominated by American hops throughout with a long, peppery finish. Mouthfeel is relatively light with sparkling carbo, all round another excellent offering from Bear Republic.
12oz bottle. Very tasty indeed. These guys really brew good beer. This is perhaps the darkest red ale I have seen yet and a great tasting one at that.

Great color....deep red brown with a creamy head. Aroma has hints of hops (pine, resin) and caramel, toffee and roasted malts. Flavor is definitely in-your-face...roasted malt, burnt caramel, toffee, hoppy resin and a bitter finish that takes your by surprise. This beer is most certainly a bastard...and a tasty one.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2009 Pours from the bottle to a brownish hue with hints of ruby and a medium thick off-white head that lasts awhile and leaves okay lacing. Immediately out of the bottle is a strong nose of malty dark druit infused nicely with hops, and as the beer warms, it is joined by the scent of the alcohol. Mouthfeel is tingly and full and the taste is even a more pronounced malty fruit blended with hops, with hints of nuts, caramel and again, the alcohol. Finish is long, full and somewhat bitter.

A darn good beer.
Poured reddish brown with a white head. Aroma of citrus. More hoppy than malty. Some caramel.

Poured into a snifter, its bright red amber with dark cherry tones and plenty of fluffy tan foam with good retention. Hops definitely come through the aroma, nice florals on top of caramel. I served it a little warm, but I get that citrus rind bitterness up front, then settle into substantial breadyness, delicately sweet. Medium bodied that holds up pretty well. Nice brew. I dont think Ive had one from Bear Republic that I didnt like. Great for the price at around $7.

Bear Republic Red Rocket Ale exhibits a dark red hue along with a large, frothy tan head. Very hoppy and strong like an Arrogant Bastard Ale. The aroma was primarily of hops. Flavors of barley, bitter hops and cherry hints provide plenty of entertainment during a sip.

Great beer and my personal favorite of BRs line-up. Slightly sweet and balanced masterfully to enhance the copper tone of the delicious amber colour and the hoppy, caramel, piney goodness. Do you think I enjoyed this? Oh my dear...

Bottle.  Pours more like a brown rocket than a red one... sure there is a lot of reddish highlighting, but generally, Id call it brown.  Head is fairly small, fluffy and tan.  Aromas are very nice... quite a bit of sweet malt caramel and the like with a good dose of hops mixed in... pineapple and oranges seem to be the main hops aromas.  First reaction is that mouthfeel is thick and kind of dusty/grainy.  This strikes me even before the flavors are detected.  As for the flavor, however, things are much like the nose predicted.  Maybe a little more of a grainy sweetness up front and maybe a little bit of a sharper pine bite in the finish.  Still, this is pretty good brew.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: The aroma has tea, prunes, caramel, citrus, pine, and fruit. The appearance is deep amber with a nice head. The flavor is like the aroma with a bitter sweet finish. The palate is average. Overall this is a very very good beer.
good beer, the aroma smeels a bit like fresh pencils, and other wood aroma. taste is highly black tea with a touch of maple syrup. harsh bitterness at the end.  still very good overall.

Overall Impression: 
Nice dark color, relatively dark color for a red ale, very hoppy flavor with a hint caramel, and a smooth taste, excellent beer from what I have found to be a really solid brewery
bottle..red pour..white head..nice hops.flavor is hoppy.sweet malt..not a bad ale...

Deep red pour with light, off white head. Piney, spicey aroma, with nice hops, Flavor is hoppy with a nice, spicey malt background. Some rye, mostly fruity hops. Medium bodied. Pretty awesome session ale.

On tap at the Beechtree.  Pours a clear deep crimson with a medium sized tanned beige head.  Lacing.  Sweet resin filled pine and citrus hops with a note of pineapple.  Thin to medium bodied, sweet and malty, with some hops coming through in the body.  Long bitter grapefruit finish.  Excellent stuff.

Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a two finger off-white, almost tan head.  Looks almost like a stout.  Strong roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate coffee and sweet fruit.  Flavor has a strongly roasted, malted/hoppy character with a crisp finish.  Not what I expected but delicious nonetheless.
Beautiful look. She fills up my pint glass with thick head and dark color. Full of malty hoppiness. Stays with me all the way.

Pours an amber/red dark tea color with a coper hue. The off tan head is minimal with lacing and some carbonation action.
Caramel roasted malt smell with some florals.
Lots of grapefruit and tea and the sweet roasted malt is well balanced throughout.
Medium/moderate bodied smooth palate with lively soft carbonation.
Another fantastic offering from Bear Republic.

Very heavy amber colour with minimal head. Definately a strong Ale. The hops were almost too much and had to really sip this one.  The malt flavour was moderate and really dominated by the hops here. A bit more balance might serve it well but still enjoyable

Bottle graciously given to me by BeerGestapo. Thanks Mike. Served in a stem glass. Dark garnet pour topped by a lasting large khaki head. Smells of toffee, herbal hops, caramel, and bread. The flavor is similar with an added burst of citrus and cocoa. Nice dry finish with lasting bitterness. This rocket is delicious!

Draught @ Flying Saucer, Columbia SC. Brownish-red, deep and opaque. Smells hoppy. Low carbonation but chewy mouthfeel. Dark berries, lingering fruit pit finish. Tannins in palate are rough and astringent. The hop-malt balance is good and nice fruit pit character as well.

Dark red to brown in color with a good size tan head.  Hoppy with caramel and malty aromas.  Flavor definitely has hoppiness with not overwhelming it takes away from the balance I was expecting.  Gets better and better closer to the bottom.

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a clear amber color with a small off-white head. Hasa malty hoppy caramel aroma with some hints of citrus. Sweetish malty hoppy bitter citrus flavor with some hints of caramel. Has a sweetish malt ybitter hoppy finish.
Bottle.  Powerful citusy aroma.  Reddish amber body, gigantic thick rocky tan head.  Moderately sweet flavor, with plenty of hoppy bite and citrus.   Some bitterness in the finish.  Very enjoyable.

12 oz bottle.  Pours clear ruby red with a tidy, lasting, and dense light tan head that leaves streaky lacing.  Aroma hits first with piney hops, then with caramelly and roasty malts with some fruity and pronounced spicy notes.  Flavor balances rather bitter with piney hops, but the robust malt bill adds some complexity and helps support the high bitterness.  Medium bodied and smooth with creamy low-moderate carbonation.  This is a nice strong bitter ale; nothing spectacular, but solid.  Personally its a bit too bitter and a hair too thin for me, but overall its well-done.

Bomber.  Poured clear coppery orange with a short-lived dusting of whitish head.  The aroma picked up toasty, slightly aged caramel, brown sugar, and soapy hops in fairly solid balance with each other.  The flavor was caramel-centric with scratchy bitter citrus and fruity notes around.. mild oxidation worked for it.. finished long and bitter, with sweeter caramel backing it up.  Medium-bodied with low carbonation on the palate.. bitterness was high, and didnt work too well at certain points.  Overall drinkable, but average.
UPDATED: JUN 4, 2009 Bottle. Aromas very nice gives a high expectation of flavor however flavor is good but doesnt meet expectation of aroma.

On tap at Capones. Poured a beautiful garnet with ruby edges and a light mocha head. Bouquet was uber pine, awesome. Taste was incredible; the pine bites and the malt kicks, a wonderful balance of titans. The palate was slightly resinous but not cloying and only really left me wanting more. Really good overall, not that I was expecting anything less from Bear Republic.

This fits the bill as a malt bomb while holding onto just enough hops to keep the beer interesting.  Deep garnet color with a solid cream colored head.  Brown sugar, caramel, and toffee in aroma...the flavor has a nice citrus and ponderosa presence.  Sticky but not cloying...a good brew.
Super malty. Red ale that sticks in your mouth a bit. Lots of caramel mixed in. Better than Rogues version, double or single Dead Guy.

This is a great example of going strong and hoppy while staying balanced. Very American. Aroma is caramel sweet with a bit of pine. The flavor is a perfect balance of heavy caramel and chocolate malts and a good dose of piney and peppery hops. Nicely done.

From a cask at Rattle n Hum.  Fresh, sweet hop aroma.  Interesting flavor.  Sweet and hoppy, with some herby notes.  The herbal flavors seem to transpire more when you have something from a cask.  Clean, hoppy finish.  This stuff is pretty close to unique, and it is very enjoyable too.

Pours dark amber with a small white head.  Aroma and flavor have a nice balance of hops to malt and b/c this beer isn’t too over the top in terms of alcohol it actually works.  Most beers of this style, even Arrogant Bastard, just had too much of a good thing (malts and hops) are really just overdue it in my book.  This is a tasty and hoppy red with a nice dry finish. Very impressive.

Style and Glass: American Strong Ale, Trappist; Snifter
ABV, Volume & Calories: 6.8 % in 22 fl oz. estimated at 300 C
Purchased at: Canals Lawrenceville for $1.66 ($19.99 for a 12 bomber case on special)

Aroma: nice, cocoa, heather, hay, flowers, leaves, musty, musk, dark roast malts.

Visuals: exciting packaging, like a lighter flavored chocolate stout, brown to black, fully opaque, staying rocky tan head, sticky intricate lace.

Taste: chocolate malts, more towards malt than hops, focyus on aromatic hops, some bittering hops finish, delicious.

Palate: milky, peppery carbonation, wash, surf, medium finish.

Overall: Amazing for the special price. Ill have it about 11 more times at least. Id like to pair it with something like pizza, broccoli, garlic chicken, soy, beans, lots of possibilities there.
originally posted at: <a href="http://beercritic.wordpress.com/?p=1872
Poured a nice chestnut ruby with nice lace. Evergreen and spice aroma. Chewy malt and hoppy with a bit of gingerbread.

Pours a dark ruby copper with a thin creamy light tan head. The nose is pungent resiny piny hops, sweet caramel malt, spicy. The flavor is spicy, hoppy, nice bitterness, sweet caramel malt, mild citrus, piney. Palate has a nice spicy bitterness.

Pours brownish red with a nice tan head nice color good solid hop aroma floral and citrus nice malt character chocolate and sweet great balance great flavor Scotch ale on hop steroids
not as malty as Kilt Lifter but much hoppier possibly a new favorite.

Pours a dark red brick/amber color. Pour creates a dense, tight light tan head with superb retention throughout. A good amount of lacing curtains the sides of the snifter. Terrific aromas of roasted malts, toasted bread, brown sugar and caramels initially shows its sweet side. Aromas show, as does the flavors a great balance with crisp hoppy citrus, spice and floral notes from the hops also filling the nose. Mouthfeel is full, round and smooth with a bit of oiliness. Flavors start sweet much like the aromas with caramel malt, toffee and brown sugar quickly followed up with a firm but moderate hop bitterness with citrus and pine coming through. Definitely one of the most balanced bigger amber ales in the market.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 Rocket brown is more like it.  This is a deep dark red pour with yellowish off-white head.  Lots of hops and lots of malt on this one, but the bitter hops win out, which disappointed me.  Not as complex as I wanted. I was hoping for something closer to Old Chub, but I guess given the ABV, that is not a realistic expectation.  This was a good beer, for sure, but I was not in the mood for such a bitter hop bomb. More malt, please.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2009 Brewed in the USA.....Pours a reddish brown color with a dissipating white head. Aroma of mega hops, malts and i noticed a slight fruity character. Taste is of caramel malts with a yummy hoppy edge that really makes a big difference. The mouthfeel has a bitter finish to it, but i must say thats what i like about this ale. Bear Republic strikes again.
Piney aroma, red color, and lots of hops.  Would have liked a little more malty sweetness to balance.  Crisp mouthfeel.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Spicy hops and lots of em.  Chewy, awesome texture.  Just a plain good beer.

somewhat cloudy ruby red in color with a thinnish light tan/cream head, it presents a rather flat look. First impression of the nose is hops. After that mellows comes a lot of caramel and a malt underbody with what seems like vanilla as a smoothing agent. Complex. Taste is less reliant on the hops and more balanced with notes of pine dominating. Overall mouthfeel does seem a bit watery.

This beer pours a great rubby brown color with a HUGE thick frothy head. Might have been my pour but that aside this was a great beer. Nice bitey hops balanced with thick sweet sugars. I like the play just wish it did not pour so thick of a head.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2009 I absolutely love this ale -- when they get it right.  I have been drinking, and usually enjoying this one for about a year.  It seems to me, however, that there are issues with consistency in overall quality.  

Problem is, I dont know which Red Rocket Im getting when I purchase it.  Sometimes, I get the brilliant Red Rocket I rhapsodized about in my initial review.  Other times, I get a brew ranging from "deeply disappointing" to "decent" to "almost got it right this time."  Its a mixed bag.  At best, truly exceptional; at worst, mediocre.

Bottle. Aroma of caramel malt with brown sugar and sweet toffee overtones, as well as a meandering hop spice presence. Flavor the same, predominantly malty but with a strong hop edge nonetheless. Nothing incredibly exciting to be sure, but a really nice beer to be sure as well.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown/dark amber with a thick, creamy light tan head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt, light fruits, and apple skins.  Flavor is super malty with a bitter hops finish.  Almost like a hoppy barleywine.  Nice beer, enjoyable.

Dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is pretty powerful. Fresh hops and some citrus dominate. Eucalyptus and some spice as well. Flavor is caramel and cream, with lots of hops, citrus and spice as well. Very grassy finish. Nice creamy mouthfeel. There is a lot going on here. I really enjoy this.

Bottle; poured a reddish copper color with a compact off white/tan head.  Aroma was nicely balanced; caramel, toffee, citrus, fruit, cocoa all blended well.  Probably one of the best aromas for this fairly diverse style.  Flavor did not quite live up to expectations, but it wasn’t bad by any means.  Earthy, caramel malt predominates with a good amount of grassy/citrus hops in the finish.  Not very alcoholic.  Hints of sugary sweetness.  Enjoyable.

22 oz bottle.  Deep dark copper brown.  Creamy head leaves strong ring against the glass.  Rich malt nose, sharp and roasted.  Undertones of prunes, molasses.  Lots of flavors going on...  Sharp, sweet, warm, bitter.  Really good.  Gooey in the back of my throat.  Yummy.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a deep red body and a good thick head.  Brown sugar and citrus aromas, with a bit of dried fruit.  The dried fruit really comes out in the flavor, and is pretty hoppy.  Very heavy, but some how smooth in the mouth.  Very solid ale.

22 oz bomber. Poured a dark brown with a reddish tinge. Strong floral aroma with a bit of citrus lingering as well. The flavor is full of dried fruit and a has a large hoppy backbite. Probably the least good of the Bear Republics I’ve had so far, which tells you how much I’ve enjoyed their beers thus far.

12oz bottle. Pours deep reddish brown with huge thick and creamy light tan head. Aroma is hops, citrus, sweet malt, brown sugar, toffee and dark fruits. Flavor is hops, sweet malt, citrus, caramel, toffee and brown sugar. Nice thick and chewy mouthfeel.  Damn good brew.

Pours dark brown, almost black with frothy head and good lacing. Aroma is dominated by dark fruit, brown sugar, and an overall theme of sweet malt. Some grapefruity hops poke through as well, but only mildly. Flavor is loaded with silky smooth, and somewhat roasty malt with some sweetness. Hoppyness complements the sweetness of the malt. Palate is full and smooth.

Pours a reddish black with a good amount of carbonation and a frothy head that leaves a beautiful lacing. Aroma is malty and sweet, with brown sugar, caramel, and maybe a touch of dark fruit. Flavor is nice, with some notes of roasted malt, sugar- has some of the qualities of a sweet stout. Palate is decent but nothing noteworthy. A good beer.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a one finger light tan head and pretty decent lacing.  Nose is floral and citrus hops, dark fruits with some alcohol.  Taste is sweet malt and some dark fruits at first with citrus malts dominating after that, before some resin bite rounds it out. Theres a touch of alcohol in the finish as well. Medium mouth feel.  Good beer.  Comes off like a hoppy barley wine.

Pours dark amber with thick fizzy head.  Aroma is malt with some pine/resin hop aroma.  Flavor is okay, I was not blown away.  Good balance.  Tastes a bit like the scotch ale I just finished... with a bit more hop balance.  Decent drinkable beer.

Appearance: This ale poured a rich mahogony with a gorgeous, rich thick pillowy head. As I swirl the beer in my tulip glass, the head continues to refresh.

Aroma: I am a bit surprised that there is not a greater intensity. The beer smells fresh and green, but doesn’t possess a huge aroma.

Taste: The first flavor I notice from this beer is a slightly bitter hop taste that lingers on the palate. The hops are definitely present, but it seems to be missing some malt presence. Some slight chocolate malt flavors make themselves felt, but the hoppiness dominates.

Mouthfeel: Lighter than expected. The hop oils linger on the palate long after the beer is gone.

Overall: This is a solid brew, but I have had other amber ales that I find better, most notably Terrapin’s Big Hoppy Monster and Lagunitas’ Lucky 13. This beer is more on the lines of Troegs Hopback Amber. A good beer, but not the best I’ve had of this style.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2008 22oz in Liefmans glass.  Pours deep amber with low cream-colored head.  Plum, raisin, grass, alcohol, and pineapple nose.  Big sweet pine and crystal taste that brings me right back to One Horse Town at The Old Vic.  Some yeast character after the gulp.  And drink it.  "People who like this beer LOVE this beer."  --Jon Plise

Orangey caramel nose.  Amber reddish color with a thick frothy head that lasts forever.  Huge malty toffee sweetness, but excellently balanced with sharp bitterness.  Full body, big carbonation, smooth finish.  This was a fantastic huge malty beer with great balance!

22 oz bottle.  Very bready, pumpernickel like flavor with strong resiny hop bite at the finish.  I detected some sweetness as it warmed.  I can appreciate this as an innovative brew, but I found the taste a bit harsh and aggressive, like their Racer 5 IPA which Im not a big fan of either.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2009 Pours a deep, red-hued amber with a solid fluff of tan-brown head. Aroma is an appealing balance of PNW hops and grains with emphasis on chewy caramel, along with cotton candy and a touch of smoke.  Medium bodied, with alcohol imperceptible. Malt, caramel and hops wash over the palate. Bitter-sweet finish. Agressively hopped. Chocolate malt flavors develop after the beer warms and aerates. Good stuff!

Pours a dark copper brown with a tall, frothy beige head. Wonderful malt spectrum aroma, sweet sugary creamy caramel with subtle underlying hop scents. I love the play of the hops against the heavy upfront malts. The caramel creamy flavor at first blends instantaneously with the bitter hop finish. Hops bite just a little but give a nice herbal balance. Very tasty.
Bomber.  Pours nice amber with malty citrus aromas.  Great hop flavor and full bodied.  They never cease to amaze me as I’ve had this one many a time.  One of the best.
Pours brown red with a thick tan head. Nice citrus hop and caramel malt aroma. Flavor is more of those nice hops with a great malty background. Nice mouthfeel. Very nice beer.
The bottle conditioning here works beautifully. The hoppiest red ale I’ve ever had. California- we love you!

I appreciate the history - this is where they got their start, and all that jazz, but I’m just blown away with their other offerings to think that this is the beer that they are known for.  Its tasty, and packs a wonderful punch for a red ale, but it’s just not my thing.  Funny that I never tried it until I was actually at the brewery...

Pours a ruby red brown in color with a nice inch or so of off white head.  Smell is caramel malt and some hops.  Taste shows more of the hops, but there is enough malt to balance it out.  I’m also getting a bit of spice.  I’m really enjoying this beer.  Bittering and non-cloying on the tongue.

Bottle: Pours a deep brown with a rusty copper hue in the light and a thick, deep tan head that laces nicely. Has a great aroma of chewy malts- mild roast, some nutty character, sweet resiny notes, sweet dark bread/dough suggestions (almost rye like). Has a great creamy texture, silky palate. The flavor, as usual with Bear Republic, has a great malt depth- chewy dark bread (sweet rye), nutty, licorice/anise spiciness, cocoa, raisin?, sweet tobacco, and a semi-sweet resiny character which precedes the long, piny, dry finsh. Extremely rich, yet very balanced and highly drinkable. Awesome!
THE NICE AMBER RED COLOR IS DECIEVING. IT IS VERY HOPPY AND COMPLEX. A LITTLE ON THE BITTER SIDE. NOT YOUR NORMAL RED ALE.

Unfortunate name for this ale. Pours with a large, tight, light brown head that leaves good lacing. Hazy reddish brown body. Aroma of hops, caramel, flowery, mango, brown sugar and berries. Taste is caramel, light hops, sweet and fruity upfront with a light bitterness in the finish. Water like mouthfeel.

Bottle at Jerry’s. Brown-black with good, foamy beige head / Nose of sweet malt and caramel / Medium to full body, chewy, with just a touch of residual sweetness and good, hoppy finish / Flavors of caramel, dry hops, bittersweet chocolate, and light grapefruit notes / Should compare well to a dry stout.

WETHER or not a strong ale i could argue that one , but beyond contention is that this is FINE beer! wonderful hop aroma cold it is refreshing slick and berry sweet with holly berriies and pine needles and cones and hops in the finest sense surrounded by a wonderful yeastiness of the palate infused with a caramel honey vanilla sweetness so genuine as to make you understand you are fortunate. proves to me that you could name a brew belly lint" and so what its the beer that counts! disagree with more than a couple of beers with really high ratings wont disagree here exCept maybe this is a 99! FANTASTIC!

red rocket ale is a very good ale is it pale is it red is it a rocket i dont know but it taste really good aromatic hops slap you like a big red rocket with some pete and slight smoke orange and toffee

Brought from a Cali-trip, Thanks Gary.  Nice deep amber brown pour with a tight foam head.  Great grain, malt flavors and slight spice/citrus texture.  A nice hop and caramel blend sort of ties it all together.  It’s got layers and levels-complex and well done.

This beer was picked up at Green’s in Greenville, South Carolina recently, and the pour looked a lovely shade of burgundy, and was capped by a dense but smallish head.  The smell was citric hoppy, with undertones of red apples.  The taste was tart, bitter, slightly peaty, and very hearty.  The flavors were strong, but beautifully complimentary, and it was hard to put it down for typing this review.  The mouthfeel was creamy and soft, and the aftertaste showcased the flavors ina slow fade.  A beautifully crafted symphony, this was a very enjoyable experience while is lasted.

Tasted 8/9/08.  22oz bomber.  Filtered with an amber brown hue.  Layer of off-white head.  Cola and cocoa aromas with spicy undertones.  Medium bodied with a dry rye, hoppy finish.  Big malt character.  Solid body with a nice bitter flavor.  Mild fruity undertones with a hint of grapes.  Subtle vanilla flavor with toast and toffee flavors.  Mellows as it warms with the malts really smoothing out and losing some of the acidic bite.  The third pour finally gets to the gunk at the bottom of the bottle.  Solid hoppy/malty balance and melding.  Good palate roll.  Another solid offering from these guys!

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2009 355 mL bottle.  Translucent dark ruby-brown with a massive, thick foamy head.  Smells kinda like an APA, with lots of floral-citrus C-hops and sweet caramel malt.  Tastes kinda like an American version of a Scotch ale: nutty, burnt caramel, some alcohol.  No smokiness, though.  Bitter finish.  Medium to full body.  Kinda reminds me of Scotch-Irish Corporal Punishment.

On tap at Bear Republic. What a great strong ale.  This is on the lighter side for a strong ale, but a good choice seemingly as this is just plain delicious.   It’s interesting this used to be a scottish red ale, definitely shows, though a good deal of refined bitterness is there too.  Malt, bread, caramel, apple, grapefruit.  There is a lot going on.  I probably could have drank this all day, but only a taster for me.

Trade from Ross, thanks man!  Pours a rich reddish color with off-white head that leaves nice layers of cascading lace.  Aroma is of caramel malt, citrus hops, and light notes of dark fruit.  Taste the much the same.  A typical ASA but done well, much the same as Lagunitas brewing.

Beautiful aroma, lots of beautiful caramel aroma, with very fine resiny and citrussy hops.  flavor is the same accept I like the aroma better, I liked the interplay of citrus and caramel, but didn’t love it.  poured deep amber in color with an off white head that stayed throughout the whole drink.  medium bodied.  Really good.

And strong it is! Another winner from Bear Republic. Pours a dark dark reddish-opaque-copper colour with a nice billowing fluffy almond coloured head. Lacing is awesome- evidence! A reminder something grand was once in that glass. Aroma is genuine- cascade hops, pomegranate and pine. Taste is equally pleasent with dirrrrty, gritty, earthy, hoptastic flava- redruM, blindfolded majestic wonderchildren dancing carelessly throughout my early morning water sprinkler. Red rocket monster sprocket. woowee.

On tap at the Flying Saucer, Columbia. Pours a dark, murky reddish brown with a small head. After a sniff, the first thing that stokes my interest is crystal clear PNW hops. Remarkable clarity is achieved in the way of grapefruit and pine, though plenty of sweeter, bready scents such as biscuits and toffee are also present. The hops in the flavor are again delightful, but are equally balanced with hearty biscuits, caramel, maybe pumpernickel. Very nice!

Date: 08/18/08, 22 bottle
Aroma - Roasted grain and nuts, cark caramel, grapefruit, spruce
Appearance - Clear, deep ruby under a billowing light brown head that settles slowly, leaving bands of thick reticulated lace
Flavor - Solid malt sweetness in the entry, with a grapefruit zest bitterness close behind, the bitterness lingers, turning peppery several seconds after the swallow. Lots of flavor, and the hops really bite. 
Palate - Mediu to full body, medium carbonation, palate coating richness combines with a light astringency that results in a very satisfying mouthfeel. 
Overall - Very impressive in every way. Satisfying, layers of flavors, a very well crafted beet in every way.

From a 12ozer. Aroma full of hippy hops and fruit. Not what I was expecting from this crimson ber. Smells amazing. Mmmm...taste is equally impressive. Fruity citrus herbage...mmmm....much better than I expected, and I had high expectations. God bless America!
Big hopped-up American Red ale...citrus and pine and well balanced by a substantial caramel/toffee malt bottom...hints of biscuit and bread.  Excellent product and very repeatable!
22 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear dark brown with a thin tan head.  Mainly malt aroma.  A very smooth beer, sweet malt and some pine and citrus hops to balance.  A solid beer.
Had this bottle at the Sunflower cafe in Sonoma.  Fantastic beer, the bottle said it was a scotch ale that defies classification.  At any rate, it was hoppy and delicious.  Great beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark reddish copper color with a medium sized creamy beige head.  The head collapses to a lasting layer with decent lacing.  The aroma has a great combination of caramel malty goodness and citrus and floral hops.  The flavor exhibits many of the same qualities as the nose.  Up front there is a heavy dose of caramel malt and light hoppiness.  The hops become more noticable mid palate to the finish.  Citrus, herbal, and some pine make an appearance at some point.  The finish is on the dry side and has the perfect amount of bitterness to accompany the sweet malt.  This is a very solid beer that I will enjoy more of in the future.

Nice red pour, cream head.  Pretty floral aroma, slight maltiness.  Taste is much more malty than hops with slight caramel/toffee.  Enough hops to even it out, solid throughout, some lingering flavors in the finish, but pretty short.  Clean, quite drinkable.  The description does seem a bit off.  Enjoyed this though.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Thick tan head and a dark brownish color body. Hoppy and piny and roasy aromas all interlap into a wonderful medley of smells. Taste is a lot of hops at first, so it almost feels like you would be drinking an IPA, but then there is just so much more to it. Medium body. Really flowery. Really rich taste. Pretty swank beer.

Beautiful mahogony color with a small off-white head.  Aroma of floral pine hops and sweet malts. Flavor is the same - juicy pine and citrus hops plus caramel malt.  I agree with WISEGUY572, this is not a scottish ale at all.  Very good beer.
UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 The malt melts in your mouth, crazy smooth feel and flavor.  Over all, it is very restrained for a strong ale.  Well made and balanced.
Bottle. Poured more brown than red. Very hoppy aroma, slight citrus. Not much hops on the tongue. Mostly sweet malt. Kind of hard to pin down the flavor, still not sure how I really fell about it

I was not sure what to make of this, and the description provided by the brewer sets up false expectations.  Nothing about this is a Scottish ale.  It is a nice uniquely American hoppy red ale. Usual description for a red ... sweet caramel malts.  Usual description for an American hopped ale ... pine needles, orange peel, grapefruit. Usual description for a red, hazy red, good head.  But a Scottish ale, hopped to hell at 65+ IBU?  I dont think so!  I like it.  I probably would have rated it higher if they had simply said well hopped American red.

Smell is hoppy with a sweet citrus notes that get overcome by the pine aromas. Ruby red with a nice foamy cloud like head that sticks around for quite a while. Taste is predictably hoppy less of the citrus taste than I was expecting based on the smell, it is definately more inclined to the piney notes... A good beer but nothing too spectacular.

Poured a glowing murky red color with medium head. Aroma malty with nice balance of hops. Taste - caramel malt on palate along with cascade hops on lips. I really liked this brew, reminds me of Rogues St. Rogue Red Ale. A definite winner !!!

This is hard to pin down. The bottle says a hopped up Scottish Red which makes sense. The sweet malt hits first followed by the dry bitter hops. Nice balance of a complex beer. Looks great and smells great too.

I shared a bottle of this a while back with tjthresh. I am not sure if I rated it and didn’t ever enter it or if I just didn’t bother. 22oz bottle bought right here on the KS side of the metro. Served in a smokestack chalice. A fair amount of sweet caramelly malt and fragrant, piney hops are present in the aroma, along with a little chocolate. Big bodied, but nicely balanced at the end. The flavor is more malt-centric at first, showcasing the caramelly malts, but is quickly followed by piney and earthy hops that bring a nice amount of bitterness. The finish is lingering bitterness. It is good, but it just seems like a little bit much of everything, sometimes I like the hops to shine and sometimes I like the malt to shine.
A pretty damn good red. Creamy head, red hops with a solid IBU, goes down quick. Shows how a mix of European and Continental hops is a marriage of love.

Aroma:  Low levels of dark malt with some sweetness,fruity and earthy hop notes.

Appearance:  Good clarity, darker red color with ok head retention and lacing

Flavor:  Sweet maltiness with pervading earthy hop flavor, finishes with substantial hop bitterness

Palate:  Medium bodied, bitterness is high, chalky finish

Overall Impression:  Tastes like an aged IPA.  Not malty enough for a Scotch Ale, not hoppy enough for an IPA (bitterness is there, needs more hop flavor/aroma).  Ok beer with nothing that stands our, not particularly memorable
Pours brown with a light brown head.  Smells of citrus, hops, and earthy tones.  Pine, dirt and earth flavor.  Bitter hop finish with a slight sweetness.

Brown/cherry color, dark & beautiful. Head builds up, then just hangs there like a runny nose. Hoppie aroma. Sweet grapefruit also tickles the nostrils. Bitter is the 1st taste I get. Thats good. Me like the bitter. Smooth yet light texture. Smells like it tastes. Yum! Taste lingers on the after exhales. Nice. Not bad. Not the best.
22 oz bottle. A true redhead. Hops with a little caramel, malt balance. Lingering hops aftertaste with grapefruit. Another really good beer from a brewery that takes its mission seriously.

I am surprised how much hop flavor and citrus comes though in the flavor.  A thin lacing of foam covers this burnt red colored brew.  The color is very nice.  It has a very nice dry hoppy flavor, but also has some nice roasted coffee flavor like a good porter.  This beer is quite good.

22 oz bottle. Nice, deep ruby color with a thin tannish white head. Low carbonation. Not much interest in the nose. The beer tastes a little toasty and bitter. It seemed light-bodied, like a decent session beer, but at 6.8% it is a little strong to drink too many. I wasn’t impressed or dissapointed.

BR is one of my favorite brew makers.  I like everything coming from these craftsman.  I have had several of these over time and come to realize that this beer is an pumped up ESB.  It’s well rounded and balanced, not overly complex, and highly sessionable.  Aroma of sweetened hops, pours a weathered penny before it turns green. Flavor is strong caramalized malts with significant bittering on the finish, but not IIPA bitter, smooooth, subtle and lasting.  The beer covers the mouth and is medium dry as it melts away and leaves a hint of bitter.  Nicely constructed brew, and up there in my book! BR rocks with this bulked up ESB.

22 oz...dark amber with a thick foamy tan head...malt and grassy hop aroma, some sweet citrus...initial pine and citrus taste with a smooth bitter bite...lightly sweet semi bitter finish...refreshing brew....very easy drinking...theres a lot going on with this beer without too much confusing complexity...great beer to break into after a 3 day break

Very hoppy aroma. A deep red/amber color with not too much head when poured. Almost looks like cherry coke. Smooth, strong taste with some non citrus fruit and malt flavor to it. not so sure about the cinnamon taste some others found. Taste was great though and it does not linger. If you like hop stuffed beers, i would definitely try this one. descent price too. picked up the bottle for $3.99

Bottle.  This deep, dark, ruby brown ale is huge on flavor.  There is a nice hoppy zing, warming alcohol, and toasty coffee and burnt chocolate notes.  The bite is long and hard staying right through the finiish of this beer.

Brown and sedimented with a big, dimpled tan head. Aroma is sweet, brown and hoppy with tangerine notes. Taste is roasty and nutty with a sweet and slightly cloying edge. Solid bittering component stays with you, in addition to a mildly vegetal flavoring. $5/22oz

This beer is a gem, fantastic in all categories. Pours an opaque mahogany/dark brown color with a thick tan head and plenty of lacing. Aroma is a strong blend of grapefruit, citrus and burnt malts including hints of strawberries and black licorice. Sharp, malty mouth feel that quickly becomes pleasantly bitter. Full bodied with a smooth harshness. Intense and complex flavors with an upfront hop medley of pine and citrus. Musty-sweet toasted malts develop into a complexity of plums, coffee, toast, and molasses. Then the hops show up again in a longing aftertaste. This beer is a great marriage of styles, and it’s done in a wonderful fashion.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2011 Pours a deep amber-brown color with a frothy head that fades to patches.  The aroma is smoky and a little fruity with traces of caramel malt and resin hops.  The aroma is somewhat subtle but enough going on.  The flavors up front are roasted malts and oak with bitter fruity hops hitting the palate on the back end providing a nice well-rounded taste.  Gets a bit more toasty as it warms.  Very nice and easy drinking.  Re-rate 9/27/08 courtesy of zythum.  Not a whole lot that needs to be added.  The smoked-roasted malty flavor with a generous dose of bitter hops make this thing really tasty.  A couple minor adjustments in the ratings.  I really like this one.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2008 A burgundy beer with light-brown head that slightly laces.  Aroma of hops.  Medium bodied beer with hops and malty caramel hints.  Bitter finish.  This is just a damn tasty beer that will satisfy the hop requirements of any hophead.

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in McKinney, TX.
Purs a nice clear very deep red/orange with nice beige head, very good retention and laced glass. Aroma of obvious hops and malt. Flavor is semi-sweet with nice hoppy grapfruit notes. Mouthfeel is nice, medium body with medium carbonation.....this is a very nicely balanced strong ale.....GOOD!!!
Clear, copper, effervescent brew with average beige head. Aroma is malty sweet corn syrup. Nice punch of bitterness, woody with alcohol undertones, dry finish.

bottle purchased in Houston, TX.  average fizzy tan head into clear amber body with good lacing present.  aromas of lingering moderate citrus hops and light malts (that seem to present themselves more as my palate adjusts to the hops).  flavor is moderate bitter throughout with a touch of sweetness.  lively carbonation.  dry sticky mouthfeel.  long finish duration.  good american strong.

I have to remember that if a craft beer says "red" in the label it most likely has nothing in common with an Irish Ale.  Red Rocket Ale is based on a Scottish Ale, caramel and smoked malts make room for plenty of C-Hops.  High on the bitterness level, with a citrus undertone.   Alcohol may be lower than what some people think an American Strong Ale should be, but I think Red Rocket came together rather well.
Hoppy with a cinnamon note.  Dark red color with a creamy head.  Some nutty malts in the flavor.  Some similarities to Arrogant Bastard ale.  Good stuff.

Bottle, Thanks to KegBear for another fabulous housewarming beer The aroma is incredibly malty and yet there is some hop that is very evident. That taste is great  malt with a lot of hops crashing through later. There is also some fruit coming through but not much. It finishes smooth and leaves the aftertaste of a caramel apple on the back of the throat.Buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Aroma is VERY malty, mainly caramel malts.  The appearance is a ruby red, persistent white head.  It certainly looks like a scotch ale.  The flavor is malty sweet, with a reasonable balance of hops.  The hops impart a little citrus quality to the taste.  The palate is mainly bittering hops, which tend to linger.  The mouthfeel is a medium consistency.  Decent for an ASA.

Poured medium brown with a touch of red, thick bubbly head that left a lot on the side of the glass. Toasted malt aroma came first, followed by leafy hops. Flavors of caramel and toasted malts work off the hops bitterness to make a very complex and pleasant flavor profile; the sweetness wins out. Medium to full body with a very smooth and creamy mouthfeel, minimal carbonation, and nice malty aftertaste.
Poured a dark red color with an off white head. Aroma was somewhat maltier than most asa’s, but with a hint of hops. Flavor was more floral with a nice bitter finish.

Deep brown with no head.  Sweet notes come off as well as subtle hop touches.  Interesting spiced quality starts the palate which evolves into a chocolatey malty complexity.  Not sure what they were going for, as the beer goes in a number of directions, but it all works well.  Quite tasty.

Pours a very dark rich ruby red with a foamy, tan, and very persistent head.  Thick lacing on the glass.  Malt and berries on the nose.  Flavor is strong of hops with coffee and chocolate notes readily apparent.  More subtle notes of berries and nuts.  A bitter, hoppy finish reminiscent of an IPA, with a little coffee underneath.  A tasty wonderfully balanced brew.

650 ml. Clear, deep garnet with a three-finger, creamy head that lasts forever. Aroma is a luscious blend of caramel, molasses, citrus, earthy resin, and cocoa. Flavor is nearly the same, but slightly heavier on the citrus-resin, especially on the finish. Medium-heavy body is almost smooth, and astringently dry.

Thanks to Bear Republics expanded distribution I found this at the localCanals.  Clear reddish copper pour under a tall dense light brown head.  Aroma of caramel, citrus and toasted malt. Crisp malty flavor with touches of chocolate and roasted nuts.  Good helping of piney hops lets you know this one hails from the "laid back" coast.  Full textured body and a dry and somehow satisfyingly metallic finish.  One of the few legitimately good amber ales out there.

From a 22oz. bottle purchased locally. Aroma is malty, fruity and hoppy all rolled together. Color is a deep ruby with a tan head. Flavor is malty and sweet up front followed by hop bitterness and a toasty, nutty breadcrust malt with cittrusy hop flavor in the finish. Full bodied, finished pretty dry for the gravity and a little lingering hop flavor and bitterness. A fantastic over-the-top amber/red ale.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 Half a glass offoam, half a glass of brown, pronounced "red", beer, pronounced "ale". The name just conjours up bad images. Where they thought they were going with this?... Anyway, aroma is very good, slight malt with a nice hop dominance and a bitter end. The taste is , well the whole thing is realy something to revel in. It starts off smooth and almost malty, and turns to a smooth hoppy flavor with an aromatic hop note. Its like a great smooth IPA with the texture of a Scottish Ale. This beer is better than most youve had. The only comparable thing I know is Lagunitas Lucky 13, which is a cunt hair better. And, you know, so to speak, I had to come back and add that the head on this beer just does not quit, and where else can you find that kind of enjoyment? Ok, thats it. Here I am again. I had to come back  once more and say that this beer has the best head on any beer youve drank since the moon rose and sat more times than you can remember.

A dark cloudy red/brown/black with a tan cream head, beautiful lacing and retention.

Smells of floral hops and malts.

A roasted malt flavor is soon dominated with a crispy hop finish. Very hoppy in the end.

THis is a somewhat heavy beer that leaves the mouth a little dry.

If I wasnt so buzzed, I wouldnt be opposed to having another.

Serving type: bottle
On tap at Papago. Foamy, red and roasted. Not much aroma, but theres a good deal of malts and roastiness in the nose. Lots of bittering hops in this one.

12 oz. pours clear reddish amber with big off white head. aroma is citrus and floral hops. mouthful is smooth with caramel and back with nice hoppy bite. very nicely balanced malty hop experience. WOW

Pours a deep brown color with ruby edges and a thick, tan head. Aroma is dominated by floral hops. Taste is a big hoppy sledgehammer up front, and when fades out the malts come through, with a slightly sweet ending. Kinda reminded me of a hoppier Arrogant Bastard. Definitely worth a buy.

A great strong ale. First off, this beer gets a whopping 5/5 for appearance because it is the only beer Ive seen that was neon amber. Ill type that again. NEON AMBER, BITCHES. Great flavor of citrus hops with lots of underlying apples to it. I taste apples everywhere in this brew, though they arent sweet, its like green apple skin. Very nice ale.

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor. Dark brown with red tint and large creamy beige head. Smokey but big bittering hop aroma. Big bittering hops, dry peeted malt, nice and dirty. Medium and creamy body. Smoky and nice.

bottle thanks to 17th floor. beautiful deep red garnet pour with thinnish tan head, some nice sticky lacing. piney hops, caramelized sugars, mild smoke. Pretty big sweetness on the flavor, mild smokiness, big pine conflicts with the smoke a bit. A little plasticy, but not bad. Mild fruit coming out a bit. Not bad, but a little off.

Pours deep clear mahogany with a thin beige froth.  Big rich malty, light smoke and piney hop aroma, slightly vinous.  Burnt crystal malt, burnt brown sugar,  bitter piney hops.  Bold, robust. Tingles on the finish, very bitter.  Medium body with fizzy carbonation, slightly sticky.
dark red with tan head.  flavor is a strong malt component with some obvious crystal in there.  some hop bitterness but nothing overstated, yet well balanced.  a good beer
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 Dark red body with a thin head. Aroma of hops. Nice, thick body. Even malt to hops ratio. Great lacing.
Bottle.  Pours amber red with a thin head.  Nose is sweet malt, hops, pine, honey, and caramel.  Flavor is that with a salty sweet finish.

Pours a deep mahogany with a nice, dense head that lingers quite a while leaving very good lacing.  This is a seriously nice looking beer.  Smell is a nice balance of sweet caramel malts and subtle floral and citrus hop aroma with oranges, grapefruit and a touch of grass.  Also a bit of dark fruit in the background, maybe raisins.  Taste starts with a big bready malt flavor, smooth and sweet and thick with caramel malts.  The hops are right behind the malt though with more pine present than I get on the smell along with the grapefruit of the citrus hops leaving a crisp and slightly bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied with strong carbonation.  Crisp but smooth.  Drinkability is good on this one but the hop bitterness and heavy body would keep me from drinking too many of these in a sitting.

bottle - Pours dark amber with a one finger tan head.  It smells of caramel malt and some citrus accented hops.  The flavor has some good, crisp moderately strong hops that are well balanced by the bold caramel malts.  Its an interesting and enjoyable brew without being truly outstanding.

Dark, dark red with a nice fluffy light brown head that leaves intricate lacing on the side of the glass. Smells like hops and some malty caramel. 

Nicely hoppy beer that brings the hops but doesnt obliterate your mouth with them. Defiantly more hop than malt flavor coming out in this red ale. Nice beer, a bit of thick stickiness does bring the hops down a bit, but this is a hop laden fool. 

Good beer overall, on the lighter" side for an American Strong Ale. Nice once it cools down after a hot day. Not my favorite style, but a nice beer.

~Pours a dark red colour, very nice colour when held to the light, head is small, but frothy
~Strong scent of hops and sweet caramel malts .
~Nice sweet flavor with plenty of bitter hops and a tinge of pine.
~Feels a bit sticky. Ends dry and bitter.
~Good tasting beer.

Bottle: Brown w/ a light brown head. Piney hops dominate the aroma. Flavor is of grapefruity hops & a bit of sweet malt. Generally this is a hop monster, but has enough sweet that it doesnt murder you.

Bottle:  Poured a red/brown color with not too much head.  The aroma was sweet and malty, grapefruit and caramel.  The flavor was nice and smooth, with some hoppiness but not too overpowering.  Finished with a hint of grapefruit or pineapple.  Overall, a very good beer!

Bomber. Served in a trappist glass. Pours a dark, rich mahogoney with a slightly beige, small head. Nice hop character with charamel malt present. Finished dry. A bit light on the palate. This is a pretty good beer, but a bit boring. Not as complex and full as other ASAs.

Bottle. Pours brown with a beige head. Sweet aroma with citrusy hops, orange and caramel. Medium body. Flavor is also a little sweet with bittering hops hitting the palate first, followed by grapefruit and caramel. Nice finish which leaves a light lingering bitterness.

Aroma: Malts smell like candied nuts (namely, almonds and cashews) with a tart, fruity overtone... orange marmalade comes to mind. Theres also the faintest hint of brown sugar. Hops impart a crisp, leafy, piney, slightly grassy aroma. I think I also detect a slight vegetable odor, similar to celery. Overall, this reminds me very much of autumn.

Appearance: Deep, dark ruby-brown, kind of similar to oolong tea. Head is tall and resilient, and similar in color to apple butter.

Flavor: Delicious. So well-balanced. Big hop flavor, but the toasty malt makes a strong statement as well. Theres also a subtle, fruity vinous current running through this beer, and the alcohol is also quite pronounced, but not overwhelmingly so. Extremely dry, lingering finish with a bite of alcohol.

Palate: So creamy! I think the mouthfeel is the best thing about this beer. Its hard to describe, but its wonderful... big, thick, and chewy, but still airy and refreshing.

Overall: This beer is great fun to drink. Bold and flavorful, but goes down smooth.

Tastes almost like a supped up amber ale with some very nice hoppy flavor countering the expected maltiness.  Overall this is a pretty good beer. Not as interesting as some in the style but perhaps the most drinkable American Strong Ale I have had.

22 oz bomber from Spirits RB. Pours a deep dark brown with slight red highlights and an average size spongey light beige head. Aroma of pineapple hops and caramel malt that is nicely balanced. Medium body with a slightly creamy feel and nice carbontation. Flavor picks up some of the pineapple hops, caramel malts and adds a touch of malts. Nice ber that is easily sippable.  Drank this one whilce chatting and watching Zombie Strippers, if Zombie Strippers doesnt make a ber moemorable then it probably wasnt worht remembering in the first place.
Bottle purchased at The Wine King in wall... Poured a nice crisp dark red color with a tan head. Good flavor that went down smooth.

22 oz.  Im not sure why I havent rated this yet...  Dark reddish-brown pour with a fine yellow looking head.  Crisp aroma - grapefruit and floral hops, sticky malt notes, and some alcohol.  Smells great.  Flavor is well balanced but less dynamic and complex than the aroma.  Finish is bitter but a tad watery.
Pours dark red , biiter sweet.  Tasted from bomber at cellar temperture. chalky finish.
Draft. Ruby red color with massive lacing. Light malt citrus hop aroma. Taste  was the same with thin bitter finish.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 Sampled on draft at the Rivertowne Pub this beer poured a dark red color with a small khaki head. The aroma was moderately strong floral and fruity hops. The flavor was strong floral and fruity hop - a bit harsh at that - with a nutty caramel malt undertone. The finish was dominated with the hops.  A bit dry. Decent but nothing extraordinary.

Tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee.

Great Hoppy flavor and aroma. a good amount of carbonation slight bitter finish

Bomber via dkachur (thanks!), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Deep chestnut/mahogany, clear?, with a moderate tan head.
  
Aroma:  Spicy dried fruits, some pine and grapefruit from the hops, dark bread crust, a bit of sweet caramel and toffee malt that becomes much darker  like a med. roasted coffee, some faint notes of warm spices  ginger and allspice mainly.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body and very soft, silky carbonation give a velvety, pillowy impression.  Yes, I referred to a beer as pillowy.
  
Flav.:  The malts come through as much darker with burnt sugar and some hints of black coffee and dark chocolate, a bit of fruitiness, the hops is more on the piney end of the spectrum; on swallowing, a bit fat shot of bitterness that stays with you, dry and leaves a touch of earth and some burnt sugars.  

Dang, I like riding this rocket.  That sounds a bit funny.  I dont care.

This brew poured a dark redish brown. I feel like making a paragraph devoted solely to the head. The head was completely out of control (in a good way). It was massive and refused to back down. The smell was of grain, hints of coffee and had a very hopped up smell in general. The taste was also very hopped up. Slighty bitter from begining to end. The mouthfeel was fairly thick with a good amount of carbonation. It coated the inside of my mouth and stuck around for a while. This beer was fairly drinkable, definitely one to sip on but all in all a good brew.
Amber with tan head.  Aroma of caramel and hops.  Taste of caramel, sugar, and citric hops.  Long bitter finish.

Bottle purchased in Spokane. DO NOT shake or pour out the sediment! Hoppy nosed red IPA. Dark amber with red tint. Fair head. Chewy malt delicious IPA. Much better before I poured in the sediment which dirtied up a great beer and added a chocolate finish.

Whoa!  Didnt know what to expect, bought this on a whim.  VERY hoppy, but characterized well.  Bitter and intense, with some sour notes mixed in as well.  Nicely crisp and dry.  Well done, tastes like a "hopped"-up red ale.
Dark amber pour with a creamy tan head that lasts and leaves some nice lacing.  Lots of caramel malts in the aroma.  Similar flavor.  Bitter hoppy finish.  Nice.
A well- balanced, creamy beer.  Pours a nice amber, small head, with a malty aroma.  Lots of caramel and hop flavor.
Pours a clear brown with a light brown head. A little sweet but quite dry. Very hoppy with caramel aromas and toasted grains. Piney hops. Medium to full bodied. Medium carboanation. Dry finish. Good.

Pours dark, dark red with a thin white head.  Aromas of bourbon and tart raspberry, with a bit of an herbal hop bouquet.  Huge hop flavor up front with a hint of herbaceous in the middle and a fleeting taste of dark malts.  Finishes long but very clean and hoppy.  Could use a bit more malt sweetness to balance all the hops.

Poured a very dark amber color with a tinge of orange. The head was a nice creamy tan color that went down rather quickly. There was nice lacing however on the glass. The aroma was very subtle. The taste was slightly dry with a little bit of a hop bite. The flavor became a little bitter on the finish. The bitterness was on the mild side, which made for an enjoyable finish.
220z. bottle, perfect head that looks like whipped cream, dark red amber color with a malty taste and slight scotch undertones, hoppy finish
UPDATED: SEP 18, 2008 Yummy sweet, creamy, malty, dry with a slight hoppy bite.  Light color with a tan head.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 Beautiful deep, clear amber pour with a thin tan head that faded quickly. Nose is sweet with malt and a bit of plum. Flavor is also sweet and malty with a touch of dryness. Smooth finish

Poured a cloudy light-mud color with a thin-medium head. Thick, but not too thick.  Easy going down.  Loved drinking a red ale with this much hops.  Sweet and fruity, a pleasure to drink.  Not as hardcore as some of Bear Republics others, but still definitely a Bear Republic.
Amber color.  Thick white head.  Hoppy aroma.  Caramel malt flavor followed by a citrus bitterness of hops.  Tasty.

This isnt an IPA? Seriously? Sweet, huge caramel malt backbone with a bready essence that serves as a sturdy framework for the a monster hop line-up that really dominates the drink. Floral and citrusy with a slight grassy bit. Fantastic stuff.
A strong thick beer with a fantastic aroma. Initial taste is great, full flavored and very balanced. The aftertaste is a little strong and bitter. Otherwise a great beer!
Upfront sweet malt yet finishs bitter which leave the mid-palate full of citrus notes.  A sold full bodied beer with tiny bubbles.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful translucent redish brown with a small grey head. Nose is strong peaty, piney hops with a hint of sweet malts. Attack is sweet and earthy/peat, with a clean bitter finish. Really nice beer!

From bottle. Fruit, hops in the aroma. Great ruby red colour with an off white head. Hop flavour, little sweet. decent ale with plenty of flavour, little smoked hints in there with fruit. Very enjoyable ale, possible sesh beer if not so high %.

A very enjoyable beer.  A nice amber to red color, not to intense.  Hop aroma was there but not overpowering.  Slightly citrus like.  Good malt flavor to balance out the hop bitterness. Not sewwt not dry, well balanced. Excellent head and good carbonation.

Bottle from Whole Foods in Charlottesville. Pours a deep brown color with a little bit of a red twinge. Little head but decent lacing. Aroma is green apples and brown sugar. Hops are very assertive in this one. Malt backbone almost balances this one out, but falls a bit short. A bit metallic tasting at times, but overall this is very drinkable.

22 oz. bottle poured a mahogany red in color with a nice looking thick head of light tan froth. carbonation is steady leading to an aroma of wet hops, pepper, pine, sweet malt, and a woodsy smell. taste is really red ipa like but has a pleasant coating mouth feel. flavors have plenty of resinous hops, sweetness balancing, and a heftier dose of malt then expected here. at times the hops seem to lead and then a few sips later the malts come across. some citrus underlying and finishes on the dry side with some bitterness from both the hops and malt.

On tap at the Bockown.  Big tan head with a rolling tap pour!  Darker burnt orange brown. Has a mild sweet candy aroma. Initially quite mil;d then a sharpness from the bitter hops develops. Medium top of mouth and back throat bitter personality. Sweet to acrid in 30 seconds flat. Leaves a lingering soap finish on the palate.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 22oz bottle.   Opaque deep brown with an eggshell head.   Rich malts and hops, with a slight smokiness in the aroma.   Malty, fruity flavor, with caramel and a bitter and hoppy finish.  Full body with smooth carbonation.   Pretty nice malts to support those hops, and pretty drinkable.

Pours a nice shade of red, somewhere between garnet and mahogany. An inch of tan head caps this beer, leaving streaks of sticky lace as it reduces to a halo.

Aroma is quite hoppy. Lots of tangy citrus and toasty sweetness in about a (respective) 65-35 proportion.

The hops are a little more toned down in the flavor. The balance is nearly perfect between the citrus and the toasty caramel. The hop bitterness comes through in the finish.

Lively carbonation, medium body, sticky and long finish. Easily drinkable.

Pours an opaque deep amber colour with a sudsy, frothy tan head that has moderate retention and spotty lacing. The aroma is rich with pine, caramel, grapefruit citrus and vinous malts. There is also a peppery overtone accompanying the nose. Initially, the flavour is dominated with bright citric notes and toffee sweetness. The aftertaste though brings out a spicy bite that is reminiscent of rye malt. The finish is dry, roasty and somewhat coffee-like. The palate is medium bodied and sticky in texture, especially in the finish.

After it was poured into a tulip glass, since it was all that was available it foamed right up with a thick head that thined right out. The color is a dark brown with some spotted laceing along the sides of the glass. The nose is of bitter hops and roasted malt with some sweetness, mainly from light fruits. As you take a sip the flavor hits you like a train of dark and light fruit mixed with hops and roasted malt. You can really taste the hop bitterness comboined with these dark fruit flavor along the side walls of your mouth. The finish is very light with fruit and hop acidity that sticks in your mouth like a stick of gum.

pours quite dark for an american strong. smells hops all the way, tastes equally hoppy. it tingles on the tongue, grapefruit, and grass, very fresh. very in your face. 
good stuffs.

Pours a dark red/brown with a tall tan head that faded slow and left a trail. Smells of hops but without the citrus kick, tempered by subtle malt hints. Tastes hoppy, immediately followed by smooth nutty malts and finishing on a bitter hop note. Excellent thick cream mouthfeel. A delicious beer to start 08 St. Patricks day off with.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2008 Poured a very attractive reddish/brown color with fluffy white head that hung around for a while. Aroma was citrusy hops with a bit of alcohol coming through. Flavor was citrusy and floral hoppiness. Malt flavor is also there but is dominated by the hops. Mouthfeel is great and this left nice lacing on the glass. Drinkability is good. This is one fine ale.

This was a dark red ale with a hoppy  and very unusal but good finish and flavor,there are all kinda of things going on in this beer and it was nice and malty and reminded me more of an ipa but it did have that malty red ale taste,overall a good beer.CHEERS!
Bottle: pours a dark red with a thin tan head, aroma of floral hops and a touch of citrus, taste is hoppy up front with a smooth, malty, dry finish.  Solid brew.

Bottled
Dark ruby/amber color, steady creamy beige head, lace. Piney-hoppy aroma. Medium-bodied. Piney-hoppy flavor backed with chewie malts. A bit yeasty. Hoppy aftertaste. More like an IPA than "red ale".

Aug. 2007 - These guys make good stuff.  Sweet aroma of malts, kind of tinny.  Dark amber pour with almost no head of lacing.  Flavor of sweet malts (caramel and irish red type malts), loads of english type hops.  Dry flavor, but lots of it.  Nice fully creamy mouthfeel.  Nice one again from BR.

22 oz. brown bomber bottle. No freshness date seen. Poured out a deep red color, with a sticky tan colored head. Very aromatic. Aromas are of piney hops, some citrus, sweet malts, toffee. Flavors include toffee, citrus, piney hops, sweet malts, some sugar. Thick mouthfeel, rich and chewy. Finished sweet & hoppy. Decent beer overall, makes me wish Id had it before now.

The BrewKeeper in North Ridgeville, Ohio, has this on tap and I tried it for the first time. Very smooth, with a distinct malt flavor. Not very bitter or dreadfully hoppy. Although I love hoppy beers, this didnt taste overwhelming. The color is a cross  between caramel looking and amber. Very delicious

Pours with a frothy, three finger thick, lightly browned, tan colored head.  The beer is a dark, concentrated plum, amber hued color that shows a brilliantly clear, cranberry hued color when held up to the light.  This beer is quite hop focused, I dont get any malt at all upon first inspection of the aroma.  Aromas of grapefruit, freshly zested lemon peel, bergamot, tangelo, orange zest and some light pine / herbal notes.  The malt is here, it does in fact play an integral role here with aromas of richly caramelized malt and toasty browned biscuit notes.

This beer has a chewy body, that has a medium heft to it, yet it is not very sweet.  The ample hop character and darker malt notes seem to inhibit the malt sweetness.  Bracingly bitter from the get go, the biting hop character lingers on through to a long finish.  The hop flavors here are influenced heavily by the lack of sweetness; the vibrant fruit notes of the aroma are fairly subtle here, instead flavors of pine, menthol, and a deep herbal note are what is most noticeable.  There is some light notes of grapefruit, and perhaps a touch of orange towards the end where a touch of malt sweetness is able to come through.  The finish has the hop bitterness as well as a sharp, herbal hop astringency and even a touch of toasted, darker grain note.  The malt character, while clearly a supporting role, adds a nice dimension to this brew; toasty malt and bread-like flavors as well as a richly caramelized, yet not sweet malt character.

A pretty tasty brew, I wish that there was a bit more residual malt sweetness to this brew; a solid citrus hop character would have been really nice.  This is actually slightly tart as a result of the lack of sweetness; this is not bone dry though, there is just not enough malt sweetness to stand up to the hops.
Lots of hop flavor for it being a red ale. Some citrus but mostly bitter hops. Finished rather dry and harsh.
Aroma is a bit weak but good; sweet malt, hops, berries. Palate is a bit thin. "Tangy" hops indeed, orange citrus. Finishes pretty dry.

Pours a caramel tone with a beige head that leaves lacing.  Aroma is hoppy, but a nice almost chewy malts presence is definitely felt.  It definitely doesnt have the overwhelming hops of other American Strong Ales Ive had, but they are felt.  The malts take the cake though and leave you with a moderately dry finish.  Really good.
22 oz bomber.  Pours a dark murky amber with a medium sized beige head.   Aroma of tangy citrus and hops.  Taste of tangy citrus hops.  Nothing special here.
This 22oz bottle poured to a reddish amber color with a thin tan head.Mild hop aroma with more malt aromas than hops.Nice tasting,caramel ,malt and hops with medium body with a nice finish.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008 This is not a beer for lightweights, nor for hop wimps. Pours a clean dark brown with reddish tint. Minimal head, some lacings. First sip is a big hit of grapefruit citrus pine needle hops. Slight sweet malt taste as the bitterness subsides. I think this brew is more like a double IPA with a bit more malt than typical. I cant see having this as a session ale but it was an enjoyable tasting. Will most likely enjoy this with a meal next time. Well recommended.
22oz.bottle. Poured a hazy light red. Small head. some cherry flavors present and also surprisingly hoppy! Overall i enjoyed this one.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: 750 mL bottle.  Clear brown pour with a reddish tint.  Heavy malt aroma with a slight hint of hops.  Delicious, creamy malty flavor.  Nice hoppy finish.  Really good.

Pours a hazy chestnut red/brown.  Small tan head dissapates quickly.  Aroma is hops, hops, hops.  Oh, and a  nice malty sweetness.  Flavor is deep cherry maltiness and big hops with it.  Medium to heavy body goes well with the high hops and stong malt backbone.  A really nice beer.

Bomber courtesy of lb4lb. Pours a deep reddish-brown with lots of fine sediment and a rocky, beige head. The nose is of unfrosted sugar cookies and light caramel with bright, citric hops, in support. Medium-bodied and creamy-soft, transitioning to a toasted and bitter, hoppy finish. Initially sweet and malty, the flavor swings over to a bright, bitter hopped finish: pine and citrus notes combine with a toasty, sweet malt note that lingers long after the swallow. This is a solid brew and one that would pair exceptionally well with burgers and/or other pub fair. Thanks for sending this one, Deniz!
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2012 Re rate via bottle. Poured reddish brownish, pretty clear.  Very floral aroma, but strong maltiness also in the taste. A noticeable beer.

Red Rocket is a deep rusty red ale thats a bit hazy.  The head is gracious-- the color of coffee ice cream.  It leaves sheets of foam on the glass.  The aroma is loud and proud: Cascade hops, in all their grapefruitnpine glory.  There is a light roastiness and something like fresh baked bread.  Nuts and sour candy are in the nose.  The hops pretty much dominate the aroma.  It smells fresh.  It is soft and foamy in the mouth.  It starts with a billowy medium-full body and then turns the mouth dry and crispy at the end.  It makes me take another swig.  Man.  This is loud and proud; bright and bitter.  The hops are solid and juicy.  Its really a lot like grapefruit juice.  The malt lays low and emerges with an alcohol rumble at the end.  It the thunder to the lightning hops in this beer.  The bitterness is incredibly smooth.  Damn fine.  Its been so long since Ive tasted this (constant pitchers at Zeitgeist in SF back in the day) and its been too long.  It seems like a Double IPA to me, but I think that term is newer than the beer.  Great example of the West Coast IPA-ish pale ale.  This is heavy session ale.  It will wreck your taste buds and your liver, but it will coddle you while it does so.

Earthy caramel aroma, I also pick up some hops. Clear dark brown thick fluffy head.
Tangy caramel flavor with a good floral hops, and I also pick up some smoke in the finish. Clean and refreshing. Palate is full and smooth.

clear garnet color with a light tan head, nice lacing. Med. strong floral hop nose with a whiff of caramel. Big carbonation with a lively mouthfeel. Mildly sweet caramel malts with a good dose of hops to finish. Tastes like a watered down version of Hop Rod here. 8205
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 22 oz bottle.  Pours a copper brown with a thin, off-white head which lingered and gave lacing.  The smell is grassy hops and some roast malt.  Taste is definitely a strong ale with the malt strong but a hoppy kick.  Mouthfeel is medium with carbonation and a bitter hop aftertaste.

A dark brown pour with hints of red. Light off white head and lace. Toasted malt with hints of molasses on the nose. Flavor of rich maltiness that rolls into a huge bittering finish. Medium bodied with carbonation that is a bit aggressive for my taste. Solid beer that has a very surprising hop bitter.
22 oz. bomber.  Poured beautiful deep amber with fluffy off-white head.  Splotches of lacing.  Light citrus nose.  Flavor of sweet malts and grapefruit.  A bit of a thin mouthfeel.

22 oz bottle pours a deep brown color with read highlights.  Almond color fluffy head covers the beer.  A malty, sweet aroma with some smoke in there as well.  A grassy hops aroma compliments the malt aroma.  Bread like mouthfeel and dry when you swallow.  Bitterness does not come in until you swallow.  Some fruit flavor like raisin and prune appear too.  Another great beer from the Bear Republic.  I just wish we could get more in MD.

Pours a nice hazy auburn color with a long lasting beige head. Aroma of citrus and earthy hops accompanied by sweet, fruity darker malts. Awesome balance, as it is pretty hoppy yet sweet and fruity at the same time. Citrus and earth make way for some nice fruity maltiness. Lingering bitterness accompanies and exceptionally smooth drinking body.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Thanks to lb4lb for this one. Bottle, 22 oz bomber. Pours a very dark ruby-brown. Cotton-like beige head. Lacing permeates. Aroma is sweet citrusy malts, chocolate, caramel. Flavor is light chocolate malts, tangy citrus, bitter hops. Well balanced. Sweet, slightly sticky. Enjoyable.

This slightly creamy red ale has a great head that actually has persistent structure, almost like a head on a root beer float.  Unfortunately, it blocks a lot of the aroma, at least until you drink it down.  The color is a deep brownish red.  This beer has an excellent balance of malts and hops, with lots of flavor and a nice smooth finish.  This is the first beer Id tried from Bear Republic but Ill be keeping my eye out for other offerings.
