pours a deep, reddish brown with an offwhite, foamy head.  aroma is very pleasing with caramel hoppiness.  I took a punch with the flavor.  the hops are strong and on the bitter side.  other flavors of grapefruit, caramel, and hops.  very fresh.
22 oz. bottle.  hazy reddish brown pour with offwhite thick head.  bold nose with malt and hop.  very robust and complex.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2008 Bomber bottle....brown with red highlights...light brown sugar head...hops on the nose, mandarin orange and grapefruit...I smell malts too but more underlying...wow!...holy citrus burst...followed by a short sweet malt burst....flavors of grapefruit and im sucking on a lemon seed...grapefruit takes over....nice balance of flavors, but in the malt citrus department citrus is clearly the winner...refreshing yet hearty body...citrusy finish and nice lacing
Reddish brown with thin lacing head.  Deep earthy malty scent.  Very hoppy taste.  Bitter and smooth.  Earthy notes.  Complex aftertaste.  Plays with the tastebuds.

From tap this beer is not really red, more dark brown with tan foam.  Smells almost like an IPA.  On first taste, comes off as an IPA, but has a smoother hop flavor, more malty caramel carries through.  Very nice to drink.
Dark brown body with small tan head. Has light aromas of cascade hop citrus-lemon and like mostly. The flavor is a very nice balance of yeast, malt, and like with a twist of lemon.
Bottle. Musky hop nose, light sticky sweetness. Pours amber-brown with an off-white head. Really balanced caramel-malt sweetness upfront into a mild bitterness in the finish. Thick silky palate.
dark amber with a thick off white head.  Aroma of hops (mmm).  Flavor of orange citrus,  hoppy goodness,  and a bit of malt to back it up.  Bitter and dry finish,  nice carbonation.  Good.

Deep hazy mahogany with a dense rocky almond coloured head displaying excellent retention and generating thick lace. Aromas of green hoppiness and brown sugar.Very malty palate, sweet and cakey with lots of resinous and floral hop character. Very creamy mouthfeel. Delicious!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: On tap at DINOSAUR BBQ!! WOOhooooOOO! Wow-ee dats hop-ee! I love the flavor. A great example of a hoppy beer that maintains a delicious taste.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2008 Beautiful amber complexition, nice lacing, great balance of Centennial and Cascade hops (Cascades are one of my favorites), really delicious and a great session beer. Highly recommnded.

bomber.  pours a deep redish with little head.  aromas of malts and some hops.  nice and smooth over the palate with some spices on the front while finishing with some strong hops.  overall a solid beer but lacks the extraordinary that would make me want to buy it again.  I think the 96% rating is a bit high... I would give it a solid B.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours murky brown with a frothy light tan head.  Aromas of sweet caramel malt and citrus fruits.  A little bit of hop bite up front, mellows with some caramel malt and then a little bitterness in the finish. Im getting some dark fruits as well.   Medium bodied.  Good brew, nicely balanced and easy to drink.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2010 bomber from BevMo san diego.  mahogany color w/ medium white head.  aroma of malt, little pine.  taste smacks you with malt but ends well balanced.  with spice and hop finish.  complex and really good, but not my thing.  RERATE: 7/9/10 Bomber from Newton Farms on Seabrook Island, SC - earth, grain, floral hops.  Long bitter somewhat harsh finish.  Well balanced otherwise.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2008 Draught and bottle at various times. Pours dark brown/red with a moderate off-white head. Aroma is somewhat fruity and caramel malt with quite a few hops, especially dry-hopped citrus and pine. Flavor is bitter and citrus hops on a malt background. Honestly this reminds me more of an IIPA than anything derived from a scottish ale, but its pretty good anyway. Better from the bottle than on tap, I think.

Pours a deep red color with a thin off-white head that lingers but does not leave much lace. Smells sweet like fruit and berries, raspberries . Tastes sweet of malt and red fruit, raspberries maybe some cranberries. Not too thick, not too thin. Nice crisp carbonation. This beer is very drinkable, a great red beer to drink if your feeling like a tasty beer with a little punch to it.
Tap.  Poured a reddish brown w/ some head.  Very well balanced.  One of my first beers from Bear Republic, Im now on the lookout for more.

nothing over the top with this one, but very drinkable and enjoyable none-the-less.  poured a reddish-mahogany-brown with a decent off-white head.  aroma and flavors are a nice balance of malt and hops with some caramel, rye and piney hops combining for an easy drinking Amer. Strong ale.  thanks to my secret santa for the 22 oz. bottle.
22oz bottle from BevMo Carmel Mountain.  Pours a nice deep mahogany color with a faint reddish hue.  Head was fairly small, light tan, little lacing.  nose was both malty and hoppy.

Duane shared a bottle of this with me last night.  Thanks!  Mahogany colored pour.  Plenty of piney hop aroma.  Flavor was well balanced between piney hops and malt sweetness.  Picked up some type of rye-character as well.  Solid beer.  Easy and enjoyable to drink.

Ehh. Lacking in the taste department. Pours a mahog color with a small yellow head. Smells like malt and hops. Taste is very bitter with roasted malt and hops. Kinda a messy representation of the ASA style. Harsh fizzy mouth feel.

Nice reddish color with a creamy head.  Aroma is heavy with rye, piney hops, caramel, and assorted grains.  Flavor is a bit too medicinal with a faded pine/floral hop mix slightly present.  Rye/ malts are decent - I think this bottle may have been better fresh, although Im not sure how long ago that was.  Not bad, but nowhere near the Hop rod or some of thier other brews.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2008 This is an excellent, complex, very satisfying beer.  It is somewhat dark red brown with a fairly good-sized tan head that lasts, slowly diminishing to a smaller, but complete, head and leaving some good lacing.  The aroma is wonderful, strong, very aromatic,  sweet, and pleasant, with flowery, piney hops over a base of caramel, malt and yeast.  The taste is similar to the aroma.  It has definite, strong hop bitterness, but this accompanies great, floral-pine flavour, and rich, caramel-malt sweetness.

Pours with a light brown, three-finger head that goes slowly to a thin layer, leaving a good lace. Light carbonation and medium bodied. Cloudy amber color. Nose is hoppy. Flavor is smooth, slight sweetness then a balanced to a hoppy finish.  Lingering bitter aftertaste. $4.55 for a 22oz bottle from Colonial Spirits, Acton, MA.
Poured a deep amber/red hue with a small soapy head. Bright floral hoppy nose with a small yet well-accompanied malt spine.  Smooth and silky mouth feel makes this a winner!
Poured a dark red with almost no head. This beer is full of hops, but not so much that it made it too bitter. Definately differnet for a stong ale.
Poured with little to no head, but had a great, smooth taste on the palate for a hoppy brew.  The dark red color drew my eyes back to the glass for more.

22oz poured out a fizzy off white head a muddy ruby brown with some particulate. Aroma was Mildly citrus some malt backbone. Flavor was mild bitter some roast malt with a creamy finish. A possible session beer..

650 ml bottle from local liquor store. Pours a translucent dark brown-red color with a beige head that left plenty of lacing as it dissipated. The aroma was medium in strength and had notes of sweet malts and some citrus. The flavor is reminiscent of a pale ale, biter hops take center stage, with malts and apricots rounding out the sides. The mouthfeel is full and silky. The finish features more biter hops. This beer went extremely well leftover open-faced turkey sandwiches, gravy and candied yams. Overall: Very good--Recommended.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2010 re-rate: 9/25/10- not as reduntantly amber as I remember, I need to re-rate it because it is not a steop above hop head red by greenflash but is still a damn good amber
12oz bottle part of world market 10 pack sampler... this is the first one I tried out of the sampler because Id heard so many good things about it.. Like an umbrella on a rainy day, this was just what I needed... pours a DEEP amber red with a nice frothy head upon arrival.. The punch of distinctive piney hops with a malty overtone.. Initial hit to the palate is a subtle explosion of toffee and spice malts.. not overpowering, very very smooth and leaves an inviting aftertaste on my palate.. good, no... great from start to finish the balance of hoppiness to malt is perfected in this ale.. maybe a little light on bite for an american strong ale, but still well worth it.. Damn good brew.. incredibly smooth given the abv..  wow!

Bottle.  Nice dark red, opaque color with rich, creamy head. Beautiful beer with fantastic balance of complex malt and citrusy hops.  Very surprised at how good this beer is. Balance is so good that the IBU and ABV numbers are hard to believe.  Fantastic beer.

With a BBQ chicken club at Porters Pub, UCSD. Salty and hoppy on the nose. Seems it would make a good harbor/sea beer. There are no alien flavors in this brew. Good 80/20 hop-malt balance. A solid specimen. However, I would classify it more as an IPA rather than a strong ale.

Tap. Aroma starts with moderate malt notes of roasted and caramel, pine and orange peel for the hops and light broth for the yeast with wood, pepper and toffee in the backgound. Head is smallish, white, creamy with some large bubbles mixed in and the lacing coated the glass better tha 50%. Color is a dark red/brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic then finishes moderately acidic and heavily bitter. Palate is medium, watery, has a lively carbonation and finishes a little astringent and lightly dry. Both a full and well balanced American strong.

Bomber pours a nice clear amber with big tan head due to the bottle conditioning and decent lacing. The aroma has dry roasted malts, mild caramelization, a hint of earthiness and very little hop presence. I think its a pine hop note. The taste begins aggressive with pine hop bitterness and dry nearly astringent roasted malts. The flavor becomes more sweet and rich with malts as the midway point is reached. I get caramel malts more roasted malts and also mixed in there is a nice peaty earthiness.  This is an aggressive flavored beer. It would be interesting to let this age a year or so and try again.

Bottle via trade with lb4lb. Lots of spicy and dry hops on the nose. A hint of rye like spice as well. Some malty and brown sugar sweetness as well. Pours rich copper/amber with a nice creamy tan head leaving excellent lacing. Flavor is balanced bitterness and maltiness. The dry hops and creamy malt work well with each other without any one dominating. Medium to full bodied. Nice!
Bottle courtesy of the usual suspect; Hellbilly!  Pours dark amber with thin fizzy head.  Fresh hop aroma, Twist of malts and caramel. Nice Hoppy backbone.

very dark amber color with a nice head on the pour.  hops immediately on the nose with the initial sniff.  i was quite impressed for a beer that had so much hop smell, not too thick but actually quite a good beer.

22 Oz Bomber-poured an amber color w/a moderate tan head. Sweet malt aroma. Has a hopped flavor, much more than you would expect from the pour. Doesnt seem to know if it wants to be an IPA, Scotch Ale, or Barleywine. Style is just too mixed up for me; this beer is a mess. Wasnt terrible, just lacked a definitive style.
Rich ruby amber color.  Beautiful and amazing lasting head.  A roasted caramel smell.  Nice rich bitterness.  Great crispness on the palate.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2008 Re-rate:  Bought a 6-pack of this stuff at BevMo.  Pours a BEAUTIFUL dark brown that goes totally red when held up to a light.  Smells grassy hoppy with some caramel sweetness.  Similar flavor, with some smokey and woody notes and a welcomed sweetness that isnt cloying in the slightest.  Wonderful balance between malts and hops, nice bitter finish without going overboard.  Perfect amount of body, not watery and not overly thick and hard to guzzle down. Alcohol well hidden, leaves a little warmth in the finish thats nice on a cold night like this.  This is good shit.

Bomber. Deep, rich auburn color. The scent is close to that of a barleywine without the alcohol afterburn. A tasty brew with a combination of caramel sweetness, hot sauce spice, and bitterness, with the malt shining through. It has the complexities of much stronger beers, so in a way its deceptively "weak". Still, an interesting and fun beer.

Pours a deep ruby-amber color with a substantial head that retreated quickly.  Tastes and smells like an IPA with a very hoppy character plus a little caramel.

1pt. 6oz bottle.

A nice American strong. Aroma of mostly caramel and malt. Pour was a medium murky brown with a little off white ring for a head. Taste starts as caramel and malt, then a little smokiness hits the taste buds. After the swallow there is some hoppiness and the back of the throat and tongue are left bittered. Very nice and well balanced.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Warm reddish bornw with a dense creamy tan head.  A bit sweet with some dark malt character with some light hops.  A bit of caramel, balanced.  a bit toasty.  Amarillo?  soft carbonation, a bit of body, creamy.  Not super rich.  A bit toasty.  Dark malt, agaisnt amarillo type hops?  Toasty, relatively dry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 mahogany color, active tall head.  aroma reminds me of a campfire; burnt wet pine/fir and burnt sap.  moderately heavy mouth feel, cotton, and a tickle of the characteristics of a good scotch brew with a cruncy hop bite.  i have to say, while re-rating this, Skeegles post was the most recent and it convinced me to bump the appearance up to a 5.  Good call on the neon amber dude, this really is a great looking beer.

22oz Bomber
A deep reddish color with a thin head.  This was a great beer.  Hops in the nose and flavor the malts where great the flavor had a crisp and spicy finish this was a fun and great beer to drink. I liked the complex flavor and the beer just drank awesome.

reddish brown color with medium dense tan head. caramel pine aroma with some bitter orange to it. medium to light syrupy body and a light carbonation. citric pine resin flavor with a nutty roasted caramel maltiness. fairly light bitterness for the style. good and not too heavy, surprisingly drinkable and goes down like a pale ale

This beer pours a deep deep mahogany almost black with a thin tan head leaving some decent lacing down the sides.  The smell is of nice beet sugars and hops and the flavor totally emulates this.  This really is not that bad of a beer!  Its got a strong malt flavor but is equally balanced by the hops.  I thought by the smell this would be more malty and less hoppy.  Glad I was wrong!  This is a very drinkable beer!  Cheers!

The aroma from the bottle issued the promise of something approaching Bastardly, and was much a letdown afterward.  Once in the glass an less concentrated, the aroma barely presented itself; as nice as its Bastardly tone was, it lacks volume.  Appearance is the best part: actually living up to the Bastardly promise, with much lacing.  The main delivery is lackluster, like 1 parts Bastard mixed with 1 parts water.  Body very watery.

(bottle): Pours a dark brown reddish color, dark white head, average, diminishing. Very pine hoppy aroma, some alcohol. Sweet, slight grapefruity smell. Sweet taste, slightly syrupy. Taste of pine. Slightly heavy body, bubbly, good mouthfeel. Okay.

9/23/07 On draught at the Fremont Oktoberfest, Seattle.  Aroma is sweet malt forward with caramel, dried fruit and citrus hops. Appearance is hazy amber with a good off-white head.  Flavor is typical scottish roast malt with a good earthy hop balance that is not blended, but works well together.  Mouthfeel is medium body with a moderate carb feel.  Overall, this was a little too earthy for my tastes, but not bad.

Dark red to brown in color with a good size tan head.  Hoppy with carmel and malty aromas.  Flavor definetly has hoppiness with not overwhelming it takes away from the balance I was expecting.  Gets better and better closer to the bottom.

Dark rich maroon pour with a big lasting beige head that wouldnt die.  Smell was rich sticky sweet malt, and almost rye like touches at times, and a nice vibrant hop blast.  Taste was quite hoppy, but suitably backed by a unique maltiness.   Mouthfeel was lightly carbonated and incredibly smooth going down. Alcohol is well hidden but pokes out ever so slightly.  Nice lacing on the glass too, after the girlfriend and I downed the bomber.  This one grew on me more and more as I drank it, and reminded me a bit of their Hop Rod Rye and Im very glad we get these here in Austin now.

Bottle: Brown with red tints and a nice light brown head.  Mild hop aroma, but plenty of hops in the flavor.  It has a great finish and feel of an all around good beer with substance.  I was impressed.

5gal keg from Halftime.  Dark reddish brown in color with light brown head.  Aroma hops.  Taste hops.  Finish, well it actually tastes like weed, very herby and well, hoppy.  Kind of weird coming from a red beer.

Large foamy, tan head.  Beer is amber copper in color; looks real nice.  Aroma is stong on the hops, citrus, some pine, grapefruit, a litle orange, sweet fruit malts, with a nice floral finish.   Hoppy flavor!  Citrus, some pine, hops, hops, hops, with a nice light fruit and floral finish.  The finish is long and bitter, with a dry feel to it.  Medium, solid body.  A great brew to say the least.  Bear Republic is fast becoming one of my favorites.

From large bottle.  Pours opaque reddish brown with medium sized caramel colored head.  Aroma is delicious sweet fruity hops.  Flavor is big hops and nice malt backdrop.  I love it.  This is a truly big beer.  Reminds me of a Lagunitas Sirius on steroids.

pours a rich dark copper with red hints with a small creamy head. aroma is pine hoppy with sweet malts, earth, dried herbs and alcohol.flavor has the same pine with woody/paper bag characters. caramel is balance well with a nice bitter finish. creamy medium bodied...

A Sim rate (on tap at the Flyng Saucer Houston): I cant believe that something that looks so red and delicious can be so very hoppy. Ånd perhaps Im biased as I love traditional red ales and am not a fan of hops. Aroma and flavour are so dominated by hops that I really couldnt enjoy this one. Bitter in the finish.

650 ml bottle
At $2.49 this is a winner.  While it wont be gracing my Top 50 any time soon I cannot imagine something this inexpensive being so good.  It amazes me that places like Bear Republic, Lagunitas and Stone can charge so little for their beers despite having to ship them halfway across the country.  If all craft beers were this cheap and excellent I think Miller and AB would be in serious trouble.
Aroma / Appearance - The half finger cream head decorates the stained oak body underneath.  It poured a very dark red which let through only about 10% of all the light.  Spruce, caramel and lemons present an interesting contrast for a flavor I have yet to find in any other beer - candied beets.
Flavor / Palate - Hops play against the butterscotch and honey to form a sweet opening impression.  Caramel, malts and peat follow through a few sips later.  The final sips remind me of wet earth, magnolia blossoms and tea leaves.  It is simultaneously sippable and sessionable depending which way you like to drink your scotch ales.  This is a great value and if you want something inexpensive for an evening give this a try.

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark brown/ruby color with a very small off white head. The aroma is very hoppy with grapefruit. Decent lacing on this one. The taste is malty with a bitter finish. A very good american strong ale.

Bottle... Poured a murky, ruby color with a frothy off-white head.  Some hops on the nose.  Flavors of grains and a caramel sweetness.  Contained a nice hop bitterness while still being balance by some malt.  Finished with a sweet, syrupy aftertaste.  This beer was a nice treat, Im glad I picked it up.

(draft @ The Old Toad - Rochester, NY) Dark ruby color with a creamy tan head. Aroma has a very nice and sweet resin note at the beginning, followed closely by citrus and caramel with a little touch of bitter hops. Flavor is smooth and sweet at the front with a middle of caramel and sweet malts and a light and bitter finish. Lingers for a bit on the tongue.

22 oz bottle pours a clear red mahogany body with a lavish beige head. Complex aroma of pine and grapefruit hops atop a caramel and toffee malt backbone. Taste is dominated by bitter grapefruit and pine hops which slightly overpower the toffee malt sweetness. Just a hint of apple fruitiness adds a nice complexity. Very drinkable.

Date: 09/07/1997
Mode: Firkin
Source: Brewpub

ruby red, slightly sweet malt aroma, semi dry malt flavor, nice long lingering hop bitterness, much more an esb than a scottish
-------- />
Date: 05/20/2006
Mode: bottle
Source: tasting

drippy lace, big sweet carmel malt aroma, rich malt flavor, nice sweetness, light bitterness, well balanced easy drinking ale

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: **+/4

Thanks to Joebrew for sharing
Nice red color with no head.  Hoppy citrus nose.  Faint sourness in the citrus hop body.

From a 22-oz bomber, shared by joebrew pours a clear caramel amber brew with a thick creamy head with food retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, citrusy and grassy hops with some light chocolate. Taste is medium bodied, light carbonation with a slight metalic character. Flavors has a rich caramel malt and some mild bitterness. Finish is semi-sweet and then a flat caramel flavor in the after taste. A little light on the alcohol for a strong ale but still tasty.

22 oz...dark amber with a thick foamy tan head...malt and grassy hop aroma, some sweet citrus...initial pine and citrus taste with a smooth bitter bite...lightly sweet semi bitter finish...refreshing brew....very easy drinking...theres a lot going on with this beer without too much confusing complexity...great beer to break into after a 3 day break

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2011 22oz bomber from Once Upon a Vine, Richmond. Fantastic looking beer, pours deep red with a big fluffy head (foamberg lasts forever). Smells of rich malt, unassuming but obviously quite well crafted. But the taste introduces a really interesting citrus hop profile, obviously indebted to West Coast IPAs (which BR also do quite well), and that gives this pumped up red a distinctive and very enjoyable quality.

Pours a medium grade brown ... Assertive firm head ... Has a nice bold hop profile ... lacing is B+ ... Rust, Pine, Caramel - Aroma ... Does contain a appealing blend of flavours, id change a few things but a solid offering.. "Baie dankie"
Very solid hops aroma with a hint of peaty smokeyness.  Flavor is a bit like smokey pine.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2007 12 oz bottle and draft at the brewpub a few nights later. Poured a slightly hazy orange color. Head was thick and off white with decent retention and lacing. Pleasant aroma of grapefruity and resiny hops accompanied by malty caramel. Slightly sweet on the tongue with moderate hop bitterness. Flavor followed aroma with a nice malt-hop balance. The alcohol was well disguised. Good beer. Almost as good in the bottle as it was on tap.

Nice pine hop nose to start with.  Pours a clear dark red,  with a huge off-white head.    Taste wise, its got a nice pine hop bite, with a touch of coffee/roasted flavor hiding in there and coming out in the finish.  Somewhat thin in the mouthfeel, I was expecting a little more body in it.  A good solid beer, Id say add some dry hopping, and get it a bit thicker, and it would be outstanding.

Bomber. Dark orange amber pour with a huge that head that becomes a rocky island. Very hoppy nose, big pine and citrus melds well with sweet caramel and light earth. Strong flavors of piney wood, flowers and caramel, plus a tinge of smoke that is not quite peaty. Damn close, though. Caramel and citrus finish. Excellent.

Pours a red to dark brown with a light tan head that lasts pretty long.  Good aroma of caramel, toast, piney citrus hops and butter.  Big flavor balances both malty and hoppy agendas.  Lots of caramel and toasty flavors, light chocolate, and mild sweetness with some real nice earthy and planty hop notes.  Finishes with even more hop flavor thats toasty and buttery, and the bitterness is pretty mellow.  Cloys a little bit after the finish, despite the beer not being syrupy at all.  Thick full mouthfeel is completely coating, which was a pleasant surprise as I didnt expect that.  Low carbonation.  Good beer, could compete with Arrogant Bastard pretty well.

Floral hoppy aroma, toasty, slight alcohol.  Clear ruby color.  Taste is malty, fruity, hoppy, slightly nutty.  Sweetness is the taste is balanced nicely with hop bitterness.  Slight alcohol sting on the finish.  This is very complex and very good.

Bottle.  Poured Teak red with a fast dissipating head.  Aroma of hops,  candy and caramel.  Much caramel and hops in the flavour, with a hoppy tang on the tongue.  Lingering finish that lasts forever.. 

Edited for spelling
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: 22 oz bottle.  Had this after a Lucid absinthe (blech!) before the Phillies-Braves stinker.  Clear amber with a tan glacial head that leaves a patch to the bottom.  Simple nose of caramel orange.  Almost syrupy orange toffee with a grapefruit brulée hop kick.  Tiny, tingley carb.  Rye-peat drying.  Sticky, sort of barleywinish.  Good.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2007 Beers pours a deep amber with a clear, frothy white head.  Very aromatic hops greet the nose with citrus notes.  A big malt odor lurks behind the floral hoppiness with a slight metallic tinge the only negative.  Oily hoppiness rolls onto the tongue with an orange peel flavor and medium bitterness.  The thin malt flavor is overwhelmed by the hops but still detectable during the middle of a mouthful.  But when the brew heads for the back of the mouth, a moderate astringency and stronger hop bitterness quickly drown out the malt.  The metallic note in the nose becomes apparent to the palate on the aftertaste.  I really didnt much care for this one.

Pours dark brown-amber with moderate fluffy tan head.  Strong citrus hop presence in the nose balanced with caramel and toffee malts and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor is smokey with nice bitter hops and a smooth malt backbone.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Not overly complex, but delicious nonetheless.

fine clear reddish brown with a thin tan head, balanced malt/hop aroma with. flavor is thin in the middle, with various odd ntoes off to the sidesmoke, brown sugar, vinegar. very dry on the tongue but the lips are tingly.

Damn, this is good. Great balance with an edge towards hoppy. Fnishes pretty flowery and hoppy too but as it warms up the hoppiness diminshes.. Seems like it should be classified as an amber if it were my decision. Glad I got a good balanced brew to mix into my regular rotation.
draft- sticky, red, malty brew (dont really get the carmel malt decribed in some of the ratings), with some big time piney bitterness. Yum.
A really good copper ale, very similar to Lagunitas Lucky 13. Picked it up in SF on a road trip. Caramel malt with semi-aggressive hops. Solid brew.
dark and red.  smooth thick sailing.  it would be hard to say you didnt enjoy drinking this ale.  exceptionally balanced.
good. i have a few in the category that i choose over this one and that are easier to obtain but i would most certainly drink more of this.

22 oz. bottle from Bottleworks in Seattle.  Pour is reddish brown with a normal off white head.  Aroma is resinous grassy hops and earthy malts.  Taste is initially resinous hops but move to malt in the middle and finish with pine hoppiness.  There is some dry / sweet fruitiness (dates, sweet raisins) in their as well.  Nice brew.
Pours caremel reddish with short head.  Strong malty chocolate flavor with nice hops.  Slightly astringent, but altogether vey drinkable.  Ill have this one again.

22oz bottle.  Aroma:  Big hop nose with notes of pine, citrus, and resin.  Malt comes through more as it warms with notes of caramel, bread, and chocolate.  Appearance:  Dark reddish brown in color and opaque.  Medium beige head was full and foamy with good retention.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Roasted malt with notes of caramel, dark fruits, and bread.  Hops come on strong with pine and resin, and a good citrus note.  Medium-high bitterness leads to a medium-sweet finish.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Overall:  Loved the play of malt vs. hops.  Hops are the focus, but doesnt overbalance.

Dark amber, large rocky head with good lacing and retention. Aroma is strong PNW hops (grapefruit mostly) with some chococaramel malts. Medium to full body, fairly predictable hopping, but the malts made this somewhat interesting. No matter what, its well made and enjoyable.
22 oz bottle. Pours dark copper color with off white head. Strong citrus hoppy aroma. Taste of malt, hops, hops and more hops with bitter after taste.
Full bodied with the some of the best flavors. I like the way it looks in a tall glass, the color is beautiful. First taste and I was hooked.

Nose of flowers, pine, pine, pine and pine.  How about an Evergreen Mountainside?  Pours cola brown with ruby amber highlights.  The lovely cascade produces a tight creamy bone head that is mostly lasting and leaves lace like spiderwebbing.  The flavor is consistantly bitter with moderate acidity.  The huge roasted and bitter floral finish is impressive.  The thick body is creamy and soft.  The finish feels dry.  Bear Republic has emerged as another serious player in the world of microbrewing.

Dark ruby red color with lasting tan frothy head with lacing. Big citrus hop/caramel malt aroma. Flavor is nutty malt and big full, well-developed hops. Heavily bodied, finishes more on the sweet side. Kind of a Scottish/American Amber Ale mix.
From Alefest in Columbus Ohio.  Brown, with a thin creamy tan head and a medium body.  Smooth and smoky.  A very drinkable beer for a strong ale.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Pours a darker copper color with a tan head.  Aroma is of citrus and pine hops,  toffee, dark fruits, caramel, and some sweet malts.  Flavor starts off sweet with caramel and dark fruits.  Theres not much of a middle flavor but the citrus and mainly pine hops come forward strong on the finish to give it a bitter, lingering flavor.  Overall this is a pretty good brew, a little dissapointed with the flavor but still pretty decent.

Dark brown color with medium whitish head.Aroma of dark malt and hops. Rich and comolex on the palate. Aggressive hop taste with sweet malt and some earthy spiciness.Extremely well balanced with a nice smooth finish. A winner in my book.

Nice ,handsome ale,brown with red tinges, topped by a gorgeous thick frothy tan head.
Good balanced aromas, you first pick up the piney hops but soon a nice caramel malt aroma joins in.
Smooth mostly malty flavour at first with the hops appearing much later in the mouthful, mainlly citric in intensity.
Though nice on the tongue, this is just a tad too thin for style.
Over all a nice amber ale.

On tap.  Pour a very attractive dark red and brown that had nice depth to it.  The head was thin, white and only hung around for a bit before retreating to the edges, leaving spotty lacing down the glass.  The aroma was top notch.  A super nice blend of soft citrus notes like tangerine combine with sugary malt and piney hops.  Unfortunately the flavor didnt find the balance that the aroma did.  The sugary malt and citrus were dominated by the very dry piney hops.  Good mouthfeel.  On the verge of being a really great brew.

Pours brown with an average fizzy white head. Aroma is moderately hoppy with some citrus, scotch and sweet malts. Smells great! The flavour is a near perfect blend of hops and malt. Palate is nice and creamy. An awesome beer and one of my favourites. Bear Republic continue to impress.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2007 Malty and sweet. Strong malty scent.  Dark blood-red glow to it in the glass. Big visible chunks of sediment. Medium head. Good lacing. Difficult taste to evaluate; Ive no experience with Scottish red ales and in any event this is one is not supposed to be typical of the style. I want to say its well balanced, in that I taste both the hop and the malt--but the tastes on both sides are strong. How can you have a bitter hoppy kick AND strong sweet maltiness at the same time? This beer shows you can. Not sure I like it completely but I love the fact that this brewery goes all out in its brews. (The feel on the palate matches the taste: lasting malty smoothness, stinging hop, light warming alcohol.) Overall: Weird. Likable. Admirable.

Do these guys make bad beer?  Another outstanding beer from them.  This beer is seriously helping my back problem and I am heading back for another bottle when this one is finished.  There are other beers that Ill never drink again and this isnt one of them.

Havent gotten off of my ass(on the couch that is, and then come over here and sit back down on my ass, but this time in front of the computer) and written a review in awhile, so welcome back to me. I have enjoyed Bear Republic beers since moving to Virginia(were not available in Florida) and certainly the Red Rocket continues that tradition. Pours a rich, sherried honey color with a pleasent, tight head. Nice, pungent aroma of toasted hazelnut and spicy rye. Hits the mouth with an initial dry bitterness that quickly steps aside to make room for a smooth, nutty, caramel-tinted body and a come-hither finish. I must drink deeply again and again. Tasty. A robust Americanized red ale that would rock long and hard at any meat-heavy, eating-time gathering.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2015 WOW... 22 oz bottle. Pours a nice dark amber/red color. A nice creamy head. Starts out like a really good amber beer and then has a hoppy finish like a really good IPA. The best beer I have had so far. The bottle says to drink at a temp of 45-55 degrees. Took it out of fridge and let it sit out for 30 minutes before pouring in a glass and enjoying.

This may have been an old bottle and I do not believe it was stored properly at the liquor store where it was purchased, but here goes.

Pours a really dark red with a huge pillowy head that takes a few minutes to dissipate. Aroma is sugary malts and floral hops, very pleasing. Taste is hops, carmel malts, some fruits and a little roastiness. Taste is slightly cardboard which makes me think this bottle had been on the shelf a little too long. Slightly off tasting aftertaste hurt drinkability a little. Seems like a very good beer. I will adjust this review as soon as I can find some fresher product.
On tap at Bear Republic.  Pretty red color, faint aroma, caramel taste, not enough hops for my taste.

22oz bottle pours dark copper in color with a healthy offwhite head that stays for a bit and laces some.  Nice aroma of caramel malts, some grapefruit notes as well and maybe a little peat. Flavor is caramel, molasses, toffee, and grapefruit.  Very smooth on the palate and quite easy drinking.  Slight bitterness at the finish. Soft carbonation gives this a nice smooth mouthfeel too.  Not bad at all.
Slightly hopped and malty aroma.  Hazy red with a medium head.  Medium palate.  Good caramel malt flavor with a hop bite and a somewhat rye flavor coming through.

Pronounced fresh hop aroma. Balanced, drier than a traditional Scottish ale, but well balanced. Sort of a Scottish-American Pale Ale. Roast bitter cherry with a complex persistent finish. Very, very nice beer.
Dark amber pour with off-brown head.  Malty nose with hints of hops.  Light citrus, with great sweet malty mouth feel.  Nice little alcohol feel to it when it hits your lips.

Aroma of pine, perhaps a bit of floral. Quite red color with a beige head. Starts with malty sweetness, full mouthfeel, followed by some hop which seems to be citrus. Some gritty brown malt in the finish, backed by some bitter. Fairly smooth, almost creamy at points. Seems a bigger ale than the 6.8% would indicate.
Bitter hops and some light malt stand out in the aroma.Pours a reddish brown with a medium tan head.Nice hops with a good malt balance in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a nice hop finish.

22 oz bottle, via jarspag.  Pours a dark ruby colored body, completely clear, under a foamy one finger beige head that left copious amounts of lacing.  The aroma strikes me as a typical ASA with a heavy citric hoppiness.  Lots of syrupy caramel and toffee maltiness.  Aggressive hoppiness grabs you up front with a moderate bitterness level.  Finishes a little sweeter with some toasted and toffee malt.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a slightly sticky and resinous texture cut by a lively aggressive carbonation level.  This was decent, but seemed to lack any distinction between this and a 100 other ASAs.  Im never too big of a fan of the "lots of everything" formula for Strong Ales.  How about some subtlety?

Magma hued pour with a perfect, incredible thundercloud head.  Candied plum and caramel apple aroma.  Hidden foresty hops.  Rather monstrous flavors.  Burnt toffee and charred dark fruits chased in the finish by barren woody hops.  Brown sugar glazed orange, semi-sweet chocolate.  Palate is full, rich and forward.  Somewhat noisy and brash, but still strangely pleasant.

Nice aroma, malty, with hints of roasted barley, some brown sugar.  pours dark red with a huge white head that lasts!  Malty, roasted notes, sweet yet hoppy.  Some brown sugar, with some roasted notes, with a heavy dose of hops.  Citrus hop flavors, definitely northwestern flavor.

Many red ales taste flat or watery, or extremely bitter and one-dimensional. Not this one. Its moderately bitter with a smooth caramel hopiness. Soft carbonation.  Like a toned down IPA. Quite refreshing.

One of my fav bear republic ales that I have tasted...  I am a fan for sure, a pretty hoppy red ale - hoppy finish is the highlight - quite enjoyable.  Not too much or too little of any certain quality.  Nice session beer

Ah good red ale... had this one a while back. good hoppy aroma with a great color to it. sweet at first with a good malty and hoppy finish that totally lingers on the palate. Up there with the hop rod rye.
Reddish brown body with a average head with good lacing. Floral hoppy aroma and taste with long lasting bitterness.

Big, thick, chewy head. Nice clear dark amber color. Not much aroma there, but maybe because it is still a little cold, just out of the fridge. Interesting, complex malty flavors up front and in the middle. very unusual, a little spicy, earthy hops in there. Overall ballance and interesting malt profile make this a decent beer, but not one of my favorites.
22 oz bomber pours a dark red with a two finger beige head.  big hoppy aroma with nice malt sweetness.   Very well balanced beer.

Mahogany body with a smooth khaki head. Big hop nose, citrus and sweet caramel. Strong hop flavor, fresh and crisp with a good sweetness to counter it. Now that this beer is in 6 packs this will be a staple and the 7% ABV is a nice added bonus.
22oz from Bevmo...$3.49.  Pours a clear redish amber color with a adequate head.  Nice balance of hops and malt flavors.  Very smoov!
A great brew, nice garnet color, small head, decent lacing. Hopped nicly, with plenty of malt.Some citrus flavors. alcohol is well hidden. finishes on the sweet side, great, great brew!
good ale, strong in hops, good head that looks like a brain, good bitter kick

Clear, dark reddish brown. Frothy light tan head. Nice aroma, laid back hops, sweet brown sugar, 
Sweet sugary hop taste, some roasty caramel, sweet butter, orange chocolates. Pretty good overall. Average mix of flavors.
Very good, bitter ale.  Strong flavor of hops, great head.  Better than expected.  The beer leaves a delicious after taste.  Will use all taste buds.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: 650 bomber, split with VeloVampire - pours dark reddish brown/amber, with an extremely foamy, rocky, crater ridden head. Awesome. Floaty yeast chunks in the glass. The mountainous head retains its shape through almost the entire glass, leaving excellent lacing as well. Beautiful looking beer. Aroma is a huge dose of piney/grapefruity west-coast hops against a light malt background. Really nice, but fairly typical US beer aroma. Flavour however is a surprise, and a knockout one. Very complex. Starts with piney hops, followed by notes of chocolate, some caramel, nutty malt, yeast/bread, followed by a lingering bitter finish. Amazing, and totally unique. Very smooth and full in the mouth. Incredibly well balanced. I loved this beer.

650 ml bottle, shared with StompBrockmore - dark amber in the glass with suspended yeast chunks and a beautiful brownish rocky head that lasted for a long time, and was almost reminiscent of a Belgian ale.  Aroma big fruity hops, and lots of malt.  Flavours nutty, yeasty, chocolatey and of course HOPS.....and.....MALT!  Full-bodied with a smooth malty finish.  Really a combination of a few styles that works really, really well - Scotch ale, brown ale, and American IPA, all coming together to create a unique and utterly delicious brew that defies categorization.  This ones the real deal - get it!

Clear copper with a large head. Good lacing. Head turns rocky as it slowly dissipates.
Aroma - grapefruit, pine and caramel.
Flavor brings out the caramel, fairly balanced. Medium body. Oily and slightly sticky texture. Astringent finish

This 22 oz. Bomber emitted a healthy pop when opened. The beer poured beautifully with a nice off-white head that gave way to a sturdy, consistent lacing during drinking.  The initial aroma, for me, was very hoppy with underlying tones of caramel and malt. Complex is a fantastic adjective for this beer as there seems to be so much in it, that many specific flavors and scents are not discernable.  The overall mouthfeel is almost silky and the taste of malt comes to the forefront.  An aftertaste of mild hops and some earthy spice follow.  Although I dont care for hoppy beers, this is balanced very nicely and is very drinkable for people with a variety of preferences as the experience is and extraordinarily in-tune and complimentary package (aroma, taste, body, aftertaste) to experience.

Pours a nice brown with a thick tan head.  Smell of malt, caramel and bread.  This beer was ver nice indeed.  It was very smooth going down, but towards the end of the bottle, it left a nice dry hoppy aftertase.  This is a very solid beer

Has good maltiness to start but then youre nailed with a strong hop hit. Neutral fruitiness with floral character - a decent balance of aromas. Some tea in there behind the sharp hoppiness and caramel. Dark brown amber clear with off-white foamy head. Medium heavy body with medium carbonation. Good bitter ale. Mild malty sweetness with dry powdery bitterness. Finish is medium bitter with dry chalkiness. Bitter end with floral notes but not over the top. Finally, a bit of rounded sweetness on the palate.
deep copper, light tan head.  Nose is caramel, resin, fruity bubblegum.  Flavor is caramel, piney & orange hops, brown sugar.  Maybe a touch of rye in the finish.

22oz. Bomber

Opened with a hefty pop. Havent opened a bottle, that didnt have a cork on it, that sounded like that in a long while. Huge carbonation on the pour. Half my glass was head. 

Red rocket has an unbelievably big rocky head. The head looked like a mountain with all kinds of peaks. Hazy dark red with tiny particles floating in it. The head reminds me of a root beer float. The lace sticks like huge chunks on the glass. I dont think I have ever seen a head this chunky on a beer before. Looks delicious. After finishing this beer theres still a quarter inch head on the bottom of the glass. Impressive!

This beer really smells interesting. Ripe melons come to mind and some kiwi. I dont know why but this beer smells really fruity and fresh. Theres a caramel smell poking through the fruit. Very inviting. I cant wait to drink just to see what tastes will come through.

MMM....A solid caramel maltiness comes through at first and is quickly followed by a nice assertive hop bite with a mild lingering bitterness. Theres the smallest amount of alcohol present. Theres some other flavors I cant put my finger on.

The mouthfeel is excellent. Its smooth and very creamy. Its like velvet in my mouth.

Drinkability is good. I could very easily drink a lot of these. The more I drink the more filling it gets though. I would drink these till I filled up.

Overall Red Rocket is one of the best red ales Ive had up to this point. It will be a hard one to beat. 

Sampled 10/13/06
A nice brew. Aroma is hoppy. Pour is dark brown with just a little lacey head. Mouthfeel is exceptionally smooth. Flavor is packed but lacks any destinct taste. Certianly worth a try.
Unique citrus rye hoppiness with carmelm malt. The reference to a Scottish red ale puzzles me,  perhaps since Ive never had a scottish red but this seems nothing like scottish ales Ive had.

12 oz. bottle- color of deep reddish brown , with a ok tan head - nose of spruce , hopps , resin , malt , and citrus  taste of hopps , malts , citrus , dirty , and dirty - body thick , sour and dirty  aftertaste of dirty resin , and spearmint

Bomber.  Cloudy root beer color with a thick bumpy cream head.  Left sheets of lacing.  Aroma of dark toffee and cake, with hops seeping through.  After a while in the glass some bubblegum scents come through.  Hoppy brown sugar flavor.  Bitter finish of burnt coffee, which I think may be more the result of the hops rather than the roast of the malt. Finished with a slightly harsh bitterness at first, though mellows out after a while.  Full bodied with a slightly slippery mouthfeel.  Everything seems a bit jagged.  Needs more smoothing over.

22-oz. bottle obtained via trade with fordest.  Pours brown and sparkling with a large lasting rocky off-white to light brown head and excellent lacing.  Aroma is average malt (caramel, roasted), heavy hops (flowers, pine, perfume), average yeast (dough, sweat) with notes of alcohol and brown sugar.  Full bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation and a bitter finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, heavy acidity and moderate bitterness.

This bottle of Bear Republic Red Rocket Ale was sent to me by bitbucket from the first part of our multi-part trade.  Thanks Bob!  I have been really looking forward to trying this beer (especially after having a couple of the other Bear Republic brews)...

No matter how I pour this beer, a MASSIVE light brown colored whipped foam head is generated.  However, it is really hypnotic to watch the bubbles stream down like sand in a hour glass as the liquid rises from the bottlom and the head and top shrinks.  In the end, there is still a pretty think foamy head that has excellent retention and collapses unevenly.  This creates interesting craters and ridges on top which look wrinkly as it condenses.  The head never completely collapses, so the residual lacing is quite think and prolific.  The color of the beer is medium to dark brown and somewhat cloudy.  This beer is very aromatic and has lots of orange and citrus hops which rocket from the bottle as soon as the cap is popped off.  There is also some sweet caramel maltiness that blends nicely with the hoppy aromas.  This beer really does taste as good as and exactly like it smells!  At first it has a nice caramel maltiness and mild hoppiness.  Then more of the citrus hops flavor and bitterness comes out as it moves into and though the drier, rye-like finish.  The bitterness is well controlled (moderate) and has a nice sweet, almost spicy, pine/citrus hop flavor.  The body of this beer is medium/full and it is mildly carbonated.  It is extremely smooth on the palate.  This beer is amazingly full flavored and well balanced overall.  I would love to drink this beer one right after the other.  I dont think its possible to grow tired of it.  Plus, its only 6.8% ABV which makes this a great beer to drink in quantity.  Too bad I cant buy it here in Ohio (but that might be a good thing since I could almost take this stuff intravenously!).  Bear Republic Red Rocket Ale is just as good, if not better than Stone Arrogant Bastard and Stone Double Bastard!  Thanks again Bob!  This one was really a treat!

Another home run for Beer republic. This pours a nice dark redish color. Another thick headed foam on top. Very easily drank. Almost a brown ale taste to it. This is just another great beer. One that I could easily sit and drink in a long long session.

Tap.  Pours a blackened red with a short, foamy head.  Nose is sweetened hops.  Flavor was caramel and vanilla with citrus and a bitter finish.  When I first saw the pint, I thought it was much darker than the red/amber ale it was described as.  However, it was a real nice brew.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a beautiful dark ruby red, nice creamy head, and lots of lacing.  The aroma and flavor is outstanding.  Bold sweet carmel malt flavor with mild hints of citrus, vanilla, toasted malt and a nice balance of bitterness.  Bear Republic is becoming one of my favorite brewers.

Pours a clear deep brick red, topped by a huge clump of frothy tan suds. Good head retention and thick lacing. Spicy and piney hops in the aroma.

A blend of sweet and dry maltiness provide a backbone for a more prominent hop character. The malt gives light caramel, light toasted, and a hint of licorice. The hops are a little citrus, a little pine, a little spice - with bitter pine in the finish and aftertaste. Medium body, fairly smooth - aided by tons of soft carbonation.
Dark hazy brown with lasting tan small tan head.  Fruity, citrus, toasted oats aromas.  Med body with strong bitterness lasting awhile.

Bomber from Liquorama.

Intense hop aroma is defined by pine, but is lightly citric. The malt component while not in command has more range featuring, toast, caramel, fruit cake and a touch of brown sugar.

The body of this beer is a dark opaque brown with very faint orange hues to it. The head is creamy, firm, a thumb thick and lasting. Nice looking brew.

The fore is heavily hopped and that first sip is very creamy. Toasted caramel malt, burnt brown sugar and even a good dose of chocolate follow the hoppy first blast. It has a nice balance of malt to hop and both are very heady. This kind of has a Christmas beer feel to it, though hoppier than most would be. I really like the base malt flavors here. Very nice brew.

On Tap at Landmark.  Brown color.  Smell of hop, copper, metal,  citrus, little bit of smoke, caramel and hints of pine.  Tastes the same with more sweet and spice.  Dry bitterness at the end that lasts for awhile.

Pours a ruby/brown with an average creamy off white head that left some lacing.  Aroma of various fruits, floral, citrus, caramel and toffee.  Flavor of pine, grapefruit, toasted malts, caramel, a bit earthy and light bitterness.  Overall  a rather hoppy beer which is nicely balanced all around with the malts used.

Tap at David Copperfields.  Deep ruby/amber colour with a creamy off-white head.  Lovely fruity aroma, piney hops, some grapefruit citrus, mango and sweet maltiness as well.  Flavour is well-hopped but only shows moderate bitterness.  Sweet toasty crystal malts behind the sweet resiny hops.  Very piney lingering hoppiness.  Nice taste of the PNW.

Bottle via trade with cbkschubert. Thanks craig! Decent hoppy aroma with nothing standing out. Deep ruby look with thin head. Flavor is good but mild and slightly hoppy. Smooth but too one-dimensional. Decent brew.

Bottle courtesy of Hogtownharry: Poured a dark brown color ale with a big dirty brown color head wit good retention. Aroma of big citrusy hops is quite powerful and dominant with some roasted sweet caramel malt also noticeable. Taste is almost entirely dominated by big citrus hops with a good caramel malt backbone. Body is about average and carbonation is slightly above average. If you like big citrus flavour beer from the west coast then this is probably going got be for you.

The bastardization from hops is very noticeable in the aroma and the dry hoppy head. Very gritty taste. Has the scottish maltiness in the beginning and hops near the end. Weird and good, but seems to float in that space where I cant decide whether I really like it or really dont.

Inviting appearance, sweet aroma and bitter taste are the three most noticable characteristics. Translucent red-brown body below a big, frothy head that sticks around. The big nose is full of malts, caramel, floral scents and grapefruit. Small notes of earthiness. Flavor is initially slightly sweet, but the hops quickly dominate filling the mouth with a long, bitter finish. Medium body and watery texture. Moderate carbonation. Dry finish.

Moderate hop aroma, most of washington varieties, malt aroma balances with the hops. Poured a cloudy red with tan head that disipated within a min. Flavor of bitter hops and a slight burnt note possible from darker malts or astringentcy due to hop additions. ver full mouthfeel and mouth coating but bitterness detracts a slight
bottle.  Aroma is fresh resiny hops, lots of malt.  Taste is fresh hops, citrus, malt, a touch of chocolate and sugar, lingering slightly bitter finish.  very well made, really enjoyed this.
Malty aroma very little hoppiness.  Poured an amber red with very little off white head.  Initial flavor is malty, fruity sugary.  Slight maple and brown sugar flavors.  Clean finish.  Excellent red.

Bought this for the Mrs. She likes red ales for there lack of hops. Thats why i ended up having this. Full flavored hoppiness with lots of caramel malts and spices.  Didnt like the hop flavor though i got pine, celery and slight grapefruit. A bit metalic and leathery at the end. Not great, but drinkable.

Smooth, rich palate.  Dominant caramel.  A good bit spicy.  Even a bit of a chili pepper flavor.  Slightly resiny.  A bit leathery and smoky.  Some slight pine.  Grape.  Obviously quite complex.  Hops play a nice supporting role.  Another well done Bear Republic beer.

Pours dark amber brown w/ medium semi cremy froth. Aroma is potent w/ floral hops. medium full nectar w/ ample mellow residual effers. Flavors are strong and citrusy, w/ caramel, leather and spice.  Malty sweet backbone is perfect w/ big, bright,  dusty hops pushing forward. Not your typical red ale. Just slightly unbalanced. Its big. A good food brew paired w/ rich and spicey dishes. Really good after a few nips of premium Bourbon. The palate prepped w/ Bourbon  wont let the hops show allowing you a different perspective. nice. Highly recommended.
Bottle. Pours caramel, off white head. Aroma is malt, hops, citrus, floral. Flavor is malt, smokey, floral, slight citrus, and rye.
A hazy red-brown beer with an orange head. The aroma is sweet and very hoppy, but also with notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet with lots of hops, combined with notes of caramel and straw.

Stunningly beautiful deep purple-burgundy red colour with a dense yellowish head, leaving lace. Powerful American hops nose, piney, and dry hop bails jumping out of the glass. Maybe also slightly cheesy, oxydized hops. The aroma is so powerful that the taste seems almost lame in  comparison. Almost, as theres a lot going on: perfumey hops, decent bitterness, soft sweet cakes. Bit of caramel. Very little body, caramel cant give body, neither can hops. Its a nice drinker that unfortunatley want to present itself as a BIGUN. Which it isnt.

On Tap at the Yardhouse in Long Beach, CA.  Beautiful dark amber color, nice hop aroma with caramel,  Very complex flavors throughout, nice citrus and bitterness from the centennial and cascade hops.  Thicker mouthfeel.  Great beer!
22oz bomber-A dark amber beer with a tan head that goes away very quickly. An aroma of hops and malt. Tastes of malt,caramel, and hops on the front end. a great tasting beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark red color with a nice off-white head on top. Aroma is hops, pine, citrus, grapefruit, and malt. Flavor a hit of so much all of a sudden. At first sip you get a nice hoppy bite to it, similar to that of an IPA/IIPA with a citrus/grapefruit taste. Then right after is the hit of the malt, mostly a caramel taste. Another good beer from the folks of Bear Republic!

This had a small short lived head.Aroma was a soft sweet siron.This had a deep full taste.Grapefruit,pine,caramel.seems well balanced.I would prefer a tad more hops.Actually tastes better the more I drink it!Finishes with a complex slightly sweet,bitter and something else...that RED taste!A real good red.Flavor lasts after taking sip.This might be my new favorite red ale.

This is one of my trades I recieved from realale420.  22oz bottle.  Very heavy hop aroma.  Citrus and pine in the air!  Dark reddish rusty color. heavy creamy tan head.   WOW!  what a flavor combo,  Lots of ctrus, Grapefruit.  Malt flavors include some carmel.  What a hoppy finish!!!  Females beware:  this one aint sweet.l

Pour is obviously red with a small white head.  Aroma is a nice dose of oliy hops with  heaping of malts.  Flavor is much the same.  Dark malts giving the brew a great thick mouthfeel.   Hops also show up and give it a nice crisp and fruity flavor.  A very interisting brew for a brewer that puts out excellent stuff.

This stuff was good.  Pours a dark amber with off-white head.  Hoppy, citrus and malt aroma.  Flavors of malt, caramel, and citrus grapefruit.  Sweet, but balanced with a nice hoppy bitter finish.  Honestly though its not that bitter, more sweetness.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. pours orange\brown with a beige head. Aroma of citrusy hops &  caramel malts. Flavor is overly hoppy for me, i didnt enjoy this at all.

From the Columbus gathering, brought by Sliffy. Browinish orange color with a light tan head. Citrusy-hopppy aroma paried with sweet malt. The flavor was similar, caramel malts with the grapefruity hops. Decent mouthfeel and body with a nice amount of balance.

Bomber. Pours a dark amber red with a thick creamy, massively lacy yellow tan head. Citrus, flowers, fruit and caramel in the nose. Full body, almost syrupy, with moderate carbonation. Taste is much like the smell, but you can toss a touch of peat into the mix. Smooth grapefruit and piney bitterness in the dry, lingering finish. Amazing stuff.

Pours dark brown with a reddish tint - more sediment in this than I expected.  A sturdy tan head form on top and sticks around.  Piney / woody hops are predominant on the aroma - there is some rich caramel background lingering in the background though.  Thick body with a little bit of soft carbonation towards the end.  Starts off with deep roasted malt with some smooth creaminess.  The are sturdy woody hops in the initial taste, but they really come out in the finish.  Aside from the forceful hop on the finish there is a ripple of caramel going through to keep it somewhat balance.  This is a very nice strong ale.  Another home run from Bear Republic.

Bomber. Turned out to be a benchwarmer in a trade with jrob--much to my delight. Pours deep brown to ebony. Steady planes of carbonation saunter up continuously (its thick). Huge dense turbulent tan head that settles to a foamy seastack in the middly of the glass. It laces the glass to an almost pornographic extent. Ultra sweet malts on the nose--caramel comes ringing through, and a little bit of that Crystal earth is there too. Mellow but deep fragrance. Lots of sweet malt flavor right from the attack--theres enough there to capsize a smaller brew but this is balanced lusciously: citrus, spice, molasses. Clean hop finish. Amazing stuff. Nothings better than grabbing a beer youve never heard of off the shelf and having it turn out to be this good.

Bottle thanks to santa: Mahogany colored pour with a white head. Aroma of pine, citrus, caramel. Flavor, citrus and caramel were very prevailant, there was some brown sugar and some spiciness to liven things up as well. Best of the bear republics that Ive had so far.
Columbus gathering beer#2. Brought by Sliffy. Very citrusy hoppy for an ASA. Smooth but a  little over hoppy. Nice combo of malts and hops that overpowered. The end was very sweet.

22oz bottle. Poured dark copper color with an averaged sized off tan head. Aromas of caramel, with oranges, and some pine and very light grapefruit. Tastes of caramel, maple syrup, with pine and citrus.
22 oz.  Nice dark amber color, with light tan head.  Citrus flavor with some caramel.  Smooth, and a nice finish, where you can taste the hoppy flavor of the beverage.

Bottle sampled with Beerded-one. pours bronze with a light tan head. Aroma of citrusy pine hops & some caramel notes. Flavor is smooth, carbonated, slight sharp hops on your tongue, with a slight bitter finish. Great body, good brew.

Poured a deep red-brown color, darker brown than I was expecting. The head was fantastic, almost Belgian pillowy, and full of lacing. The aroma was of caramel malts and pine-floral hops. Flavor was most like an amber ale, as the alcohol wasnt strong at all. The malty base was deep and rich to support the floral-citrus hops in the flavor. If youre a hop head, go for this one... hopped like an IPA, abv of an IPA, but with a strong amber malt base.

Pours a cloudy amber with a huge rocky head that settles into a great creamy layer.  Hops dominate the aroma - flowers, citrus, grapefruit, orange, lemon and tangerine - WOW!  Waifs of caramel malts manage to break through the hop onslaught to offer balance to the nose.  The body notes more fruity goodness - banana, apple, peach and pineapple as well as honey and butterscotch.  This drinks great too, medium body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.  Long, hoppy finish.  Damn nice beer.

Poured a clear dark amber color with a thin off-white head.  Big hoppy aroma with floral and citrus notes.  Sweet malt underneath.  Pine and carmale flavor.  Sweet maltiness most of the way.  Medium bodied.

Shared with csbosox: Poured a bright ruby red, mahogany color.  Wasnt sure if the lighting was playing tricks on me, or if it was really that red.  A fluffy brownish cappacino head sat atop the beer throughout.  The aroma began as some sort of smoked wood, some dry earthy notes and finishing with some prunes.  The flavor is very sweet, a brown sugary-malty with small under a small hoppy flavors masked behind the sweet malts.  The palate was sweet and smooth almost creamy.  Overall a very nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2007 This one really kind of messed with my mind at first.  When I took my first whiff all I got was bacon grease.   I thought csbosox may have not washed my glass very well.  Then I read the lable and picked up Scottish red ale and things started to make more sence.  The beer was poured into a New Belguim Worthy glass.  Dark red with some firey hues near the bottom.  Carbonation rose from the bottom to ample beige head that lasted most of the experience.  The nose was smokey with a touch of roast.  The hops didnt really come out to play until the beer had warmed quite a bit.  The flavor was  very rich with chocolate and roast along with some peaty smokey flavor.  A touch of toffee.  Quite full bodied, and silky over smooth over the tongue.  No unpleasant sensatiolns at all.  Overall, this isnt a beer Id drink very often, but interesting nonetheless.  Thanks for sharing csbosox.
I have to agree with Piscator.  Not that impressed with this one.  More malty than I expected.  Wouldnt buy this one again.

22oz Bomber, no date.  Pours a ruby brown with a medium bubbly brown head. Aroma has some caramel and raisins, grapefruit and a little pine.  Also has a little metal too.  Flavor has some caramel and toasted nuttiness to it, as well as the raisins coming back.  There is bitterness in there fighting the sweet malts, but neither really wins.  Slightly bitter finish.  A well made brew.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: This brewery just dont stop making great beer.  If you want a good red with over the top flavors, then youve found the beer for you.  The commercial description pretty much nails it.

this beer is pretty tasty. Pours amber with a minimal white head.  Aroma is big citrusy hops (a bit tart even) and some fruit malt.  Taste is similar except the caramal malts come out much bigger than one would expect.  A medium mouthfeel that is very refreshing.  This is a perfect beer to switch to when I need a break from these huge beers or uber hopped IPAs.
Bottled.  Pours a deep, dark mahogany with an ivory head.  Malty aroma with some dark fruits and hop notes.   Malty, then hoppy.  A little unbalanced.  Prunes, caramel, oranges.  Astringent finish.
Botte.  Tons of hops, but not so much that they overwhelm the experience.  Pours dark amber to brown with modest white head.  Aroma of spicy hops.  strong but still quite quaffable.

(Bottle 65 cl) Pours a dark amber with tiny impurities. and a creamy, off-white head leaving some laces. Hoppy, citrusy nose. Medium body with some caramel and a dominance of fresh, grapefruitish aroma hops. Quite some bitterness. 300406

Dark red in colour with high carbonation. Strong caramel aromas with some minor grapefruit and floral notes. The caramel fades in the flavor, and roasted elements start to dominate. Theres a bit of sourness there too, along with a harsh bitterness. Medium bodied. An ok beer, but a real disappointment from a usually excellent brewery.
Dark amber color; creamy head. Solid aroma, malt and American hops. Medium malty body, too much dry, with a good amount of resiny hops. Unbalanced and rough.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour with a small head. Very fruity aroma with powerfull burned malt in it. Nice tasty flavour of burned caramel and a nice blend of hops.
Bottle. Ruby colour with a big beige head. Malty, pinetree hoppy aroma and taste, floral. Medium to full body with a light sweet, dry finish.

Bottle.
Cloudy orange red coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of malts, hops and pine needles.
Flavour of malts, caramel, hops, pine needles and grape fruit.
Dry hoppy finish.

Im excited now! Too bad I drank it yesterday. Dark ruby/amber. Frothy, off white head settles to a thin layer. Aroma of toasty caramel malt, and big time piney, resinous hops. Same flavor, lightly sweet with pine cone sized hops. Full, balanced body. More impressive if you think of it as a stronger red. Solid brew.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2009 Pours a mostly clear, deep garnet/brown color; head is light tan, mostly full, and pillowy leaving a small froth after some time and a bit of lace.  Nose is fairly simple but nice with citrus hops (grapefruit), light grassy notes, faint resinous notes, sweet caramel, and hints at raisin.  Flavor is far less hoppy than expected; a toasty, biscuity, caramel sweetness is prominent with some brown sugar and just hints of scotch smoke; the lightly resinous and citrusy hops taking over into the finish with a more than moderate bitterness.  Palate is lively with a medium-full body and an interesting crisp and creamy texture (if that is possible!).  The beer finishes mostly bitter with light underlying notes of sweet caramel and the scotch smoke just hanging around until the end.  This really reminded me of a strong, hefty American pale ale with a slight scottish character.  It is a beer caught between being a drinkable beer and a complex Imperial strength beer.  Something interesting for sure and not something you find in your everyday beers, but something I would buy again whenever I wanted something different from the norm.

In the bomber bottle. Reddish amber in color, in fact, the color of a cheap hair dye on a woman. Has a thin white head.  Honey molasses aroma. At first it has the aroma of a barleywine, but this mellows quickly into sweetness. Plenty of hops, but still manages to whimper away at the end. Fairly good lacing to the beer. The aroma is clearly the best part to this beer. Has a good malt flavor, but its not quite the beer that other Bear Republics are. Massive yeast sludge contained in the bottom. Had this been a better beer, I would have captured it.

Pours burgundy into a trappist glass.  Medium-sized head with good retention and slight lacing as it recedes.  Grass and citrus notes.  Full bodied and well balanced with up-front caramel and a slight metallic long lasting grapefruit finish.

Pours a reddish/caramel with lots o floaties, topped with a creamy, off-whtie head that settles in craters before becoming a thick film. Citrusy-lemon with biscuit aromas strike me as an ESB. Flavor holds thorough bitterness in a creamy mouthfeel finish with sharp, peppery orange rind. 


<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL 60462<font size=-1>
Great redish-brown body. Good Caramel and malt aroma, some yeast accents as well.  Good body, malt and mollasses dominate.  Cool, yet bitter ending.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a medium amber with a large foamy off-white head and plenty of sediment floating around.  Aroma of caramel malts and floral hops.  Caramel, toffee, light brown sugar and rock candy come out in the flavor.  Interesting brew.

Pours a deep red color with a big off white head that kinda clumped.  Good lacing.  Awesome roasted, toasty malt aroma.  Flavor is the same as the aroma, malty.  Nice hop bitterness background.  Medium body.  Darn good beer.

was very surprised by the huge IIPA smell that first came forth.  strong citrus hops.  a dark brown beer, reminds me of a british or nut brown ale.  tiny bubbles, an ugly brown mustard head.  alcohol taste comes first and fast- and surprisingly its welcome.  RB labels this as an ASA, but it defies classification.  close to IIPA.  great taste, so balanced.  some carmel, but not enough to suggest barleywine.  a bear thats probably very enjoyable if drank under any normal circumstances but loses points when drank critically due to its unchallenging nature.  For my own record, this is the beer on which Ive finally decided the thumbnail/nose trick doesnt work on good beer head.  Palate drags a bit.

This is an unusual brew.  Never had one quite like it.....and thats not a bad thing.  Aroma is nutty, much like a Scottish ale.  Flavor is interesting...nutty and caramelly in the front end, with a mild hoppy finish.

This is a wonderful, beautiful beer.  Bear Republic is quickly becoming one of my favorites and this beer is one of the reasons.  The head is absolutely stunning, it hangs on for the entire beer and is so tasty.  I dont think 6.8% is that high for a Strong Ale and it is balanced just right.  A personal favorite, pick it up.

22 oz bottle.  I have sampled this a few times. I really like this beer. Its a great red. Its really balanced, great combination of thickness and cripsy, with the slightly scottish flavor. even the burps taste good!

22 oz. bottle.  Bottle conditioned.  Pours a nice darkish amber.  Clear, with a ~1cm tan head that got a little chunky and then left a nice layer of foam that sticks around and laces the glass.  Aroma is of fruity, floraly hops with a hint of malt sweetness.  Flavor is initially a medium-high level of bitterness, rounded out by some malty sweetness and a medium mouthfeel.  I enjoy this beer and find it pretty drinkable.  I would definitely seek this out again.  No surprise from Bear Republic.
22 oz bottle rich aroma of caramel and hops and yes alcohol slight orange peel on the first palate then loaded with caramel malts. nice bittering hops.godd strong red ale

22 oz bottle, which i believe to beb courtesy of larry pitonka. rich aroma of caramel, american hops, and alcohol.  no real subtlety, but i dont think that the aim is anything subtle.  pretty easy-drinking  for a relatively-strong ale, and like the label describes, i definjitely wouldnt refuse this beer on a moutaintop.  not over-indulgent, but still manages a rich flavor.  yum.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2006 From the bottle.

Pours an attractive caramel red with a good head and sick lacing. I just love the aroma of this beer: fruity centennial hops, baked apples with raisins and cinnamon, warm toffee.

Unfortunately, the aroma is the highpoint. The flavor is a rather ill-suited blend of strong burnt-caramel malts with hints of peat, and the big can-kicking C-hop extravaganza of a good PacNW IPA. After starting off with that marvellous aroma, Im left with a slightly sticky, somewhat syrupy, significantly sweet American Strong Ale. This is the sort of yet-another-sweet-ASA Id drink for #3 of the night at the Big Time Brewery and then forget about by morning. Theres nothing unpleasant about this beer, and I can even safely say that the parts are pretty darn nice -- but the whole falls well short of their sum.

Caramel, caramel and caramel, in aroma and flavor. Deep clear red and crystal clear. Over the top caramel however the hop bitterness cancels it out in the end, Youd call that a balance but one after the other. Nice clean dry finish.

A very nice and easy to drink albeit lighter take on this style.  Seems everyone is trying to make these imperial red styles.  This has some really basic and typical cascade hop profile flavors and caramel malt.  Easy to drink, but boring and run of the mill.
Pours a dark mahagony brown with a small off-white head. Hoppy aroma with fruity and nutty undertones. Strong malty taste with a spicy finish.
Clear dark amber color with a thick off-white head that mostly diminishes. Caramel and hops aroma. Bitter flavor mixed with some sweet caramel.

651 mL Bottle - Courtesy of awaisanen I hate being critical of beers or styles that friends take the time and trouble to send me, especially after Ive specifically asked them for the beer, or theyre taken special time to send me special bottles of (Thanks Andy and Chris), but damn, Im tired of west coast American Strong Ales. Theyre all the same to me! Give me a Belgian or an English Strong Ale any day. These "Double" Red/Amber/Brown/Scottish/whatever with punishing levels of similiar hop profiles just dont light my fire. Yeah, theyre tasty and theyre good carriers of west coast hops, but I really dont feel like the malt character is that much better or more interesting than an IIPA. Anyway, enough ranting, time to get rating. Heres what I though. Pours a hazed light brawny fire, with a finger of clean creamy tan head. Rich, but typical, Cascade orange and pine aroma. Flavor is a punishing orange resin, with fresh squeeze grapefruit and floral with a hint of Jack Pine. Very light gentle toffee in the sweet background malt character. Head is ridiculously lacy. Light nuttiness and a hint of lemon. Palate leaves a grassy fresh bite on the tounge. Good body and thickness. Maybe I need to have a bad example of these attempts before I can appreciate them more. Thanks Andy!

No. 33 is surprisingly not Rolling Rock from the glass lined barrels of old Latrobe.  Every since South Park, I have not been able to envision red rocket as anything but..well, you know.  And if you dont, you really should watch South Park.  Even though were all adults here, Im pretty sure that it may not be appropriate material.  But his Red Rocket is quite an appropriate brew.  Caramel-sweet malts with a whipcrack of hop bitterness blasting off in my mouth.
On tap at the pub. Dark amber-red color with a tan head. Malty hop taste with a nice bit of bitterness

Poured adark red witha long lasting tan head.  A heavy dose of american hops dominate the aroma and balance out the malty flavors.  Once the hop bitterness fades a nice finish of caramel, cherry, fig and pine follow. For my tastes a little softer use of hops would make this an exceptional beer.

Bottle. pours dark amber with a huge off- white head and good lacing. Aroma dominated by cascade hops with a backdrop of caramel and something I cant figure out.....rye maybe? Bold hoppiness in the flavor with a sweet caramel backbone. Finish is dry and bitter. Flavor lacks some complexity, but still a darn respectable beer....as long as you like hops.

Feb. 24, 2006; 22 oz. "bomber"

Ive liked everything Ive tried from this brewery so far, and this "hop-heads" delight is no exception.  Dark, hazy red/amber.  Hops dominate, but their influence is tempered by some sweet malts.  The bitterness long outlasts the other elements though, making it seem stronger than 6.8% ABV -- and its sure to give the uninitiated taster a "bitter beer face!"

(02.09.06) One pint, 6 fl oz brown bottle purchased from DiCarlos, Libertyville, IL.  6.8% ABV. Clear dark red amber hued Scottish ale having a small white head.  Intense caramel and hop aromas.  Medium bodied that starts with light malt sweetness and caramel/fruity/hop flavors.  Some sharpness and hop bitterness develops in the middle.  Finishes with light lingering bitterness.  Smooth.  Well-balanced.  Nice firm malt foundation to support the hop bite.  Simply delicious.

Dark ruby red color with lasting white creamy head.  Big hop/malt aroma. Smelling is very enticing.  I know this gonna be a good brew!!  Flavor is almost nutty malt and big full, well-developed hops. Big strong body and a very nice finish. A beautiful beer that easy very easy to drink.

POurs with a deep red-brown body topped by a thin head with lots of lacing.  Its sweet and malty but bitter and hoppy.  Full of contrasting flavors.  Some caramel shows through as well as a nice grapefruit and pine note.  Medium to full bodied and smooth.

Pours dark read with a big head that is long lasting. The aroma is not as strong as expected, definitely a mix of hops and resins and a touch of roasted nuts.
The flavor is dominated by a hoppy bitterness and roasted notes. The beer is full bodied and just carbonated enough. 
This beer is very unique still fairly smooth and drinkable on a lazy afternoon

Deep ruby red color, slightly cloudy, with smallish light tan head. Aroma has fair amount of citrusy hops, dose of diacetyl, touch of caramel, with a bit of that overripe strawberry note that I associate with over-dryhopping (although I seem to be more sensitive to this than most). Flavor is malty, slightly chewy, with caramel and a round hoppiness. Finish is mildly bitter, mildly acidic, with a bit of alcohol bite. A decent brew, but doesnt overwhelm me.

Bottle:  Smells of strawberries, sugar, a little hoppy, and a bit like Boppin Berry Hi-C.  Reddish amber color.  Average sized tan head.  Good lacing.  Flavor is a cornacopia of things such as malt, carmel, berry, sugar, hops, choclate, pine.  I cant even describe it accuratly.  Long finish is bitter and a bit dry, but tingles on the tongue.  Full bodied.  Average carbination.  Overall, interesting, and good.  Almost and I2PA, but with more malts.
this beer was okay.  thats really all I can say  Flavor was not what I expected - odd because I like the cascade hop beers.
