22 oz bottle. Red and clear with a tan head. Piney hop aroma. Big caramel malty flavor. Very hoppy but not over hoppy. Hops linger throughout beer. Smooth palate. Nicely drinkable. Great.

22 oz bomber. Pours red and clear with a tan head. Piney hop aroma. Chinook? Flavor has a big carmel malt component and a big aggressive hop in the background that lingers. Now, this is not over hopped and the malt shines through, so I am suspecting Chinook again. Rather smooth palate and nicely drinkable, almost reminds me of Arrogant Bastard.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Deep reddish-brown in color with a nice, thick creamy beige head that leaves sticky sheets of lace in my glass. Strong hoppy aromas of grapefruit and pine, citrus, bready and fruity flavors kind of like pineapple cake. Full bodied with a thick and creamy mouthfeel, another good one from this brewery.

Citrusy-orange pine hops in the nose with strong supporting caramel maltiness. Notes of red pepper - slightly pleasantly vegetal. Deep brown with suspended yeast and tan head that diminishes to just cover and ring. Very short flavour with long-lasting bitterness - orange/pine hops and roasted malts. Hops balance the sweet malt. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium body. Assertive bitterness and dry finish makes it feel lighter. Bottle (enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT and Rastacouere).

Clear auburn with a fluffy, off-white head.  Thick hoppy aroma of blood oranges, grapefruit, pine trees, grains and a little caramel.  The body is a little thick but also creamy and carries the bitterness well.  Rustic breads all over the flavor profile with orange marmalade, pine resin and chewy caramel.  At times I get this odd stinky cheese thing which isnt good, but not as bad as one would think.  Not my favorite offering from Bear Republic--very bitter without much balance and only decent flavors.

deep amber color, thick creamy beige head. aroma somewhat dominated by malts, lots of caramel/toffee (i admit i have a hard time distinguishing between the two) and moderate hoppiness. it recognizes itself as a scottish style ale, and there are plenty of elements to back it up...slight peatiness, lots of malts...but the hops set it apart from your typical scottish ale, e.g. the hoppy finish.

Pours turbid burgundy with huge white head and lace.  Aroma of malt, toffee, cabernet.  Tastes very malty, hoppy, with a somewhat tart finish.  I tastes hints of cabernet, cognac, port.  Finishes hoppy, malty, slightly tart and dry.  The finish reminded me a little of a scottish ale/red ale/IPA combination.  Unbelievably complex.

Noteworthy red fruit plunged in pleasing caramel...All is rinsed with a sensational dose of grassy, piney and grapefruity hops...Apricots are carried by the hoppy ending for a well-integrated, barley-winish red ale...

Very dark brown with an honest light brown foamy head. It smells exactly what it pretends to be, a good scotch ale deep malt profile with a bit of alcohol and hop hints. While they definitely dony seem agressive in the aroma, they become much more expressive once you venture toward a sip and attack with pin grapefruit flavors. Unlike many others though, theyre really just a complement here and are well integrated with the toffee and caramel malt. Its not particularly complex, but drinks easily and didnt appear shy after 10 barley wines or so. Rather assertive fullness with medium fitting carbonation. Extremely well executed, which has become a trademark for Bear Republic in my book.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ republic brewpub. Pretty intense, heavily hopped. Pine, grapey, grapefruity, and quite bitter in the finish, pretty tasty stuff.
A nice piney, floral big hop aroma.  Color is deep reddish brown with a tan head.  Malty, almost fruity, bitter hop flavors.

amber red, small white head.  big hop aroma with plenty of citrus and pine and earth.  the flavour holds more fruit, with caramel and red liquorice, but the hops are big enough to balance and contribute to a sticky mouthfeel.  like a well executed big take on an amber ale.  nice.
Had it on tap. Very full and tasty flavor. Full of hops and malt. The main thing that comes out at me is the great robust hop flavor. This is definitily a good beer.

. Lots of hops, both bitter and aggressive and dry aftertaste and great with meat dinner. Full bodied. Reminds me of a Samuel Smith. Tan head, sprucy hops, toasted taste, some malt. Even a hint of smoke.

Deep amber in colour.  Aroma was quite hoppy with lots of caramel and some malt.  Flavour was very hoppy again, lots of citrus, caramel sweetness with some malt showing up.  Full bodied.  Finishes dry with a mild bitterness.  Very well balanced.

Aroma is hoppy to the max! Hazy reddish brown, small cream head. Full hops taste, lots of that citrus crunch. Malt is present and appreciated. Well balanced, full bodied. Lovely example. Thanks for bringing this one IPFreely.

Im rather surprised that no one talks about the peaty character which provides the richness under all those hops.  There is some real Scottish ale character to this.  What makes it extremely fun is the west coast hops which give spice and citrus twang.  Really wonderful stuff.  Drank it while watching the movie Straw Dogs--fitting, as both the beer and the movie focused on the intersection of British and American style.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2008 trappist glass: fantastic aroma of a sweet and spicy forest. great taste as well. soapy, but nice head with good lacing. dark brown body with red highlight. tastes like a spicy ale. it has a nice creamy palate with a bite! grapefruit, pine, burning wood from a campfire. american strong ale? egh, "bastardized scottish" thats more like a pale red. i guess. i like it a lot! ----- UPDATE 9/11/08: very twangy dark fruit aroma and flavor, with some caramel; very creamy; interestingly different... I certainly see the Red and Scottish influence.

This beer is all about the hops - but just enough maltiness is present to show some attempt at balance.  Dark clear amber body with a full cream colored head. Strong piney hop aroma accompanied by a nearly hidden malt.  Initial strong hop flavor with a bit a malt added for balance followed by a dry hoppy and slightly roasty aftertaste.

Honey, sweet ale, characteristic hop element, rater grassy kind of hops. Hoppy, well made bitterness. That medium bodied ale got malt as a backbone to crowning hops. Nice fusion. Very drinkable, well balanced ale. Highly recommended!
Slightly hazy red-amber colour. Big aroma of west coast hops. Flavour has a nice roasty dark malt backbone to hold up the hoppy front end. Good stuff.
Deep reddish brown color, tan head. Lots of sweet, dark malts and big green hops. The flavor was almost too hoppy. Fuller body, bitter finish, dry. Pretty nice.

thanks to TimDoug for this one! Body is dark amber with some red hues in it. Nice foamy white head. Aroma is super hoppy with some sewwtness. Taste is hops bitterness with some sweet hints.  A great beer!

Clear dark amber. Finger of beige foam. Big, hoppy aroma w/ some underlying sugary malt. Resiny feel. Big, hoppy flavour w/ good malt background. Also has some peaty notes & a dry, lingering bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2011 2011-12-03. Brown headless body. 3+ Nice hoppy aroma, green leafy touches, mild malt. 7+ Similar flavour, modest bitterness throughout. 7+ Modest malt with a kiss of rye. Average bodied palate. Decent. 7+/3/7+/3/15+ 3.5 Cask at Goodbar, Buffalo 
2004-05-XX. Dark brown amber colour with a big hoppy aroma, which also dominate the flavour. Lots of malt present but the essence of this beer is overwhelmingly hoppy. Liked this one a lot. 10/3/8/3/17 Bottler shared at RB Gathering at DougShoemakers
Garnet/mahogany body with tan head.  Aroma on the sweet side.  Some floral and caramel and citrus.  Full body.  Flavor is strong and rich.  Potent is a word.  Definitely a strong ale.

I quite like this beer!  Somewhat similar to Stone Arrogant Bastard in its well-balanced hoppiness.  Full body, robust, decent looking copper body.  Very California with its hops and grapefruit.  A hint of sweetness and chewy. I think I happily drank too much of this beer.  A Great ASA!

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2004 22 oz. bottle: poured into a pyrex measuring glass.   mm, smells real good and hoppy.  a roasty character and citrus/ sour fruit notes, but mostly hops.  poured a nice deep amber color, with chunks of yeast floating, and a thick tan head.  mmm, tastes like an ipa, but different.oooh.  yes, this beer is good. i really like bear republic.

On tap at the Blind Tiger Ale House, NYC - April 2004: Nice dark red color with a little layer of a head. Intense hoppy grassy nose - sharp almost. Hoppy taste, inclinging sharp kick - long lasting. Great.

Clear deep ruby with a massive frothy reddish light brown head.  Aroma of caramel, grapefruit, pine, milk chocolate and roast.  Medium slightly creamy body with soft carbonation.  Fruity, earthy flavor of dried cherry, red apple, plum, apricot, pine, grapefruit, roast and a hint of chocolate. Slightly astringent.  A big beer, but still fairly drinkable. Very good.

Unusual orange-ruby color and rippled beige head. Smells like an IPA, at least initially. Aroma of grapefruit, malt, fruits, and mild smoke. Smoke is more apparent in the flavor. Very hoppy. More hoppy than necessary, I think. Has a cologne-like astringency to it. Still good though. Ample body plus significant carbonated feel. Novel and interesting. Thanks loweredsixth.

This is one great beer on the nose and in the attack.  After that its a little disappointing as it fades away a bit faster than I would like.  This beer has tons of upside if the boys at bear keep working on it.

22 oz bottle: dense foam, reminds me of fluffy sponge cake.  Strong gooey alcohol/caramel nose with effervescent cascade hop cones along with honey suckle flowers and sharply fresh grass.  Thick pine sap and heavy grainy malts wrap the tongue as lively carbonation - with tingly vanilla beans sooth the mouth.  Bitter pine bark in the finish along with some moist green grapes, enjoyable and solid brew.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2005 Wow! Another excellent Bear Republic brew. Deep mahogany with a thick off-white head. (the 2nd half of the bomber pours with a ton of suspended particles). Nice strong hoppy and lightly roasty aroma. Taste is moderately sweet with notes of roasty malt, some dark fruit, grapefruit/citrus, caramel, chocolate and a ton of hops. Feels like an interesting mix between a red Scottish ale and an IPA. Bitter, roasty aftertaste. Mouthfeel is perfect; full, round and creamy with subtle carbonation. Lacing clings to the glass like puffy clouds, great head retention. I love this brewery. Highly recommended!

Deep amber with beige head and great lacing.  Very full bodied and sweet with lots of crystal malts, with some bitterness in the end.  Smell is very hoppy and slightly malty.  Overall a very good beer.
Deep reddish brown, with a lingering beige head. Nose well hopped with some malt undertones. Flavour starts malty followed by a surge of hops hops hops.

Dark brown ruby with a big frothy tan head. Very Very Very cool cascade. The nose has lots of hops more so than Id like, the taste starts off very sweet and suggary than almost instantly BAM lots of bitter hops. Intersting to say the least, I see where they were going here, howver I just dont like the hops.

Upon first view of the bottle, I thought maybe I was seeing a revision of the now defunct Rainier Breweries Jet City Rocket Ale.
Completely different brew. 

This brew pours a gorgeous hazy brown, with a very stellar beige/white head. It smells of caramel malt with slight cocoa notes meshed with wood and earth. The taste delivers all the aroma promises ; sweet, with a strong, prominent malt character up front. In the middle, I found hints of coffee and wood.....with an almost oily, silky smooth mouthfeel. Finishes very spicy, with a sucker-punch of an alcohol singe...Very complex, as many Scottish heavies I have tried...a bit unfriendly and confused, which knocks the drinkability a bit. Never boring though, this may be a revisited brew that may change my mind on that. A daring variation on the style

Deep red in color with a white head and pretty good lacing.  Sweet fruity(cherries?) aroma mixed with a touch of floral hops.  Very hoppy taste.  Big hop bite after an almost sweet start, probably those fruits i caught in the aroma.  A bitter finish that was akin to orange rinds. Very long drawn out finish.  Very tasty.
Does have that deep red color. Semi-sweet aroma of cherrys and hops. First taste is a plentous of different flavors. Floral,citrus, hops, malts, piney and a little caramel. Smooth and refeshing.

The hops immediately brought Rogue Skullsplitter to mind.  The body is red as advertised, clear, and topped by a thin off-white/light tan head.  Aroma has lots of citrus and pine hops, and also caramel.  Hops definitely dominate the flavor profile with a piney, spicy, citric character.  Hops flavor is built on a malt foundation of caramel, brown sugar, and dark fruit.  These elements blend well together and this beer is smooth around the edges.  Thanks Dan (jah noth) for the bottle!

Wow, talk about hoppy smelling...

Pours a dark redish-brown with a large chunky head that never goes away but to leave a thick lace down the sides of the glass.

Scent is, well, floral hops.

Taste is definately floral hops as well; the dry-hopping is quite apparent. This gets better as it warms and becomes more complex. Caramel malt and some darker fruits and citrus are present as well.

Mouthfeel is crisp due to the (Cascade?) hops and is refreshing. Overall this is very nice, but for the style I still prefer Deschutes Cinder Cone Red.

This is a very interesting beer from the guys at Bear Republic up in Healdsberg CA.  It poured with a thin beige head.  Color is dark copper/brown, shines beautifully red when held up to the light.  Aroma is hops and rye, nicely fruity.  Malts are sweet and carmel tasting, but subdued as the hops begin to dominate soon into the taste.  It's not overly bitter tho, just pleasent with a piney/citrusy taste in the typical west coast style.  Medium body, finish is just pleasent hop bitterness.  ighly recommended.

Nice blend of hops and malt...thought I detected some rye. A ton of citrus hops that barely missed overpowering the caramel, brown suga notes. Not a lot of aroma beyond the standard 'beer' elements. Bready and only balanced when well-above room temperature. Good, not great.

Unfiltered rye. Cakey and rocky off-white layer of foam. Raw and bushy hop aromas with notes of orange zest, plaster, and wet paper. Figgy, mushy malts struggle to the top along with barky malts, cocoa, lemon oil, and honeysuckle. Thick, sappy texture. Feathery carbonation. Thick malt flavors are immediately countered by a rubbery astringency. Bushy hops and lemon oils pucker the cheeks while the hop bitterness squashes the subtle caramel flavors. Brief earthy flashes of moss and peat, yet again, succumb to the sappy hops. Astringently waxy, rindy finish with just enough delicate flower notes and powdery malts to soften it up. Remnants of oxidation, toasted malt, hop leaf, and fig flavors. Pretty rough around the edges, although a solid stab which was much-improved at 65 degrees.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Awesome red color, with a great hop aroma. Hops start out with a bang, then a sweet caramel flavor takes over. This is good stuff.
Chewy, chewy red that is about half way  to a porter. Mahogany? Really enjoy this. With al the malts and all the hops the finish just goes on forever. Mmmm good.

Thanks to jeffc666 for this one! Reddish brown body. Small tanned head. Very citrusy and hoppy nose. The tongue is met with a hoppy orange, and malt mix. There is somesweetness lingering in there and it makes it's appearance during the finish as well, along with, yep, hops. Good beer!

Pours a deep, amber with hints of redness. A frothy tannish-white head develops, leaving ample gobs of lace trailing down the glass.

The aroma is complex; sweet caramel raising bread toast, fruity cough-drop deeply enveloped in toastiness. Piney hops are also quite apparent.

Bold, sweet up front, rich mouthfeel. Alcohol lingering on the palate, not hiding but residing. Creamy, caramel malts and a creeping hoppy finish that closes with a lustrous flourish. Beauiful ale.

A nice red hue and a frothy tan head.  A very pleasant hoppy aroma that is pine and floral in nature.  Nice balance between the hops and the malt, with a great mouthfeel.  A very nice beer; very drinkable.
this beer has a spicy tangy flavor. a mid brown color with a white head. not bad.

1/25/04.  Poured out of 22 oz. bottle, bought at Liquorama in Upland, CA 12/5/03.  Pours a deep, clear crimson amber, very fluffy off-white head with very good lacing.  Aroma is quite nice, a little bit like a fruity barley wine-- berries, some cream, cake, and a little bit of spice.  Flavor is pale and creamy malts, still a little cakey, and a hint of hop bitterness along with the lightly drying red/amber spice.  Very good stuff.    Very smooth, lighter-than-water mouthfeel with medium-thin body and creamy texture.  Finish pumps up the bitterness a touch and extends medium-long with a cool malt hum-- a little bit of smokiness even.  Somewhat sticky on the lips.  Quite a good brew, very easy-drinking and enjoyably unique in flavor.  Another solid one from Bear Republic.
Nice fresh hop nose. Palate is fruity, malty, hoppy, & smoky. Finish is smooth and flavorful. Bad name and label.
Big hop taste that poured like a stout. Very unique malt taste. Not being a brewer, I don't know what they did, but it worked. Smoky, mellow finish.

Very dark orangish red color with a fairly large off-white head. Extremely hoppy aroma with a hint of sweet malt. Flavor is not as strong as I would expect from the aroma, but consists of fairly strong grapefruit hopps bitterness and lightly malty flavors. Nice medium carbonation, and a fairly dry finish. Pleasant, but not quite what I expected.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2004 Malty, fruity, spicy and hoppy aroma, heavy with brown sugar sweetness and mingling with butterscotch, cinnamon, tart orange, tangerine and grapefruit, caramel, milk chocolate, a slight roastiness, herbal, spicy hop and some faint yeast notes and woodiness.  Deep, dark red-brown color, unfiltered but lacking much sedimentation, with a good-sized creamy, uneven, off-white head and spectacularly thick lacing.  Malty, toasty and sweet to start, becoming tart and fruity with suggestions of orange, apricot and white raisin, and turning substantially earthy, hoppy, spicy and moderately bitter.  Aftertaste is balanced and rather complex, all of the above ingredients just kind of hanging around for various intervals of time, showing a bit of aggressive hop here, some reddish malt there.  Interesting mouthfeel, smooth and creamy but effervescent with the tiny bubbles creating an intriguing backdrop for the multitude of flavor attributes.  Quite a unique beer, proving more difficult to rate than most, it's features somehow elusive yet prominent, like a sense memory that remains tantalizingly just out of reach...

in feeble light, i had to guess that this  wooly-topped brown pour was as solid as a totem pole grizzly bear-- with the reddish blush of dusk lightly warming the edges.  closer inspection and greater wattage however reveals lots of murky peach tones and a snow dome's worth of dancing detritus within.  aroma is an even blend of tanin-touched malts and orange peel hop bitters.  it's a strawbroom that's been brushed with smoked molasses and mixed with apple juice and vodka. soft carbonation entertains without favoritism both tea bitterness and chutney sweetness in the flavor.  those heavy monk's bread malts and lemony hops and yeast are bold and yet there is a watery feel as well.  like a spider playing 'twister', it manages to cover all the requisites of several beer types simultaneously with effortless balance.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark amber color with a medium-sized yellowish beige head.  Had a grapefruit dominant aroma with a citrus and hoppy flavor.

Deep amber red, very nice creamy head.  Aroma initially of grapefruit with some roasted malt, and a touch of something sweet.  Became smokier as it warmed.  Flavors also evolved tremendously, starting with a citric hop quality, then in the middle stages had quite a bit of roasty tang to it.  The end had a smoky malt sweetness with some balancing earthy hops.  An interesting beer to drink, quite good.

Bottle: Nice smokey, carmel nose. Great clean dark amber color, though I poured last bit in seperate glass got some sediment. Small to no head. Great smokey malt & pine citrus(grapefruit) mix. Smooth, tad creamy dryish smokey finish. Wow, nice mix of styles. Another great brew from Bear Republic.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark russet color with a majorly thick finger high head of tight cream colored froth that installs itself on top; slowly puffed away form the center outwards where a thin skim and fairly thick collar stay present the whole glass through and lacing in webby sheets that sticks well at first but then disintegrate more as it goes. Aroma is pleasant of a nice leafy hop bringing a smooth woody earthy dryness over the top of some dulled fruityness and toasted, nearly burnt malts. Taste has a very nice balance of toasted malts and grassy/woody dry hops, starts smooth and lightly sweet of malts as it turns toasted with a substantial building over the palate of the toastyness with the wood dryness sneaking in just past midway and making a home through to the finish where it mixes nicely with notes of dulled dried fruit of apricot, peach, and raisin, and finishes with an overall super nice earthy dryness and texture. Feel is close to full, detains a smoother start then raises from there into the drying finish, slim toastyness lingers. This is a very good amber, one of the better ones I've had with a nice dry hop profile that was hardly bitter in any form, just some tiny glimmers of bite that made this a very nice drinker with a certain complexity that was favorable to my palate. Good stuff eh.

Pours a beautiful deep ruby red, with a mostly lasting creamy tan head that laces lightly.  Aroma is toasted malts, caramel and a slew of piney hops.  Flavor mostly toasted malts, with a hint of sweet caramel, the middle and end brings in an onslaight of pine & citrus from the hops.  Big, full body, goes down easy, flavors linger nicely on the tongue.
Caramelly amber.  Deep and hoppy, with both nice bitterness and flavor.  There is a slight touch of smokiness in the background.  Nice.
22 oz. Bottle.  Poured a dark ruby red color with a long lasting tan head.  The lacing was amazing! Deep in flavor, rich in hops and overall it was delicious!

In bitterness, the Red Rocket falls just below the Racer 5, and has considerably more malt, though hops continue to dominate the flavor profile.  A beautiful, rich light brown color, with a lasting beige fluffy head, the Red Rocket gives off a strong hoppy aroma, warning you of what's to come.  Sort of a Double IPA with malt.  Very good.

03 Bottle. One of the best looking beers I've seen. Reddish brown mahogany, bright but wavy. Tons of sediment due to bottle conditioning. Very hazy. Big rich yellow-beige head.  Incredible amount of lacing.  Smells of lots of bittersweet hops, maybe the slightest bit of scotch-like aroma.  Flavor is mostly hoppy (pretty high alpha content) but has a well balanced medium dry caramel malt backbone.  Creamy texture.  Finish is clean and surprisingly not that bitter.  Touch of light roasted barley.  I almost think there is a touch of scotch-like alcohol flavor, but I might just be thinking that.  Spicy, full, balanced and very very drinkable.  The flavor could stand to be a bit more complex, however.

Reddish brown hue with a very nice creamy off-white head that just doesn't quit, very good lace. The aroma hints of pine, grapefruit, roasted malt, butterscotch, wood, and spice. The taste has a solid backbone of malt and sweetness to balance against the hoppy pine character and bitterness. The additional undertones of burnt wood, light citrus, and blended spices work well and enhance the flavor. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with the expected dry finish. What a wonderful brew, big yet sublime, surprising. Recommended.
This is some good stuff - certain elements remind me of Arrogant Bastard - lots of malts, but not overly sweet, still plenty of hops in the mix - caramel and chocolate - tasty and heavy.
reddish amber with a big glassy, peach colored head and a hoppy aroma...piney, spicy hop flavors and some grainy notes too..some grapefruit rind in the finish..
A really nice malty/hoppy beer, with a big American hop nose and bitterness, well balanced by a sweet, caramel-y/roasty malt body. An excellent strong amber ale.

Big beautiful frothy head that leaves very nice lacing. Deep clear ruby color. Malty hoppy aroma, citrus and sweetness. Man this beer smells good. Flavor is awesome, big malty chewiness balanced by a very nice hop bitterness. Body is medium full and very chewy. What a beer. This beer deserves better reviews then it gets!

22 oz bomber.  This may be the most under-rated brew i have ever sampled.  This brew was fantastic!  "A bastardized Scottch ale" is correct!  The appearance on this thing was garrnet red, with lots of rocky off-white head.  Aroma was awesome!  big, malty, sweet, and hops-i loved this aroma!  Flavor was very well balanced between nice carmal/roasted malts and a nice dose of american hops.  I so need more of this stuff!!  this is one hell of a brew!

Ruby red, tan head. raw hops and caramel aroma. I see here in my notes that I described it as "Mmmmmmmmmmmm drinky". Look, it had been a long tasting session and I was pretty worn out by Tennessee's 5 overtime win over Alabama, so maybe my tasting notes are a little, you know, unclear. At any rate, there was apparently a veggie and "raw grass" (as opposed to cooked grass?) flavor, too. dry, and hoppy to the finish, which is also described here as "butu".

Lofty, rocky and lasting light-tan head above a murky brown. Wonderful nose, loaded with a bouquet of flowery hops. Moderately carbonated with a "second," underlying layer of texture that was incredibly smooth and creamy on the tongue. Very aromatic and complex, with notes of campfire, citrus (orange, grapefruit). Malts were deep, thick, satiating, smoky, burnt and rich. Tingly hops in the finish ... complemented by a healthy dose of bitterness. Chewy, exuding flavors ... huge malts and big hops in this beer. Good stuff.

Nice dark ruby color with small white head.  Good lacing.  Nice aroma...mainly hops on the nose with a light malt presence.  The taste is roasted malt up front with hop bitterness after the swallow.  A very interesting beer.

Very dark amber colour with a light brown head. Strong aroma of hops, malt and a subtle tropical fruit aroma. Medium to Full-bodied; Strong roasty/smoky malt characteristic with noticeable hoppiness. Aftertaste bittered from both the hops and the roasted malt. Overall, a crazy mix between a scottish and an APA, but works out fairly well. I must thank Jah_noth (Dan) for the local trade and the generous treat! I sampled this 65 cL bomber on 17-October-2003.

A very dark reddish brown appearance. Thick foamy tan head. Very strong aroma of malts and hops. The flavor is quite intense. One sip I the malts shout to me, the next sip the hops make themselves known. Nice "roasty" aftertaste. Excellent!

Pours a dark red, good head and nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is malt heavy with some detectable hop presence.  Taste is malty, very dry hoppy finish.  Great mouthfeel, a little bit to thin perhaps.  Interesting ale.

Very unique ale.  Red Rocket pours a very dark reddish brown with big off white head that is retained.  Flavor is extremely unique.  There is a strong hop presence with an equally strong roasted/smokey malt flavor.  Tasty.

Deep ruby amber.  Sticky light tan head.  Malt, metallic, slightly piney, earthen nose.  Starts sweet, caramel, lightly metallic, rich earthy hops, resinous, juicy, very drinkable, light bodied...Finishing, stone and chalky, grapefruit and piney goodness.  Very quaffable, alcohol is definately hidden.  I like it, I like it alot!
Copper red color, full head, hoppy nose. Malts dominate at first but then massive hops kick in. Lingering bitter finish. Unique.

This deep red brew almost headed in the wrong direction when the typical Scottish ale malt flavors kicked in - I love the thickness of the malt, but there's always an odd taste to it.  Well, I needn't worry about that this time - a HUGE hop kick comes in to save the day and pummel some of the malts into submission.  What it ended up as was an exceptional strong ale with a wee bit of Scotch malt - tasty!
Big balanced hop/malt aroma and flavor with just a bit of smoke thrown in. This is the kind of beer I could just curl up with and watch the snow come down.

Reddish brown with a nice head.  Peaty malts and massive hops hide every bit of alcohol. Caramel notes are strong at end. Hoppy in that West Coast tradition, even if it was supposed to be a Scottish Ale!
Lemon merangue appearance.  Hoppy nose, very hoppy nose.  Brown color, with a neat head.  Interestingly fun.  Bitter like.
It did have a nice red color with a smooth almost sweet flavor.  Very drinkable.  reccomend it.

Sparkling clear copper ale with a lovely, reddish glow. Small, creamy, khaki-colored head with good lacing.
The aroma is malty and very fruity. Notes of caramel, blackberries, burnt rubber and pineapple.
Very malty and sweet flavor up front with blasts of berries and toffee. The hops really kick in to almost balance things out on the backside. The sweet malt wins out in the end, but the hops are really assertive. Left Coast beer! Left Coast beer!
Medium to full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Long, very lightly bitter, acetic finish.
Unusual, very good Scotch ale.

This is quite possibly the best beer I have ever tried.  The deep red color is very invitingbut the taste.  Yum.  The balance is outstanding.  I have never had a beer with such hops that had such a sweet malty kick.  A must try for all hop heads.  A real gem!

Very nice.  Could it be that the once great Mendicino Brewing boys are in on this one.  I noticed that the mendicino brews are now "brewed" in NYC or something.  That beer is now worthless in my book but this stuff is super fantastic. Keep up the good work and don't sell out to coors or miller or bud.

Nice Beer.  Redish brown with medium lasting tan head.  Very inviting aroma of malt and hops.  Well balanced sweet malt with slight smoke and the flavor of hops and bitterness.  The separation of this is also noticeable.  Even the finish remains balanced.  Didn't notice the 6.9%.
Dark reddish-brown with a tan foamy head that laces nicely. You can detect the bitter hops and sweet malt in the aroma and it does not dissapoint in the mouth. Excellent creation, enjoyed very much.

Beautiful clear reddish brown color with a creamy off white head - good lacing. Nice balance between toasted malt sweetness and hop bitterness, certainly well-hopped but not overbearing.  Very enjoyable.
nice strong hoppy flavor, wonderful dark blood ruby color, a nice smooth flavor, sweetly scented
Reddish brown color with a nondesipating white head. Smells hoppy, sweet and carmel. Taste bitter spicey hops and a medicine taste.
An amber color with an off white head. A malty hop aroma with hints of citrus and an almost metallic nose. A little spicey with hops and a nice caramel malt.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2003 Wasn't anything like I expected but completely satisfied none the less. Not your typical Red Ale, more like a cross between a Red Ale and A Porter. Poured thick with a beautiful fluffy head and thick lacing around the glass as I drank it. In fact, I was really impessed by the thickness of the lacing and the beautiful almost mountainess head. Tasted real nice with a great balance of hops (just enough to provide some fragrance and bitterness) and malt which was of a toasty smoky Stout like roast. This was my first encounter with Bear Republic and surely a sign of good things to come.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: This had an odd oily pour, very stout like.  A caramel color beer with a medium light tan lasting head.  Initially floral hops aroma with layers of malt, toffee, and brown sugar.  A subtly sweet malt/toffee taste dominated by hops, but not overpowered by them.  Chewy.  Finish is residual hops that do not leave the mouth dry.  Refreshing if you can get by its thinly veiled comparison to a Scottish ale.  Take care to keep the yeast in the bottle as this makes this a bitingly bitter beer.
Dark ruby. Very hoppy aroma. Flavor has more character than the aroma would suggest. Some smoke. Good stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2004 -Bear Republic comes in with another heavyweight.  This time they've taken a rightfully obscure style, Scottish Ale, and turned it into a mandatory periodic purchase.  The hops blast is a fantastic counterpunch to the rich malt profile.  It's a malt profile that stands by itself... which is so unlike the malt profiles of other Scottish Ales that tend to get lost in the "smokiness" of the style and ultimately come across as thin.  Not the Red Rocket, there is a concerted effort by the hops, malt, and alcohol in attacking the smokiness.  Ultimately, the forces of good (hops, malt, and alcohol) win out over the forces of evil (uninspired thinness of character typical of the style).  The result is a full-spectrum completeness that has been begging for years from this style.                                                 ........................  Mixing notes:  With Red Rocket the hops do a fine job of wiping the smoke off the palate, like ginger at a sushi bar.  If you're looking to linger over the smoke as it usually carries over between sips of Scottish Ale then forget about it.  However, since the beer has a very resinous (but not oily or slick) character it can be used to some advantage when exploring the malt profiles of other beers... maibocks, in particular.  My favorite combo is a 22oz Rocket followed by a bottle of Ayinger Maibock.  I'm not sure what it is but the malt flavor that comes out of the Ayinger after drinking a Rocket is nothing short of fantastic.  And the effect lasts throughout the whole bottle of maibock... such is the "lingering" nature of the Rocket (what do you know, it's a Scottish Ale after all).  Finally, both of these dogs clock in at 6.8% ABV and after the first round your mental acuity becomes inversely related to the volume of your voice.
Hoppy aroma. Very smoky malt flavor. Hoppy finish but well balanced. Burnt malt flavor gives this beer some character.
Beautiful dark reddish brown color. It's clear, w/ a tan head. Nice hoppiness, but not to the degree of über-IPA's on the West Coast. Leaves you w/ a warm glow.

Fresh hoppy aroma and a deep copper color.  Good malt backbone, but overpowered by a sticky bitter finish.  The bottle calls it a "Bastardized Scottish red ale."  I guess in some respects, this is true, but I still found it to be too hoppy.  There is a recognizable faint smokiness about ten seconds after the swallow, but that's about it as far as Scottish ale goes.
Nice malt aroma with a subdued West Coast hoppiness.  A fair amount, maybe too much (N'western varities) for the style.  Smoked, peat whiskey malt.  Very drinkable.

Very dark, red coloring. Has a medium head, and left quite a bit of lace on the glass. Hoppy, which is nice, but also had some malty overtones to it. Kind of a hybrid between an IPA and a red ale. Aroma is nice, not too sweet.

Deep red, clear mahogony.  Nice rich head.  More bitter than expected.  Malty sweet with a dry finish.  Different and complex.  Kind of like an IPA meets red.  Very enjoyable.  Perhaps just a bit flat and bland in the finish.

Cherry stained tea topped by pale tan head that is nicely creamy and lasting. The aroma is sweet and has a slight hop bite. Nicely malty flavor, toffee, smoky peat, really doughy character. Teh hops don't quite seem to match the malt though. Obviously not in the same class as Hop Rod Rye and Racer 5 but still a quality beer.

Red-amber color with a medium head.  Earthy hop nose with doughy malt to balance.  Thick mouthfeel with a nice hopd profile throughout.  Meaty malts with bread dough and toffee showing nicely.  Bitter, clean finish.  Very nice.

Ruby/amber color with a bubbly light tan head.  Fresh hops and mild peat aroma.  Deep malt flavors greet your palate.  Flavors of peat and dark toffee, along with a slight juniper/medicinal tint.  A scottish ale with a kick- no doubt. Outstanding lingering malt and peat flavors, that remind me of chewing specialty malts. A heavy wee heavy.
Bright ruby color with thin head and nose of sweet roast grain.  Subtle smokey flavors with a huge hop finish.

Brown-red color with a nice white head. Huge hops aroma...pine, citrus, and some sweet maltiness. The flavor was big...malty, hoppy, and everything else in between. This beer packs an alcohol kick...it got me more buzzed than a 6.8% abv should.

Pours a dark clear amber color with a big, off-white rocky head that lingers for a while. Strong hoppy and malty aroma. Medium bodied and strong, quite a robust scottish red ale (bastardized according to the brewers...What the hell is a Scottish red ale?). Flavor is quite malty at first, but the hops kick in towards the end and in the finish. Very good, me likes, me drink again..
Nice dark amber color.  Malty aroma with a hint of roastiness.  Nice roasted flavor that ends slightly sweet.  Quite an enjoyable brew.

Bottle.  Deep red with a laced beige head.  Slight fruit aroma with flavors of berries and a dry finish.  Tap in mid-October: Reddish brown with a strong hop bitterness.  Malty aroma and a little sweet.  Interesting graininess with some smoke burnt flavors.
sausagy, definetly red, monster head, good hops.

Pudding brown with less head then a debutante.  Malt for days, fresh cookie and chocolate with some resinous hops with little bits of brewers yeast laguidly floating around the body.  Malt covered hop cones, campfire smokieness, huge in the mouth, Long vinous finish that tapers into an acorn aftertaste.
looks like more of a brown rocket ale, surprising smokiness and nicely hopped

This brewery consistently surprises me. It begins with an intriguing malty smell that is reminiscent of sniffing a handful of crushed barley. The head is big, solid white, and wanders around the sides of the glass like icy stalagmites. This is really red, no lie, a very copperish red, but still red and crystal clear. The malt in this is very pronounced and hits you with a nice butterscotch sweetness. It goes a long way in capturing the raw essence of malted barley without too much overkill. The elegant hop finish is a wonderful counterpoint to the big malt taste and balances out just right. Wonderful beer.
on tap GABF 02:  Hoppy aroma with enough malt nose to let you know it has some.  Red color with nice head, full robust body, ends fairly bitter for a while.  Flavor is deep and wonderful.

Every single beer Ive had from this brewery has been great. This was no exception. Great balance of hops/malt. Beautiful dark red color. This is what I like in a Scottish ale. Bear Republic cant go wrong.

beautiful deep amber/mahogony. Decent head and lace. Nose of carmel, peaty smokiness, sprucy hops are there but not in the forefront. Thick body, sweet caramelly like malts, peaty twangs, maybe subtle spices lurking about, sappy hops in abundance but kept at bay nicely by the sweetness of the malt. I thought it was gonna be hoppier to be honest. This is good but missing a bright spot, flavors seemed a bit dull/muddled. Maybe its a little to thick? But anyways, its good, hearty, smooth and has a nice kick. Thank you herbjones.

Deep opaque red.  Nice little off-white head that stuck around.  An excellent ale, very hoppy and dry.  Quite woody.  As it warms, the malts become a bit more prevalent, with an increasing sweetness and a nice, toasty finish.  Get woodiness and a hint of brandy.  Palate is glorious, full and soft, just felt wonderful in the mouth.
Deep red color, medium head. Roasted malts, nice mellow hop signature. Some sweetness. Finish is clean and soft. Aftertaste is slightly bitter, some sweetness.
Like a cross betweeen an IPA and a Scotch Ale.  The aroma is pure NW citrus hops, while the flavour is more chocolatey, but still has a nice hop bite.  I like!!
Deep copper/ruby color. Sticky, creamy light tan head.  Burnt caramel and light cocoa flavor.  Nice hoppy bitter finish.

Big beautiful off-white head atop deep, reddish-brown brew. Lots of maltyness in the nose. Smells of cinnamon and a bit of brownsugar as well. Take a drink. Sugary sweetness that fades to a slight coffee-like bitterness. Has a bit of spicyness upfront as well. Really great beer.

does not taste like drinking wood.
Very hoppy, dark ale. Taste like drinking wood.
This is one damned tasty brew. Copper hued with a wood fruit nose. Complex flavors that take center stage as the glass warms. Yes, similar to Stones AB but a bit mellower. I do love them both!

When I placed the order for this through Liquid Solutions my intention was to order the Hop Rod Rye Ale. I guess I got my wires crossed, but, on the other hand, I wish all of my mistakes would turn out this great! Claret in color with a rich and creamy head that reduces itself to a thin ring around the glass. Immense toasted malt aroma with traces of fresh baked bread and caramel. Intense roasted coffee flavor (akin to biting into a freshly roasted coffee bean) with hins of bitter chocolate. A long, hoppy and malty finish. Great way to wind out the weekend!

Well what do you know.  A happenstance gift from PsychProf fulfills two recent ambitions of mine.  So much buzz about Bear Republic recently and this becomes my first shot at them.  And then yesterday Oakes initiates the American Strong style onsite and lo, turns out Red Rocket fits the bill, giving me a chance to explore the style.  The beer?  Oh yeah.  Well, it comes surging forth with a huge head roaring over a deep garnet body and an effervescent effect much quicker than, but similar to, a Guinness cascade.  The aroma is honeymalty, strong with hops and you get a charge of those hops in the taste, too, but theyre largely blasted away by the sweet gunpowder smoke of the exceptional malt.  I dont know if its easier to handle than the Bastard or if my palate has just grown up considerably from by first sip of the ol AB.  Anyway, I enjoyed the beer.  Chalk up two American Strongs for hennes!

Deep garnet in color, the head is large and beige, the lace in sheets to coat the glass. Nose is malt, floral and hints of caramel. Front is sweet, the top is medium, the finish is highly hopped, acidic, dry, and quite a Hoot.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2004 You have to admire this brewery. I have never had a scottish ale packed this heavily with precisely the malt required, and a heavy dose of hops to boot! Not true to style, yes. The bastard brother to a more refined version like Alesmith's, but hey, who needs refinement. This brewery rocks my world. Thanks to crate and barrel stoppers, I can sample away without drunkeness, or maybe not...Sweet, peat, and heat.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: I tried it this evening.  I tell ya...It sounded good and the reviews all read well so, Im sure its me but, I didnt like it.  It was too sweet and too rich (if thats possible).  Maybe I was looking forward to it too much.  It smelled great and had a rich full head that stuck around but I just couldnt tolerate the taste and didnt finsih it.

Deep dark amber. Nice creamy foam with generous lacing and a resinous surface. Huge hoppy green, bushy, piney aroma with wisps of peat over a resinous surface. After the big flavor smack in the face, it feels a bit drying, slightly finely particulate. More big malt, big hops with some alcohol in the finish. The 6.8% is definitely appreciable.  Comparison to Arrogant Bastard is unavoidable.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2003 Garnet body topped by healthy beige head.  Aroma is sweet, grapefruit, caramel, floral.  Taste is malty, earthy, mildly sweet, light peat, alcohol, finishing earthy/grapefruit bitter.  Medium full body, slightly chewy.
A real kick in the butt!  Hoppy, aggressive, a nice wake up call on a hot Saturday.  Solid brewery across the board.

This is a really good beer, missed the brewery in Healdsburg, but caught the brew in Eureka.  Wonderful hoppy, flavorful beer that was just right.  I could live on this beer, and everything the Bear Republic Brewery makes.  Except for the wheat.
Bear republic, what can i say. The absolute best.
Another big, assertive West coast ale.  Very deep flavors of roasted caramel and chocolate, and since its Bear Republic, you know there are a ton of hops to boot.  Nice stuff.
Basterdized may be a little harsh, but not very close to a McEwans Scotch Ale. Caramel/Chocolate malt, smooth creamy mouthfeel. Nice hoppy bitter finish.

Mahogany colour, rocky head, and a rich, earthy aroma and palate showing lots of caramelly malts and foresty hops. The brewery considers this a bastardized Scottish ale, and they might not be far off - maybe a strong, robustly hopped Irish Ale is more accurate.

Big, creamy, lots of flavor. I dont know that I agree it is a Scottish ale. Too hoppy for that. But I like hops and I like this beer. The fermentation has produced some great flavors. I think Ill have to pick some up next time I go to BevMo. 

(PS, the brewery is a fun place, too. Good pub grub. Last time I was ther in 1998, they had regular live music.)
